name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 18 and 19 October 2018 (2018/2771(SRRs)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, when we meet in October, leaders will return to the key themes recently discussed at the informal summit in Salzburg: migration, security and Brexit. First, the European Council will discuss migration. We should continue working on all aspects of our comprehensive approach. To start with, we must do better in taking the fight to people-smuggling networks, from monitoring and disrupting their communications online to supporting cooperation between our police forces. Protecting our external borders and facilitating returns are of course key. In addition to everything that has already been done in this respect, the discussions in Salzburg showed the sheer determination that the recent Commission proposals should be examined as a matter of priority. Finally, we need to work more closely with countries of origin and transit by building new partnerships. This means, in particular, reaching out to African countries to expand and deepen our cooperation. In this context, Chancellor Kurz and the President of the European Council, President Tusk, recently met President Al-Sisi in Cairo and in New York to intensify cooperation. During the informal discussions in Salzburg, backing from the European Council was found for this and similar dialogues. In the coming weeks, Chancellor Kurz, President Tusk, the Commission and a group of Member States will continue reaching out to other African partners. As agreed in Salzburg, there will be an EU—Arab League summit in February 2019 in this respect. The European Council in October will look into all these issues, and the Chancellor will report on the reform of the Common European Asylum System and on the prospect of progress on its various elements. Second, the European Council will agree on immediate priorities to strengthen our internal security. In the past few years, we have achieved much collectively, including through important legislation agreed with this Parliament, from the passenger name record to the fight against terrorism financing, as well as better police, judicial and intelligence cooperation. We have certainly made headway. We need to continue this work, while focusing on effective implementation. Fostering a strong sense of security in Europe is our collective responsibility and, indeed, a priority of the Presidency. Safeguarding our security also means being prepared for new types of threats, whether they take to form of cybercrime, disinformation or any type of manipulation. How we should adapt to this evolving environment was a central issue for the leaders in Salzburg. One thing is clear: ahead of the next European elections, we need to protect our democratic processes. In the light of events, the European Council may also discuss international developments, but strengthening security is also about building up resilience to any kind of risks and being prepared when crises strike, be it as a result of hybrid attacks or natural disasters. Forest fires this summer demonstrated the importance of European cooperation in that field. The European Council will address these issues in October, but the leaders’ reflections on the longer-term aspects will also feed into the preparation of the next strategic agenda. Finally, on Brexit, the European Council will need an Article 50 format to review the state of negotiations with the United Kingdom. As President Tusk said in Salzburg, this European Council will be the moment of truth for the Brexit negotiations, where we expect maximum progress and results in the Brexit talks.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, Madam President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I will be very brief this morning as the President of the Council has summed up the results or near-results of the informal summit in Salzburg to perfection. It was an informal meeting, so no conclusions were reached. Nevertheless, I should welcome the fact that in general, not in detail, but on the main principles, the proposals recently and previously subject to the co-legislator's attention and meditation have received quite broad support.  There is no agreement, on nothing except on a few points, notably on the Commission's proposals to remove terrorist messages from the internet within one hour, or on the protection of the results of the European elections and the protection of the election campaign leading us to this important date. On the other points, the European Council expressed the view that all the proposals submitted by the Commission deserve to be treated as top priorities at the forthesty Council and at the Council in December. This concerns both the reform of the Dublin system and the protection of external borders. In this regard, I was nevertheless surprised that those who have consistently called for better protection of external borders are now making hesitant progress towards the comprehensive solution that the Commission has submitted. As far as the security union is concerned, the Commission's proposals have been widely agreed between the Member States. I would like us to agree by the end of the year on the reform of the Dublin system, which can no longer wait, and to agree on the exact contours of the protection of external borders. As far as Brexit is concerned, I don't want to add remarks to the remarks already made by the President of the Council. We will have an interesting meeting as far as Brexit is concerned.  Just two points: we want a deal. Those who think that a no deal would be the best solution are not aware of the difficulties such a scenario would imply. When it comes to the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, we are sticking to the point of view we have expressed so many times. Ireland first.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, before we talk about the next European Council, it is really worth looking back to Salzburg, because there was something unique, namely unity on Brexit, and that was good to see. 27 Member States united in one main message, and this message was that when we talk about Brexit, we are not only always focusing about what is going on in Great Britain. We talk a lot about the Tory convention, we talk about how a majority in the House of Commons is possible. We first of all underline – when we talk about Brexit – what we believe in. I want to mention one concrete example about the freedom of movement, which was so heavily discussed in the Brexit referendum campaign. The idea that millions of Europeans can freely decide where they want to earn their money and where they want to live with their families is a huge achievement in view of the history of Europe. I hope that the Brits can simply understand that we still believe in this idea and that we still want to defend it. That was a big achievement of Salzburg, that we clarified our position in this regard. This is not about punishment, it’s simply about the question that we stick to the four principles of the single market, the four freedoms which we worked on during the last decades. Brexit is a tragedy, that’s clear, but it shows all those people what populism means, what populism brings – less growth, less certainty and less future. Now we experience a new level of populism when the Foreign Minister of Great Britain, Jeremy Hunt, is again comparing the European Union with the Soviet Union. I don’t want to answer, I only want to quote the former Foreign Minister of Poland, Radosław Sikorski, he said ‘Please, Mr Hunt, show us the Gulag. Please, Mr Hunt, show us the Soviet Union army troops in your country. Please show us the Stasi system in your country.’ Sikorski is right; Mr Hunt, you should apologise for what you said.  (Loud applause) Brexit means leaving the European Union and this means losing the advantages of this Union. That is the simple principle behind this. The biggest challenge for the politicians in Great Britain, like Hunt and Johnson, is probably that after March next year they have to take over responsibility. For the first time, they will have to explain to people what they did, what are the mistakes of their political engagement, and they cannot blame Brussels anymore for what is happening in Great Britain. That will be a big change for them. For us, we will not answer to these provocations in the same way. We will simply define what is important for us and for the European People’s Party (EPP) family. I want to clarify that the citizens are at the centre of the whole debate in two main questions. Firstly, about the Northern Ireland border: I fully support Jean Claude Juncker’s ‘Ireland first’, since we don’t accept a treaty that would lead to a hard border, put at risk the Good Friday Agreement, or put at risk the Peace Process. Secondly, on the millions of EU citizens in Great Britain and millions of British citizens in the European Union: we must find a way to guarantee the legal status of these citizens, even in the case of a hard Brexit. Even in the case of a hard Brexit, we need an idea for a ring-fencing agreement to guarantee the legal status of these citizens. Not money, markets or products are important; for us, citizens are important. On Brexit, a never—ending story is going on. Our principles are clear: border protection, border control, ten thousand Frontex officers. I and my Group have no understanding why there is opposition to the idea that we share the burden of border protection between the European level and the national level, to do it together. Why is there is opposition to this? We cannot understand this. A second point is that Europe must be still a continent that is ready to help people in need. We need a strong and an ambitious resettlement programme, and we should not reopen the dossiers which we have already agreed in this migration dossier. The third point: today we look to Syria, but tomorrow we will look more and more to Africa. That is why Europe cannot have a good future if our neighbour continent, Africa, is in a chaotic situation. That is why we have to care. We have to do our best to help. Finally, one short remark on the EurAsia Summit, which is also taking place in two weeks’ time. We are partners. The European People’s Party is a party of free and fair trade. The US stopped the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement. The US wants to build up walls and, having this in mind, Europe must be the continent that wants to build bridges. We want to work together with our Asian friends, but with the idea of a common level playing field. For example, on investment security we need a common understanding of what this means and we have to defend our critical infrastructure and our critical industry, so not all investments in the European Union are free-market based investments, and that’s why we have to do more on this to guarantee really free and fair trade. We shouldn’t be naive, we should defend our interests and we should be united on this. Finally, because trade is also an issue, let me underline that the Americans have concluded with our Canadian friends a trade agreement. That shows us that Washington is still ready for a compromise, probably that is a good moment after the successful trip of Jean Claude Juncker to Washington. This is the moment to give a new mandate to the Commission to start real negotiations with our American friends. We would support a free trade area between Europe and the US without tariffs.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, colleagues, let me share in the criticism of the irresponsible leadership in the United Kingdom. But even more, Mr President of the Council, we have to make a difference, and here the questions are going to start. One month after Salzburg – and my Group was looking forward to Salzburg and to making progress in solidarity – there is no solidarity. It is stuck, and the Council is not delivering solutions; The Council is collecting failures. MEPs represent hard-working people, hard-working people who are looking for solutions to our major problems, but there is no delivery. Look at the reform of the asylum system. We had an awkward summer where people started dying at sea again. Even the EU missions were in danger, because harbours were closed. What do you say to this? Where is the reaction? Where is the policy for better solidarity and new solutions? And let me ask you this: what gives you the right to push for the unpacking of the asylum package, which was voted in this House by an overwhelming majority? Why do you have the right to destroy this form of solidarity that has existed here? And what do you expect from it if you continue to block the fact that there is asylum reform? This is what I cannot understand, and this is what we are critical of. We have a common responsibility as Europeans to overcome the major challenges of our time. Migration is a global phenomenon, and we need to shoulder it if Europe is to be a credible project for our citizens. If Europe is humanity and dignity, as our Treaties say we are, Europe has to stand as the global player for the good. But we also have to tackle those domestic issues that are worries for our people. Let me ask... Let me ask, Madam President: when is social protection, were workers' rights, the fight against child poverty the main topic of a summit last time? Why are you not putting this on the agenda? Why do we not address these problems that are perissing people and which urgently need an answer? We have to tackle this together, but I see blockages. So far you are not the honest broker, so far this presidency is not the bridge builder, so far you have not achieved a breakthrough. My message to you today is: please tell Mr Strache and Mr Kurz that they are on the wrong track if they are trying to further divide Europe. We have the right to expect something different from this Presidency. We support Michel Barnier in his great work, because he makes it clear that Europe stands together and because he makes it clear that Europe has a concept, common rights, but also common obligations. I believe that the majority of people in the UK now know that they have been led on the wrong path and that it was a big mistake to make this decision to leave the community. It is a big mistake that the next generation in the UK will have to pay the hardest if there are no corrections. And if this government fails – and that is what it looks like – I think that the British have a right to express their opinion directly on it. That is the message we have to give to these negotiations. Let us dare to make a new attempt to live European solidarity. But to do so, you must also be prepared to initiate a radical change, a radical change in your working method. Go to the people of Europe, really dedicate yourself to the concerns that people have. You would then have our support. But, it needs change. The status quo cannot be managed in this way.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, leaving the people to my left and some of the people in my own political group aside, I have not yet met one person in this Parliament who doesn’t regret Brexit, and I haven’t met one person in this Parliament, except me, who is trying to avoid it.  As Mr Bullmann said, Mr Barnier is indeed very active, but he seems to be very eloquent in describing the economic impact on Britain. He never says anything about the economic impact on Europe. Britain leaving the common market is equivalent to 19 small and medium—sized countries leaving the common market at the same time. To come up with a new trade deal with one country is one thing, but to disentangle the relationships of thousands of companies, which have grown over 40 years, is quite another. Mr Juncker, had you at the time offered Britain a special deal on freedom of movement, Brexit would not have happened.  (Murmurs of disapproval) Yes, it is absolutely true and, by the way, for those who moan here, I would like to remind you that Mr Schröder got a special deal in 2004 when Poland joined – against my opposition at that time – with a restriction on freedom of movement of Poles coming into Germany for seven years which was, by the way, a restriction the British Prime Minister did not want. In order to end the confusion in London, we must end the ignorance here in Brussels. Mr Juncker, as a German I always felt that it was right that Britain won the Battle of Britain. Make sure you are not going to lose the battle for Britain.  (Applause)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, my proposal is that Mr Henkel repeat that speech at the Conservative Party Congress, not here in the European Parliament. He may deplore the situation, but it’s there that they have made the wrong decision and not here. Minister, I think that you have three priorities at the next European Council, after Salisbury. The first is to unblock the migration file and especially the migration file on Dublin because, let’s be honest, the Commission has a proposal and Parliament has an opinion, but when will the Council have an opinion?  It’s fantastic to find always ways and new proposals on migration, but you have to have a position. Take a position and we can start negotiations, because it is this broken Dublin system that really is the source of the rise of racism, problems with migrants, and also of nationalism and populism.  My second point to you is to put on the agenda in October the question of our values. We see it everywhere in Europe – and certainly in a number of countries: illiberalism is on the rise, and it will not be by being silent that it will go away. On the contrary, it will continue. I think that the time is here to put it on the agenda, because the Kaczyński government is continuing, they are now already abusing the SES system, the Schengen Information System, to stop democracy advocates and activists. Mr Orbán is even financing, I think with European money, a campaign against the European Parliament, Mr President. You spoke about that yesterday. My question to you, to the Presidency of the Council, is are you going to put Article 7 concerning Poland and Hungary on the agenda of the next European Council? (Applause)  I want a clear answer from you. You are obliged to do so based on the Treaties and based on the fact that the Parliament has activated Article 7. My third priority, colleagues, is naturally to keep and to reiterate unity on Brexit – unity between the Member States, unity between the institutions. This unity is absolutely needed when you see these insane notions of some Tory politicians the last days, like Boris Johnson whose latest invention, you’ve seen, is to build a bridge. He will solve the problem by building a bridge between the UK mainland and Ireland, when Mr Boris Johnson is more known for burning bridges than for building bridges! Then there is Mr Rees Mogg who is saying, yeah I have the proposal for the future of Brexit and ordinary citizens can be secure that their savings will be secure after Brexit, and in the meanwhile he’s opening himself an investment fund in Ireland to transfer his money to Ireland! Manfred Weber has already talked about Jeremy Hunt comparing the European Union with the Soviet Union, but in his case I have to tell you that is not so abnormal for him, Manfred, as he once even confused Japan with China. So that is not the first time that this is happening. But that said, the previous time he was insulting his wife, but here he does something far more different. He is insulting not us, but millions of ordinary citizens who lived under Soviet rule for such a long time.  (Applause) That is in fact a point on which he has to apologise, I think, because we cannot accept such a thing he said.  My proposal, Minister, is that you have three clear messages at this Council meeting. First, on the migration system, we will never accept discrimination based on skills and on nationality, as Javid this morning proposed. Secondly, that we will never accept – and I say it also very clearly to the British colleagues here – an extension of this whole procedure.  Mr Boris Johnson this morning has said ‘we want an extension of Article 50’. I think it’s a very bad idea. Enough mess has been created by Brexit; enough uncertainty has been created by Brexit. Let’s stop it. The third is that we will never give in and undermine the principles of our Union. We will never undermine the principles of the Union European project to rescue a political party in Britain which is not even capable to find a common line on the exit from the mess of Brexit. (Applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a fortnight ago, the Heads of State and Government of the European Union met informally in Salzburg. First, they carefully ignored this Parliament’s call to open an Article 7 procedure on Hungary, and then they focused on what they believe is their main topic, migration, as if this were the existential topic that our union is facing. Once again, they failed to reach any substantial agreement. I have only one thing to say about this: a year ago, the vast majority of this Parliament had the strength and the audacity to go beyond Dublin and to agree on how our union, by acting together, can fulfil its humanitarian duty in a responsible and effective way. The European Council would be well advised to follow in our footsteps. However, one thing on which the EU 27 did agree, was their stance on the Brexit negotiation. I shall readily agree that some statements made after Salzburg were unnecessarily blunt, but they came nowhere close to what we heard from the British Foreign Secretary, who took over the now commonplace rhetoric of the far right, comparing the European Union with the Soviet Union. Let him be reminded that the United Kingdom decided freely to join the European Union. It also decided freely to hold a referendum on its membership in which the citizens voted freely. A majority chose to leave, and we respect that decision. However, to those – especially in the United Kingdom – who blame the EU27 for lack of flexibility, I will say this: we cannot be held responsible for resolving intractable contradictions in the British position. Indeed, it is this Government’s choice to interpret the referendum as a decision to leave both the single market and the customs union. It is also its choice to refuse any form of special status for Northern Ireland, and it was its free choice to be party to the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Ireland. These three constraints are incompatible with one another, and resolving this British contradiction can in no way justify the dilution of the single market, one of the Union’s key pillars.  To both leavers and remainers, I will say that it is in no—one’s best interest to have the United Kingdom crash out of the European Union. This would imperil peace in Ireland, it would jeopardise the prosperity of too many of our fellow citizens, and it would poison the relationship between the two sides for the foreseeable future. We should now focus on the only thing that matters, namely finding, in the next few weeks, an agreement on the terms of the withdrawal. This will then provide both sides with the time needed to build our future relationship and, in our view, no relationship between the UK and the EU surpasses EU membership. Who knows, there may come a day in the near, or distant, future when the majority of British citizens will assert that the only way for Britain to be global is to be part of the European Union. Our door will remain open to you. You will always be welcome where the United Kingdom really belongs.  (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that we are now at a stage in the Brexit negotiations where it is getting tighter and where I have the impression that we are always trying to shift the blame for a possible failure as far away as possible. I am talking here in particular about the British Government. I certainly am not one of those who have gone into the Brexit approach of wanting to punish the British for their democratic decision or to make a symbolic decision. But what we are seeing is that, against the background of infighting, and unclear conditions, particularly in the governing party, this government in The United Kingdom is not in a position to provide even a single clear formulation of the main problems that lie ahead. What we are getting is hü und hott and no and yes and is not possible, and it is an attempt to distinguish ourselves from the failure of the negotiations – before the possible failure and increasingly likely failure – and to create a new starting point for oneself. This leads to extremely embarrassing statements by British ministers, which are absolutely unacceptable. What I would like to draw attention to, including with regard to the Irish question, is that we must make the following clear to the British Government once again: if it does not want a solution, if it does not want acceptance of the Good Friday Agreement, if it does not want to make the passage contained in the declaration of December last year, its concession that it made there, its commitment which it has made there, if it does not want to implement it, it should make it clear. Then it saves us time, money, manpower, then saves us from crumbling over things that are not to be solved at all. Then we will at least have a clear announcement. My second point is that we are still a long way from talking about what should come after it, for example on free trade agreements. However, i would also like to make my announcement to us, to the Council, to Parliament, to the Commission: we should not do anything that restricts future development opportunities, including democratic decision-making, by other governments in the United Kingdom, but also within the European Union, for example, to decide to take on stronger social commitments, to develop more democracy in their respective countries. Nor should we restrict this by negotiating free trade anywhere later. I would like to make that very clear once again. For example, you would lose the support of my group for a fair solution, which we need to shape the common future. On the Council. So, I have to make it quite clear once again: the Council has so far failed to cash in on anything under the Austrian Presidency – it has not redeemed anything! I am thinking in particular of the cancellation of the meeting of social ministers on the grounds that we have not yet come to that point. I do not think that has happened at all in recent weeks and months that, in the light of the fact that a social summit took place in Gothenburg a year ago, we do not even see themselves in a position to demand, strengthen and really send out the social signals here. My colleagues have already said a lot about migration. I fully support that. The question of the Dublin reform. But who would expect the Austrian Presidency to come up with something when the relevant ministers meet with the Italian ministers, with Salvini, with others and discuss solutions there, that they want to take control or asylum decisions already at sea. Have you ever thought about what this means that in September alone, one in five of those who fled Libya is either dead or disappeared? Can you even get an idea of what is happening? Do you not have your own responsibility to move this forward, to come up with solutions that are human and that will take us forward as a Union and strengthen our shared responsibility? So I can only say that, unfortunately, you are fulfilling all the reservations that we saw at the beginning of the Austrian Presidency. I demand that you act more actively, to act humanely, to act democraticly, and not simply to support people who ultimately have something completely different in mind. And I would also ask you to do the following: when we talk about Hungary and Poland, please look at Italy too. The law, the decree that was waved through or presented last week, to put a halt to migration – it should be carefully examined to what extent EU values are being violated here. I think in particular the reversal of the presumption of innocence for migrants and asylum seekers.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as the moment of truth approaches for the Brexit negotiations in a couple of weeks’ time, I have to say that Brexiteers are dismayed at the way that our Prime Minister has acted. I’ve got to hand it to you, Mr Juncker: your negotiators are very much better than ours. The previously undiscussed issue of the Irish border, never a problem at any point during the referendum, has very effectively been weaponised by Barnier. But of course, this has got nothing to do with the Good Friday Agreement. Nothing to do with the peace process whatsoever. No, Barnier is much cleverer than that. This is all to do with making sure that the United Kingdom stays with the European regulatory framework. The one thing Barnier has been scared of from the start is us leaving and us becoming competitive. Sadly, the British Prime Minister has fallen hook, line and sinker for this, and we find ourselves now going into this next summit in a very weak position.  There is of course a better approach to all of this that would satisfy democratically both the Brexit vote and, I think, the demands of German industry and exporters. Don’t forget what an important marketplace we are. Your exporters call us ‘Treasure Island’, so many motor cars and so much wine and Belgian chocolate do you sell us. We should go for a simple free-trade deal. For 20 years here, everybody from Commissioner Kinnock to Valéry Giscard d’Estaing has said to me: if you want to leave political union and have a free- trade deal, that’s fine by us, we just need a prime minister who actually understands it. I know the European Commission would not necessarily want this, because they’re trying to use the Brexit vote as a means of saying that leaving this club comes at a price, but I do believe it would be possible. But we get to the heart of what this European Union is when we see the behaviour of the unelected bureaucrats, people like Mr Tusk, whose behaviour at Salzburg was arrogant, low—grade and pretty vulgar in every respect. But that is what you get when you design a form of government that gives power without accountability. Nobody voted for these guys, and nobody can get rid of these guys, they can do what the hell they like, and increasingly the nature of this club is authoritarian, taking away voting rights from Hungary, Poland and who knows next.  There is one little victory though that I’m pleased with. For a decade here I have noticed that that centralising authoritarian tone began to sound very like the old Soviet Union, with the concept of limited sovereignty of individual nation states. I have even talked in the past about the ‘Volkerkerker’, the old Austro-Hungarian prison of nations, and to see the British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt now using that language means that we have shifted the centre of gravity, we have shifted this debate. I know many of you here still think that we’re a hostage and that you’re going to demand some extraordinary ransom from us. We are not. We are a free people. Under the right leadership we’d say to you: let’s have a free-trade deal, or we would simply walk away. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: There is some difference with the Soviet Union, since the Soviet Union has also caused millions of deaths. I do not believe that the European Union has caused millions of deaths.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the October European Council will focus on migration. This is a good thing, because nothing is more serious than the migration submersion that Has been the victim of Europe since 2015. And the hardest part is ahead of us because Africa will double its population by 2050, which could lead to an additional influx of economic migrants, not to mention the climate change that is likely to amplify the phenomenon.  In the face of this challenge, the European Union unfortunately takes a contradictory position, because it shows firmness in intentions, but weakness in action. In its speeches, the Union announces its desire to curb the migration flood through, in particular, the cooperation agreements with Turkey and other countries. We would like to believe it, but the catastrophic content of the 2015 agreement with Turkey shows that it is incapable of defending European interests. By comparison, Italy has defended its interests much better and, therefore, our interests by negotiating directly with the Libyan authorities. Worse still, the Union is ruining its alleged efforts in trying to impose its crazy policy of relocating migrants to European states. It is a great call for air for the millions of foreigners who dream of coming to Europe and for the irresponsible NGOs that want to bring them. Fortunately, courageous states, such as Hungary and Poland, are resisting. By their firmness, these two states show us the only way forward if we are to save the identity of the European peoples.  To stop mass immigration, helping Africa is needed. Finding readmission agreements is also necessary, but the key is to give a strong signal by refusing relocations.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, as we approach the October Council, let me once again make some things clear to both Mr Barnier and the Member States who continue to use Northern Ireland and the impossible demands of the backstop as a sword hanging over the outcome of the negotiations. The idea, as proposed in the backstop, that we would allow Northern Ireland to become some sort of semi-detached part of the United Kingdom is both offensive and outrageous. Protecting the constitutional and economic integrity of the United Kingdom is a red line that cannot be broken or bent.  I say to the EU as well as my own government, that when it comes to the stability of the United Kingdom and the security of northern Ireland’s place in it, mark my words, we are not bluffing. The Irish Sea checks proposed by Mr Barnier, would put in place customs and regulatory differences within the United Kingdom, cutting our province adrift and creating a border within the United Kingdom from day one. Mr Juncker, you may only be concerned about the Irish Republic and the Dublin government, with your ‘Ireland first’ comment, but I am concerned about the jobs and prosperity of families in Northern Ireland, whose economy is structurally linked to the rest of the United Kingdom. The sooner Brussels realises this, the sooner we can get to a place where a sensible trade negotiation as possible.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President of the Commission, representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his excellent work and for his excellent work. At the next Council summit, migration must remain the number one issue alongside Brexit. I confess that, at the last summit in June, I thought that we had finally achieved a breakthrough, that we had made some progress on the common approach to migration, that we had agreed on broad guidelines among the Member States. But when I now evaluate what was achieved at the informal Council in September, I have to admit that it is very, very disappointing! What happened? The increase of Frontex to 10,000 men: not agreed. Landing platforms outside the EU: you have talked about Egypt, but here too little, far too little has happened. Anchor centres in the EU: I do not see that anything has developed. Long speech, short sense: I very much hope that the Presidency of the Council will continue its efforts at its next summit and will not let up in order to take a substantial step forward on migration as well. The second point I would like to raise is what my group leader, Mr Weber, has already raised, namely relations with the United States. Mr President of the Commission, you negotiated with Mr Trump. I would like to compliment you once again. Before the summer recess, they managed to keep our relations on hold here. I believe that it is indeed now time to recalibrate the transatlantic relationship. I would simply ask you to encourage you to make every effort to achieve sensible relations with the United States.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Madam Presidents, honourable, I will be very critical of the Austrian Presidency.  You say that we must tackle the challenges of migration at all levels, but unfortunately you are doing the opposite. You're directing all your energy exclusively to safety. The security of Europeans is crucial, I agree, but there will be no security if we are building a fortress of Europe if we do not have an effective European migration and asylum policy and if people outside the European walls continue to die.  Migration management does not mean strengthening security. We in the European Parliament adopted all the necessary legislation before the summer, we negotiated in good faith and reached an agreement with European governments, and you now want to break it. I am saying this as rapporteur for the regulation on criteria for international protection, and this is not the only agreement you want to break. Your country is also seriously undermining Schengen by inexcusable ly prolonging internal border controls, including at the border with my country, Slovenia, and I find it difficult to explain this to my citizens, so I call on you to lead the Union much more responsibly and sensibly by the end of the year, because we care what is happening to Europe.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must stop illegal migration to Europe. This can only be done by basing ourselves on the Australian model. It is incomprehensible that NGO boats pick up migrants just off the coast of North Africa and then sail towards Europe instead of a safe haven in the region. Saving lives is noble, but supporting clandestine migration to Europe is not. At the June European Summit, it was decided to examine whether regional disembarkation platforms could be an alternative. These centres in third countries would then accommodate the drowning people. This practice is fully in line with international law. In the same breath, it was decided that all boats operating in the Mediterranean should not interfere with the Libyan Coastguard. So not even when Libya, mindful of those platforms, is stopping boats heading towards Europe. The bailout that no longer automatically results in an asylum application in Europe will be very dissuasive. As in Australia, this will reduce the tragic drowning to zero. In this way, we can get migration back under control, which increases public support for the real needy and the people smugglers lose their source of income. Like the European Heads of Government, I ask the Commission and all the relevant ministers in the European Union to adopt the Australian model. Hopefully, the European summit will finally reach concrete agreements to tackle illegal migration decisively.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, with regard to the previous speaker, I don’t agree with her policy choices but I agree with one thing and that is that the attitude of the Council when it comes to migration is absolutely shameful. The Council has become the bottleneck for mainly all policies, but in particular migration, because the European Commission has made proposals for a common policy, the European Parliament has managed to agree, across the political groups on a policy. Even the Pope – and I am not known for praising the Pope – is supportive. NGOs are supportive. Opinion polls show that the vast majority of Europeans are very pragmatic and they expect us to act when it comes to migration.  Local authorities are taking a different attitude. There are 28 individuals, national government leaders, blocking any kind of decent and efficient asylum and migration policy. It is your responsibility in the Council to unblock that situation.  The same goes for the rule of law. I’m glad that the Council has at least twice discussed the situation in Poland, but I think you should take your responsibility and discuss the situation in other countries where there are reasons for concern, such as Romania, Hungary, Slovakia and Malta, but also finally agree to a broader mechanism that will treat all Member States equally and gives an annual assessment of the health of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights throughout the European Union and not dither any longer.  Finally, on Brexit, I can see that the biggest ego in this House, Mr Farage, after making his speech has left again, as he always does. He is literally playing Russian roulette with his Russian friends with the well—being of the British people, and now by criticising Mrs May he is trying to dodge responsibility for the mess that he has created and for which the British people are going to pay the price. I’m very glad, and with this I’ll conclude Madam President, that the EU is united, because the real problem is not unity in the European Union. The real problem is the lack of unity in British politics. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question. You seem really outraged about a lot of things. Do you not understand that maybe the Heads of Government are reticent about taking on these noble ideas you have, because actually they have to be elected by the people in their countries, and these opinion polls you speak about are not relevant to those Heads of Government? Do you not see that?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Etheridge, I come from a party that has actually won the elections – and we are in government now – with the noble rhetoric that you are talking about. Maybe if you were to adopt the same rhetoric, then you too would finally get elected in your own home country.  (Applause)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, hearing Jeremy Hunt use the far right trope of associating the European Union with the Soviet Union is an abuse of history and an insult to those who suffered under Soviet repression. I’d like to offer my apology on behalf of the many British people who respect the brave struggle for freedom fought by our friends in Central Europe and the Baltic states.  For many countries, the EU has supported their path away from authoritarianism and towards prosperity. Our current cooperation in peace, democracy and human rights celebrates that achievement. Coming from a country that has always prided itself on diplomatic prowess, for me the speech was part of an unfolding national tragedy. This is where the ignorance of Brexit has led us. Insulting our friends, misrepresenting our history, indulging our fantasies of a return to the colonial past. But the Brexiteers are running out of steam. In an equally lacklustre speech yesterday Dominic Raab claimed that democracy is sacrosanct. So I’m waiting for him to join me in calling for a criminal inquiry into ‘Vote Leave’, of which he was a board member, and into Russian interference in the Brexit campaign. True democracy cannot be based on deceit and an empty prospectus; it requires that British people make a choice on the deal as negotiated so that they can decide whether this is the Brexit they voted for. When it comes to Brexit democracy demands a people’s vote. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Molly. You and I will of course disagree, but we have always had a courteous exchange going right back to Pembrokeshire back in 2001.  In your call for a second referendum, do you not realise, with respect, that the goalposts have moved? People like myself, who campaigned against the European institutions for the last 22 years, were warning about ever closer union, warning about qualified majority voting on taxation – as Mr Weber often calls for – and warning about EU militarisation. This has, of course, all been discussed since the referendum result. Is it not the case now that were Britain to change its mind, foolishly, we would actually be going towards a federal model?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card answer. – I agree that times have moved on. We’ve learned that the Brexit referendum was fought on the basis of cheating, criminality, manipulation and psychological operations. The goalposts have definitely moved, because we now know that the people are waking up to the fact that they were lied to, the fact that this cannot be sorted out in an afternoon, that we haven’t got trade deals, that we’re heading for a calamity. Therefore, I completely agree with you. The goalposts have moved, and that is the biggest justification there can be for a new referendum.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, at the next Council meeting you will discuss migration again, but the debate will not focus on what to do so that those who need it can safely reach Europe or how to launch an operation in the Mediterranean so that not one more person dies. The debate will be, once again, on how to increase control and protect our borders. And the question is, protect us? Whose? Who are the enemies to protect yourself from with fences, deportations, beatings or even gunshots? People like Hayat Belkacem, a nineteen-year-old girl killed by the Moroccan navy thanks to the agreement by which Morocco is the guardian of the southern border of Europe? Or rather the enemy is the seventeen-year-old boy who had locked up in a detention centre for foreigners in Murcia and who has been deported by skipping all international human rights legislation? As always, they point to the people below so we don't look up.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address Mr Juncker and the Council. With regard to the Italian Government's position on immigration, we have received an explosive situation with regard to immigration, because what has been created in Libya by bombs in the past, by governments that were not represented by us, has created major problems. This is the fundamental point on which the Council meeting must also focus: finding a solution in Libya, France, Italy, the United States and the European Union. A table to find an immediate solution, because there is a obviously implosive risk on a nation that is far from stable at the moment and the flows will have decreased now, but could also get worse. What has the Italian Government done? When we found ourselves receiving this problem, it accepted and welcomed more than the other European countries, because we took people who very often did not even qualify for asylum. The European Union has turned its back on us completely, and the revision of the Dublin Regulation also requires us to make procedures that would make Italy Europe's great refugee camp. There is no accountability on the part of Europe on this, and what have we done? We have started to defeat the immigration business, the NGOs that brought and ferryed these people and made agreements most likely also with organised crime in Italy, they have been defeated for the time being by this government, but a European solution is still not on the table and therefore for Libya and for this problem it should be put at the forefront by the Council. As far as the economy is concerned, excuse me, but if we also look at the accounts and procedures of the six pack, since yesterday you made some very heavy statements, I would like to understand why, Mr Juncker, two years ago, when France was due to be put under procedure, you, in an interview with the same question that you received yesterday, said that France will never be put under procedure and the rules do not apply to France. , because France is France, while for Italy what is it? Is it not a government that you like because it really says what it thinks and tends to defend citizens' rights for once? So try to understand these positions or in the next European elections on 26 May your party will have a bad end.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I strongly object to the fact that bad words are being used here against the Austrian Presidency. On the contrary, the Austrian Presidency is a model of best practice for how to handle such a Presidency. And the Austrian government is also supported by an increasing strengthening and an increasing trust by the population. With the actual causa here, the Brexit debate, I can only tell you that you are travelling in the wrong way here. The British have decided to leave the European Union. I regret that because I would have liked the British to have been a reform partner. But a democratic vote must be respected. I can only ask you not to deal with this with a revenge action here, but to treat the British with friendship, and I hope that you will finally be able, as a European nomenklatura, to negotiate with the British an orderly exit scenario that is mutually beneficial and does not bring the British into a revenge action. And, when we discuss the Presidency of the Council and the current Council, you must finally be able to give the answer to where this Europe should go. The only thing that can be about the future is more federalism, more subsidiarity, more powers back to their home countries. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, dear colleague – if you are listening to me – you have praised the Austrian Presidency. Can you tell me if you, since the Austrian Presidency, have found that there is any action, any concrete action related to supporting the principles of the European Union: solidarity, democracy, unity, a concern to keep Europe together?

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It goes without saying that the Presidency of the Council supports the issues you have raised. But solidarity – there is always the question of how it is judged, whether those states that are already burdened by problems are being held more accountable. The Austrian Presidency has chosen the motto: 'A Europe that protects', and with that the Austrian Presidency is hitting the nerve of the European challenge of our time, namely to solve the migration issue. And it is now clear, even by a majority of this House, that this issue must be resolved. Only a few people put their heads in the sand.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Thank you for the word. Migration is at the top of the AGENDA of the EU summit. I quote from the conclusions of 28 June: "Better protection of the EU's external borders must be ensured, ... resettlement of migrants within the EU will take place on a voluntary basis." On the other hand, the Sargentini report criticises Hungarian border protection measures and calls on Hungary to account for its inaction on the introduction of migrants under the mandatory quota.  Among the decisions taken on 5 June, it can also be agreed that the effectiveness of the return of migrants should be increased and that the problem should be solved at its root in cooperation with African states. Now it's time to execute.  And a thought about Brexit: the worst solution for both sides would be a disorderly exit without a deal, which can be avoided by mutual compromise. And let us take into account that the British Prime Minister is bound by the will of the people, because there was also a referendum on this issue.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, when the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, Spain will become the only European country with a foreign colony on its own soil. Gibraltar is not only a political conflict between Spain and the United Kingdom, it is also a stain on the process of European integration, a historical anachronism that before or after must be resolved.  There is currently a negotiation going on between London and Madrid that this Parliament should be aware of. First, to know how the working conditions of the more than ten thousand Spanish European citizens who live in the Campo de Gibraltar and who cross the border with Gibraltar every day; secondly, to find out what measures will be put in place to prevent Gibraltar from remaining an illegal money washer and capital evasion centre — a tax haven; thirdly, to prevent the continued smuggling of tobacco and other goods, which I do not mention, from Gibraltar to the single market every day; fourth, to stop toxic spills from the colony that damage the ecosystem of Algeciras Bay; fifth, for joint management of the airport. Sixthly, the Brexit agreement, in our view, should include a timetable for restarting bilateral negotiations on the issue of sovereignty, in compliance with the provisions of the United Nations and the Brussels Process.  The UK is leaving; Spain stays with friends. We will not find a better opportunity to resolve the unpresentable situation of the last remaining colony in Europe.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A meeting of the Heads of State or Government is chasing the other. This hectic activity is in clear contrast to the results. For years, the same issues – mostly migration – have been the motto that the solution has finally been ready. You just want to be able to explain to the local media afterwards that you have prevailed. Parliament's proposals remain largely ignored, and the problems remain unresolved – such as the situation in the hotspots on the Greek islands, which were announced at the time in full terms. The shelters for refugees are overcrowded and the hygienic conditions are intolerable. People are doomed to months and years of inaction and cannot count on fast, legally secure procedures. Children are particularly hard hit. Suicide, self-harm and conspicuous behaviour among minors are on the agenda. There is a need for action here, ladies and gentlemen. We need a real solution to the problems, not a symbolic policy.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – Mr President, Brexit will only have losers on both sides of the Channel. This was the result of a British report this year which showed that all regions in the United Kingdom are going to suffer. And that is not only true for the regions of the United Kingdom, european economies such as the Netherlands are going to suffer billions in damage. I therefore sincerely hope that Brexit can be reversed. Maybe by new elections, maybe by a second referendum. If that does not work, I hope that the British negotiators will remain close to the current status quo, certainly not a 'no deal' and neither will a hard Brexit, nor the checkers plan, because that is really just getting the raisins out of the porridge. Even after March 2019, we desperately need each other, which is why I am calling for special attention to be paid to fishing. For centuries we have shared the fishing grounds of the North Sea and let us continue to manage them together after March 2019. So especially not putting the knife to each other's throats, not going back to the old fishing wars, but working together. After March 2019, our fishermen should be able to fish in the North Sea on both sides of the channel and we must be able to trade our fish and fish products.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I also share the view of many colleagues that it is high time to unblock the Council on migration. Leadership of the Presidency here is needed, and many of the Members of the European Council are probably happy to have migration still on the agenda because it is a way to bash the EU all the time, and in fact the Czech Prime Minister says there is no other issue vis-à-vis the EU than migration. But I am afraid migration is not the only issue, though it looks like that’s the only problem. If we look at what our public says, 70 to 80% feel that the EU should have a higher role in trade policy. 70 to 80% want a European defence policy. Roughly the same number says that there are challenges in the economic area where Europe has a role to play. My question is, when are we going to close the gap on a number of those issues? When are we going to be delivering on those issues?  So migration, yes by all means, and let’s finally settle it. However, we finally need to address these issues as well. One sentence on Brexit: I’m all in favour of unity, and it’s great that we have it, but in terms of, for example, aviation safety, if EASA does not start technical talks with the CAA, we will be in a mess from next year on. That is my message to the Commission.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Once again, we are clinging to the same problems. Once again, we lament the same blockades: on migration, on the issue of flight, on Brexit, or when it comes to enforcing the rule of law in general within our European Union. I am not trying to deplore this again, but i want to focus on the fact that we are losing sight of other issues too much in the meantime. Trade has been talked about. The United States has now reached a new treaty with Canada and Mexico. We should not be persuaded that this will not mean additional pressure on the European Union. We are in a situation where we need to unite much more in order to get a good result in these negotiations, which Mr Juncker has launched wonderfully. I wonder why the Council is not taking this issue much further forward and why the Council is not making sure that there is finally a mandate that we can discuss here in the European Parliament. And I am surprised that the connectivity strategy, which has been reasonably put forward by the Commission and the EEAS, is not on the agenda. Because the future must also be shaped here! Let's not forget what's going on around us because we're doing too much belly-button show.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, as we debate here this morning, the competing wings of British conservativism are battling it out in Birmingham about the meaning of Brexit. A carnival of reaction if ever I saw one. What’s clear is that none of the Tories have any real concern about Ireland other than using us to score points in their internal party battle. None of them shows any commitment to previous agreements. They are so clueless that one thinks he can build a bridge between the islands, literally over a one million tonne unstable weapons dump, and another thinks he can currently spend sterling in Dublin.  So some selectively interpret the Good Friday Agreement to try to get privileged access to EU markets without having to follow any of the rules, while others would happily tear up that agreement along with the commitments they have already made in the Brexit negotiation. And Mr Farage says the border was not an issue during the referendum. Well he’s dead right it wasn’t, because that just shows you the level of Brexiteer ignorance that there was during the referendum of the history of Ireland. So the Dublin government and the EU must hold firm and insist that the rights of people in Ireland are not up for negotiation and that Ireland will not be collateral damage.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years Italy has been invading by 700,000 illegal immigrants. Meanwhile, the European Commission was producing hot air. What you have not done in recent years, we are doing in a few months, thanks to our leader Matteo Salvini: border control, closed ports for ships full of illegal immigrants, iron fist against illegal immigration. With the new decree Salvini will finish the parcel for illegal immigrants and in Italy there will be security, respect for the laws and justice. Irregular immigrants who have arrived in Italy illegally prepare to return to Africa. We will go ahead with the revolution of common sense and always defend the interests of the Italians, against this Europe complicit in mass immigration. Macron and the false goodies of the left are warned. Let them stop with their ridiculous lies and rinse their mouths before speaking ill of Italy and the Italians.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, unfortunately over the last four years illegal immigration and the networks of traffickers have been raging, as long as the Union continues to use failed tools and implement the wrong policies. External borders are perforated, national sovereignty is restricted, there are no disincentives against illegal immigrants, and recently ways of legitimising and further widening migration route are being invented.  It is now officially recorded that 1 in 13 are nationals of a third, non-European, country. Of course the reality is even more ominous.  Taking action does not require any innovation, because clearly illegal residents are de facto criminals. They entered our countries illegally and remain within our territory without settling their residence status. It is a question of restoring legitimacy and a sense of security among citizens, preventing the arrival of illegal immigrants and deporting those who have entered and are deprived of legal documents and legal residence. The demands are simple: No to illegal immigration. Not the creation of parallel societies. Not to alter the concept of citizenship. (Speaker refuses jaakonsaari blue card question)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Allow me to start by saying that this House and the Commission, which has been confirmed by this House and whose President of the Commission has been elected by the directly elected European Parliament, are fully democratically legitimised. And we have to hold on, more legitimate than the Prime Minister, who never faced a vote in the House, but where it was enough to kiss the Queen's ring. I think we should keep that in mind. We have to see that Mr Farage has never been elected to the national parliament in the United Kingdom, despite many attempts. We have been waiting for the British proposal for a year and a half. Then came Chequers. Then Mrs May said: "Take it or leave it. In other words, we are waiting a year and a half for a proposal that will come and which will then have to be accepted by us, and otherwise it will be an insult, as has been said. What we are supposed to do now is clear: make the Withdrawal Treaty quick. Only the Irish question can be resolved. With goodwill, this is done, there are enough eu proposals to solve this problem. And then we have two years to negotiate a decent free trade agreement and also to negotiate the other internal and external security treaties. Let us move away from the rhetoric of these party congresses, from the insults of Mr Hunt and others – if we were to do that, the devil would be loose – and finally negotiate this withdrawal treaty in order to achieve good further cooperation. This must now be achieved, and the English must finally get to the agenda. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Brok, like it or not, the UK and the Republic of Ireland are going to have to get on and it’s going to have to work out. However that happens, it’s going to be difficult, but it’s going to have to work out. For that to work out, we don’t need MEPs like you coming in here – I’m no fan of Ms May, no fan of the Conservative Party – but it doesn’t help you coming in here and questioning whether their Prime Minister is legitimate or not. It’s up to them to decide. I’ll say it again: no time for her, but you are not helping, you’re making its worse, Elmar. Stop it.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Brok, is it clear to you that it was Mr Barnier who said at the beginning that, before you have a solution for the border regime, you have to have a trade agreement? That was completely impossible. I do not know of any border regime without knowing what kind of trade agreement you have. This alone wasted a year.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, the constitutional order of the United Kingdom is a matter for the United Kingdom. But please do not attack us, we would not have democratic legitimacy! That is what I wanted to say. The European Union is democratically legitimised by national parliaments and by the direct election of the European Parliament and, from it, the Commission. That is why you should put an end to this alibi event with democratic legitimacy.  And I have to see that 27 democratically elected leaders have not accepted this British proposal. It is normal for something like this to happen. And that is why it must be noted (the President interrupts the speaker) And we have to say that the Republic of Ireland, as a member of the European Union, wants us to deal with this matter as well. And we will do so at the request of the Republic of Ireland. The point raised by Mr Henkel is that this is simply wrong. The fact that the Irish issue is included in the Withdrawal Treaty is an agreement at the beginning of negotiations with the united states. That is quite clear! And there are clear proposals on how to do it. And we want a free trade agreement. But that is why the border issue can be clarified beforehand, so that it runs in a decent way for the Irish.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, what has just been said about Brexit may as well be applied to the whole migration debate. The Commission came up with an agenda two years ago, and this Parliament has often voted in favour of reforming it, and what is the Council doing - democratically legitimised, admittedly - what is the Council doing? Two years of bickering, disagreeing and not coming up with any decent proposal. The only thing that is happening today is the so-called debate on the "disembarcation centres" and frankly: I don't know what that means. Who the hell comes up with names like that? At the same time, Madam President, at the same time, the Aquarius has lost its flag, the Aquarius which has saved 30 000 lives since its inception. That's 30,000 smiles and sixty thousand hands, maybe a hundred thousand dreams. Are there any people today in the Council, in the political centre, who are prepared to work with NGOs to uphold the values of the European Union?

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, if I may take the opportunity. The Belfast Agreement, also often referred to as the Good Friday Agreement, states ‘it is hereby declared that Northern Ireland, in its entirety, remains part of the United Kingdom and shall not cease to be so without consent of a majority of the people of Northern Ireland’. This is the principle of consent that is the heart of the Belfast Agreement. Nothing can camouflage that. Let me make it very clear to this House – and I have heard comments here this morning that I wished I would not have heard – the people of Northern Ireland, from all backgrounds, from all persuasions, do not want to ever, ever return to their past history. There has to be a solution found that ensures that that never happens in the future. That is the challenge. That is what politicians are here for. So I was very saddened this morning when I heard Mr Juncker say it is ‘Ireland first’. I’m sorry, I am from Northern Ireland, and I say it is the United Kingdom and it is Northern Ireland that must be first.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I’d like to address this to Mr Juncker, because it is about an announcement he made in March 2017. They say if you fail to plan, you plan to fail. This is why I was happy to hear, in March 2017, Mr Juncker come here and talk about a plan for the future of Europe up until 2025. He spoke about five options, and basically the options were full fiscal, economic, monetary or military union on one end of the rainbow, and on the other end of the rainbow we go back to being a group of trading nations. We were meant to have a discussion about this, a debate, something that I think would have helped a couple of years ago in Britain and would have actually headed off Brexit. We also had a series of reflection papers, which we were meant to discuss. We were also in theory meant to have a series of debates around Europe. Mr Juncker came here and told us about varying numbers, they didn’t add up. On the Commission blurb, they talk about this process, and they said it would help decide on a course of action to be rolled out in time for the EP elections in 2019. I now ask the question: where is this white paper on the future of Europe? How is it sitting with the various parties here? What is happening in the European elections in relation to it? Where is it, Mr Juncker? Where are you? Could you not have stayed here for three hours? Do you not get paid enough to do your damn job?

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here in power in the European Union, in 2014 we came here with an unprecedented number of EU critical Members who you called populists out of height and with a certain aversion. You took it to do things differently, less European Union, less federalism, less centralism. What we have seen for five years is the reverse, an explosion of federalism, a further centralization, "ever closer Union". Whereas no election has taken place in any Member State, including the referendums in the United Kingdom, which did not show the opposite, which did not bring closer the new era we represent here. It looks like 2019 will be the confrontation of those new and old times. Hence my message to Mr Juncker and, in fact, to the whole of his Commission and to the new merkel and Macron couple who want to take us further hostage in that strategy, and I say it in the words of Aznavour: 'Il faut savoir quitter la table lorsque l'amour est desservi, sans s'accrocher, l'air pitoyable mais partir sans faire de bruit'.  «Il faut savoir quitter la table lorsque l'amour est desservi, sans s'accrocher l'air pitoyable, mais partir sans faire de bruit».

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The recurring central theme of the EIT is to curb migration pressures. To do this, we must finally protect the Union's external borders, both on land and on water. It is clear that this is a matter of political will, and the means would be there for it. Frontex may play an important role in this, but under no circumstances can it take the protection of our own border out of our hands. We need to dismantle the business model of people smugglers and work with countries that are capable of eliminating migration routes. There is disagreement among Member States on basic solutions and measures, and I therefore find Commissioner Avramopoulos's outspoken pro-immigration stance at an event at the UN General Assembly unacceptable, such as legalising illegal immigration or supporting migrants to work in Europe, which extend far beyond his powers and authority.  Neither Hungary nor the Visegrad countries wish to become immigrant countries. We do not want to legalise or manage illegal migration, but we want to stop it. We want to preserve the safety of our citizens and, for our children, Europe as we know it. (Speaker rejects Liisa Jaakonsaari and Sophia in 't Veld's 'blue card' question)

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the complex problems we are facing would require less propaganda and more seriousness. Less propaganda, I say this to Mrs Bizzotto of the League, who gave us her usual rally. Here the clandestinity and illegality in Italy has fuelled the League with laws such as Bossi-Fini and the Salvini decree will only make matters worse.  So please, instead of canvassing, help us support the Dublin reform, which your allies like Orban continue to block. No more propaganda, Mr Valli, which perhaps even ignores, that when Juncker said those famous words, France was in deficit. The problem here is not the European Commission, the problem here is that you are bankrupting us with your irresponsible statements that will ultimately lead us to have more cuts and more austerity, and of course enough propaganda about Brexit. It is time to have an ambitious, serious, balanced agreement, we are ready, but there are two essential conditions and I believe that after Salzburg everyone has understood that.  We need an operational backstop which is not a frontier, but controls that already largely exist and a free trade area can be built, but without tearing apart the single market. We are ready, we are open, but we are united.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, I would like to thank mr Timmermans for his excellent work and for the work she has done. It is obvious that, after the totally unnecessary elections, the British Government has many problems, is weak and therefore negotiates very hesitantly. But the EU should not rejoice too soon, because an agreement is more important for the EU than for the British. Exports to the UK are twice as high as imports from the UK. The European Union has concluded a free trade agreement with Canada, and that should be possible with the United Kingdom. I think it should be possible to separate these four freedoms. If that works with other countries, why not the UK? There will be no further referendum in Britain. We should finally come to terms with this and show much more complacency. It seems to me that the EU is prepared to take itself to its knees just to punish the British.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: –Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Timmermans, first of all I would like to make it clear here that, without a doubt, the main issue to be dealt with in the next Council will be Brexit and that I think that we, as the European Union, should not react in a way, I would say, to be very hypersensitive and hyperactive to some provocations that come, whether on the side of the United Kingdom and even of its Government. , as we saw yesterday with Jeremy Hunt's statement, are on the side of populist forces here in the European Parliament and in the European Union. I think we should have a constructive attitude. We should not make any argument for the UK to say that we are blocking any negotiation process. Firm in our principles, but open to cooperation. Only in this way can we win this battle of getting a deal with the United Kingdom and eventually, if we fail, to stand before the electorate and public with the certainty that we have done everything we can to prevent a coup or a blockade in the negotiations. It is essential to have a constructive position. This does not mean giving up the four freedoms, it does not mean giving up the defence of a flexible and open border in Ireland and therefore, without giving up any of our principles, we must be as phlegmatic as the British in times past have accustomed us to be.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The creation of the European Union was a visionary, courageous step. Something completely new has arose: a boundless, peaceful cooperation between different states. And today? The European Council meets as a gathering of national politicians who stare desperately at national polls. We are constantly producing new so-called security laws, none of which have been fully implemented, but fundamental rights and the protection of privacy are coming under pressure. Migration and asylum must be organised together inside and outside Europe. And the single market? The people of Europe need a strong social pillar. Let us finally face up to these common challenges! Because the future of our democratic continent, the future of more than 500 million people, is worth every effort. You should finally start!

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The first topic of the forthcoming European Council will be migration. On the other hand, the conclusions of the June Council meeting, which noted, inter alia, that the Union has made a number of efforts to prevent a recurrence of the uncontrolled influx of people from 2015, are a point of reference. Better late than never, you'll say.  It would be good for the forthcoming European Council to go a step further and say that Angela Merkel's opening of the door to refugees in 2015 was illegal and that the governments of countries such as Hungary and Poland were right on migration. Admittedly, this is indirectly reflected in the conclusions of the June Council, where the mechanism for the compulsory relocation of refugees is not returned, and voluntary redefeitures are mentioned.  However, it must be borne in mind that border protection is paramount, which is primarily the responsibility of individual Member States, and frontex troops should only strengthen them. We must not allow a Member State to lose control of its border to Frontex. (The speaker refused to listen to the question raised by Liisa Jaakonsaari raising the blue card)

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, in the UK and recently also in Macedonia, referendums have put countries in a dead-end street. It is very clear that Brexit cannot be a success story, either for the United Kingdom or for the European Union. We would warmly welcome the UK back in if they decide to ask their citizens again and this is the will of the people. Brexit is the most irrational step in recent history which, if it not changed, will have a negative impact for the decades. You cannot have all EU benefits without being a member of the European Union.  I would like also to say some words on Macedonia. I hope the Council will reconfirm that the door for Macedonia is open for the European integration of this country and I’d like also to wish a lot of success to our countrymen there, for their European Atlantic way. European Atlantic integration remains the only way to secure stability in the Western Balkan region and to achieve historical reconciliation. I hope that the political class in that country won’t fall prey to populism and cheap PR in the days and months to come. On migration. Migration will be one of the most crucial topics in the next European elections and we need to prove to the European citizens that more Europe means more security and prosperity.
