The European Parliament has put the proposals on the table already, and I hope that the national leaders in the Council will swallow their egoism and find a workable solution to the problem. Among the concrete steps to tackle the migration flow are security on the external borders, prevention against radicalisation and terror and a united foreign and security policy in the Middle East and Africa.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We expect concrete results from the Council. This includes the protection of our external borders. It is not acceptable for some to evade solidarity on the grounds that we are not doing enough to protect the external borders, and if we then propose that we fall back into the small of the sovereign states, which would rather solve this on their own. And we also expect a clear word from you that those people who save others in the Mediterranean will no longer be criminalised. In eight months' time we will have a European election. You still have eight months to send a signal, so to speak, that what you have delivered so far is not enough for you. Anyone who believes that they can save anything by not acting is, in my opinion, on the wrong track. In any case, I no longer feel the desire to listen to the Speeches of the Heads of Government on Tuesday and Wednesday if they do not finally get to work. (The speaker refused to answer a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of Mr Jurek's Rules of Procedure))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Minister, Vice-President Timmermans, the European Council has a key responsibility and must come up with solutions to the current problems, which are still undoubtedly migration and security. Colleagues who are also calling for solutions to other important issues, such as social, environmental, issues, are important, but without returning trust to citizens on this key issue of security and migration, we will not move on.  In Salzburg, the Council of Ministers has made progress. Strengthening europe's border and coast guard is undoubtedly an important step, particularly in the form of increased human and material capacities. It is important that we also make progress on the creation of hotspots outside Europe.  The ineffective fight against irregular migration and the influx of economic migrants makes it politically impossible to help those who really need it. People who are vulnerable or, for example, child victims of war. I speak from experience, as I have been trying for several weeks to get the Czech Government to voluntarily, I underline voluntarily, accept 50 unaccompanied children from Greek camps in urgent need of protection, care and education. Even such a symbolic proposal is met with mistrust, provoked by populist forces that take advantage of the fear of illegal migration that we have unfortunately experienced in recent years. I want to assure you that the Czech Republic is in solidarity, contributing financially to the aid fund and to specific humanitarian projects. People in the Czech Republic want to help those who really need help.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for months the Heads of State or Government have been fighting the phenomenon of migration, each time arriving at vague and unachirresable solutions, on a voluntary basis. I would like to ask the Presidency-in-Office: what has changed since the June summit? Has a consensus been reached on the Dublin Regulation or has the reform been permanently shelved? Do you still vigorously oppose the centralised European asylum application system, based on the principle of solidarity and full sharing of responsibilities, as voted by Parliament last year? Continue to be trapped in your emergency logic. Rejoice at the reduction of landings without, however, developing global strategies for managing the migration phenomenon. Criminalising NGOs by denying the principle of safeguarding human rights. Yes, I now turn to Mr Valli: NGOs are now becoming the scapegoat for the failed and inhuman policies of the Italian Government, which is increasingly populist and xenophobic, shredded in the mud with false accusations and criminalising their humanitarian activity. Shame on you! Yet Italy pioneered the search and rescue system in the Mediterranean with Operation Mare Nostrum, and I would remind you that tomorrow marks the fifth anniversary of the Lampedusa massacre.  In the Council: invent new legislative procedures so as not to assume your responsibilities in debating a proposal for a regulation already adopted by Parliament. Focus on Dublin and not your workarounds.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam Chairman, there are three topics that should dominate the European Council.  First of all, an indispensable Brexit, which I think was a huge mistake, and now that we are already here, I am in favour of resolving the issue with Ireland and prioritising it, as we have already heard.  Another topic, which is very important, is the protection of external borders and internal security. Speaking of external borders, I'm sure the Dublin rule needs to be improved. Parliament had its own position, the Commission had its own proposal and we expect the Council to finally take a decision on the Dublin system. That would be very good. I speak now on behalf of Croatia, which has the longest border in the European Union, the longest land border of 1350 km and the protection of the external border is terribly important to us. It is the only country that is outside Schengen with such a long border. And the third topic is certainly trade and should talk about trade agreements. After Jean-Claude Juncker's visit to the United States, I am sure that transatlantic relations need to be improved, but I also support the Eurasian Summit.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, chaos and confusion reign when it comes to Brexit. The British Government is torn apart by its internal divisions on the matter and is reverting to the tired old game of blaming Brussels for its own internal divisions. It is staggering, gradually zigzagging, towards a very damaging Brexit, a costly Brexit, a job-destroying Brexit, a rights-threatening Brexit, a Brexit that bears no resemblance whatsoever to what was promised by the leave campaign at the time of the referendum. In those circumstances, it is not surprising that more and more British citizens, especially those who voted leave, are saying ‘wait a minute, this is not what we were promised, this is not what we were told, and it’s damn well not what I voted for’. The Labour Party at its congress last week decided that it will vote against any such damaging withdrawal agreement on a Brexit deal. If that doesn’t bring down this government and cause a general election, then we will support other options, including the possibility of a new referendum, a referendum on the actual Brexit deal. People have a right to stand up for a proper democratic process. People have a right to say ‘this is not what we were told; this is not what we were promised’. The issue of Brexit in Britain is not settled, there is still a struggle going on to make sure we are not led over a cliff edge.  (Applause)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Time is pressing. Time is not just pressing on Brexit. I must say to the citizens: for all the proposals, for all the problems and challenges, proposals from the Commission and decisions of the European Parliament are on the table. We are just waiting for the Council to put an end to its blockade of negotiations and to develop a style that is based on solutions rather than blockades. Anyone who wants to make the European Union more effective, more democratic and more efficient must decide, instead of blocking the external border protection, the asylum agency, legal immigration. He must decide to live the old community of laws and values and to initiate the Article 7 procedure against Poland and Hungary. It must stick together and take On European responsibility, rather than leaving the citizens alone. It should support the Commission's proposals to eliminate unanimity and stand up for liberal democracy and thus for parliamentary democracy. That is what we expect from the next Council meeting. Open the door to the future and to implement the proposed solutions!

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as always, the Council promises moments of truth – these are Tusk's words – and strong decisions, but then lives on postponements. The most striking story is that of the Dublin reform, as Mrs Kyenge pointed out, it could already have been done and instead it is in danger of dying. In this way, the Council does not expose the lies of the Eurosceptics that we always hear in this House too, does not expose their deceptions against the people – as Mr Corbett said – the Council mainly covers its own contradictions, the contradictions of its members, dear Minister, and also double-bogus in order to protect itself. How can we call what is done differently if I do not duplicate what is being done, when we say, on the one hand, we ensure a policy of solidarity for immigration and then establish the voluntary basis.  Here my government has its enormous responsibilities, including in this chapter, as if to say, if it is not double-edged what its President Kurz and President-in-Office of the Council are doing at this stage, which on the one hand talks about solidarity and then does, strengthens national borders. The double game is to condemn Orban for violations of the rule of law and then accept his approach to national self-interest on immigration. Parliament is very alone, sometimes with the Commission, but it will continue with the knowledge that it is directly elected by the citizens of Europe to play its part.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Mr President, the European Commission has put a concrete project on the table. The strengthening of the European Union's external borders with 10 000 extra border guards and coastguards, and I think we can say that the European Parliament is ready to make this proposal up and running quickly, to give the green light quickly. We are counting on you, Madam President, to advance this proposal within the European Council of Ministers. Some in this house and beyond are not interested in a solution at all. They want to keep shouting that this is a continent without borders, that the back door is open and that it keeps selling nonsense. But you, Madam Minister, have an excellent opportunity to send a firm and clear and clear signal to Europeans, a clear signal that Europe is protecting its citizens and its people and is clearly worthy of the public's trust.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: "Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support While we're sitting here, somewhere out in the Mediterranean, people are tossing around in a crappy boat heading for Europe. People who have no idea that governments in Europe today are desithing over who can close their borders more effectively to refugees. While we are holding a plenary session here on, on the Greek island of Moria, nearly 8,000 people are waiting in horrific circumstances for some decision to be made on their case, on their lives. But nothing is happening and nothing is happening because the issue of refugees in Europe today has become the subject of political manipulation.  Commissioner Avramopoulos gave a great speech in New York and made clear the basic principles of European asylum policy. However, this is not worth much if the Council, the Prime Ministers, are not concerned with solving the problem, but are fearing for their own political future. Political and moral courage should finally be shown, not concessions made to the far right, because we will lose the Europe that we have all built together.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, the Austrian Presidency has launched its agenda under the motto ‘a Europe which protects’, but we fear that the understanding of a Europe which protects is being too limited. Starting with refugees and migration, it seems that most of all we need to protect ourselves from a kind of invasion coming from refugees. This is completely out of the reality. We need to ensure a proper way to rescue people drowning in the sea. We need to have a real European asylum system. We need to start discussing a legal corridor for migration in Europe and we need to have partnerships with the origin countries, which really helped these countries to provide a better life, for people to stay. This is the ambitious European policy we need to build up.  But then let me underline that if the motto is really ‘a Europe which protects’, the Austrian Presidency has a short time to deliver on key issues. The first one, I would say, is to protect fundamental rights and democracy, triggering Article 7 in the Polish and Hungarian case. Updating our law to protect us from cyber—manipulations. Then we have the need to protect people when it comes to social rights, delivering on the European pillar of social rights. Last but not least, we need to have the financial means and that’s why taxation, fair taxation, will be crucial to provide the means for us to sustain our welfare systems, our public services, but also the means to provide a community budget up to the level for the next years. Own resources are on the plate, and overall this is the short list of issues where the Austrian Presidency should be able to deliver until the end of the semester.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, we all believe in a strong and united Europe, a Europe that can meet the challenges. If Europe is to succeed, I believe that it must remain firm in positions, principles and values, whether on the issue of Brexit, on the issue of immigration or on the rule of law. The European Union, whether with Great Britain or without Great Britain, can move forward and be strong and strong again, as we have known it and as the 500 million citizens expect it to be. But the European Union cannot experiment and cannot discount its principles and values. And here is the opportunity: the European Union itself, the European Commission to clarify whether this strong Europe that we want defends and secures its external borders, defends and safeguards the sovereignty of the Member States. And I say this because again yesterday the President of Turkey made threats against Greece and Cyprus, threats to its energy reserves, threats to its sovereign rights.  Are you in a position, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, to proclaim and proclaim that Cyprus and Greece have nothing to fear and send a strong message to Turkey?

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the Salzburg Summit again, nothing happened, the usual securitarian obsession with border control with regard to those fleeing violence and hunger, nothing about Dublin or internal solidarity. Some people would even like to make agreements with Egypt, when we have been asking for truth for Giulio Regeni, a European citizen tortured and killed for 32 months and still no response from the Al-Sisi regime. You are thus selling off the fundamental rights that underseat our Union. Macron said in Salzburg that Dublin needs to be reformed before the European elections. You finally noticed. All you have to do is adopt the position expressed by a two-thirds majority of this Parliament which would oblige each Member State to play its part in the reception. If you let this reform end up in the drawer, you take responsibility for the rise of xenophobic nationalism and for not giving the citizens of Europe the common European answers they are asking for.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is surprising that the speech of one former minister at the national party conference of one of the dozens, or perhaps more political parties in Europe, causes such a stir – this is how you were touched by jeremy Hunt's comparison to the Soviet Union. I am against sharp comparisons, but I would like us to apply this standard in our House. Mr Verhofstadt, who is very disliked when someone does not want to listen to his speeches, but he is reluctant to listen to the criticism, because as we can see he is not here, compared it in this House, admittedly implicit, but compared Prime Minister Orbán to Goebbels when talking about burning books in front of parliament, and this did not provoke such a radical reaction.  I am very concerned to hear that here in our debate it was called the exercise of the rule of law with regard to illegal immigration xenophobia, an obsession. I think That President Timmermans, a well-known defender of the rule of law, should react decisively to this.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, the forthcoming summit will return to the refugee crisis with a progress report. We hope that there will be a real assessment of the crisis appeal, without complacency due to the reduced number of arrivals to the European Union. Because the tragic reality, the drownings of people in the Mediterranean, are not just numbers. The recent agreement of the leaders in Salzburg on the refugee issue is unfortunately moving in the wrong direction. Agreements with third countries will only succeed in increasing border controls, strengthening the logic of fortress Europe.  We insist that a strategy based on solidarity is needed. Abolish Dublin II, create a common fair asylum system and a permanent binding and fair system for the relocation of refugees. Member States need practical support. For example, ships with impoverished refugees, including children and pregnant women, are arriving in Cyprus all the time. The number of refugees may be small;

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the informal Salzburg Summit does not leave much room for a substantial change in the European Union's policy on the serious issue of immigration. The same arguments are repeated: that external borders must be protected, which is right; that people should not die, which is also right; but wrong tactics are being applied and therefore the problem cannot be solved.  Effective protection of external borders is only achieved if this protection is undertaken by the armed forces and the Security Corps of the States. It is not done by failed bureaucratic organisations such as the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, FRODEX, and corrupt NGOs. It is also not achieved when the European Union allows Turkey to send illegal migrants in waves and turn Greece into a vast camp of unhappy souls. Moreover, it is not achieved when we allow, as I said earlier, failed organisations to act as they do.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think Michel Barnier must have the most unenviable job in the world, especially if he was watching the debate here this morning. He has called for dedramatisation of the issues and it was the exact opposite we got. We had total drama. People playing to the gallery, people playing to their audiences back home without taking the issues seriously. I think Mr Juncker is right in terms of saying the Irish question first, because too much has been invested in the Good Friday Agreement. We have peace, we want that to continue and that has to be guaranteed. It has been guaranteed up until now and it will have to be into the future in the withdrawal agreement.  Statements like comparing the European Union to Soviet Russia are so wide of the mark and so disrespectful as to be risible and probably, maybe, best ignored. They are coming from people who have no interest really in trying to get an agreement. But an agreement we must get and we all have to work together to do so, and if we do so we can get it.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As far as migration is concerned, we know that the people fleeing to the EU are in an extremely vulnerable situation. However, they must be given the right to seek asylum throughout the EU. The situation we are living with now is untenable. More people need to share the responsibility. If we do not share responsibility, it will lead to a severe imbalance in the commitments otherwise of EU cooperation and break up all other cooperation. As far as Brexit is concerned, I just want to say that, as a Swedish Social Democrat, I am very sad denounced that the British are on their way out of the EU. We have had a lot in common from the Swedish side, from the Nordic side, with the British. We could have continued to do that and achieve fantastic results. Now you're disappearing, it's sad. Then there must not be a race to the bottom when it comes, for example, to workers' rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, I think the time has come to abolish Dublin III and replace it with a new system for examining asylum applications which completely abolishes the concept of the state of first entry. A system that maintains the national sovereignty of the Member States in the field of asylum. Mr Timmermans, the Dublin system has failed, as it has turned Greece and Italy into warehouses of souls.  The Aegean islands, and in particular Lesvos, are flooded with constant increased migratory flows, flooded by thousands of third-country nationals, who, although they wish to go to the hard core countries, are nevertheless trapped in Greece, in the impoverished Greece. Frontex, instead of protecting European borders, has become a tour operator. The guarding of Greece's borders must be entrusted to the Greek armed forces and the government must apply Article 72 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on grounds of internal security and suspend the Schengen Agreement, Dublin III and the provisions on asylum and immigration.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the growing spread of the rhetoric and concessions of the extreme right in the discourse and practice of the so-called traditional right and social democracy itself is well in sight in the debate on migration.  The concept of fortress Europe, openly assumed and defended, the explicit association between migration and security, the instrumental selective vision of migration with the management of the immigrant workforce made solely in function of the interests and needs of large capital, the support to concentration camps in the vicinity of the European Union, the convergence in the idea that danger comes from outside to hide that danger to workers and peoples is inside in action policy that one and the other carry out.  If we add to all this the profound disregard for the sovereignty rights of peoples and the policies of social retrogression there we have the broth of culture created for the rise of the extreme—right. Some of those who hypocritically warn of the snake's danger are the fastest carers of its eggs.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, of course, we are talking about what happened in Salzburg. I am interested in what you will do in the future, in the next Council, because a lot of things have been said here from all the political groups. Europe is in crisis. We cannot ignore the precedent created by Brexit. What do we do? Do you not think, the Commission, the Council, that you need to reset the working methodology? Do you not think that there is already the perception of European citizens in certain countries that there is discrimination, that democracy is defined differently, that there is no equal treatment? Behold, tomorrow we cannot speak at a debate about my country. This has never happened before. So, Commissioner Timmermans, last night, did not answer any of the questions. What democracy is that? What should we explain to the citizens of our country?  Dear Commission, esteemed Council, I believe that you must bring here not only words, but facts: how do you make the European Union project a project of the future. And I also believe that we need to have the same unit of measure and we need to take into account the sources by which we inform ourselves.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, according to the information we have all received, there are three issues that will monopolise the discussions at the forthcoming summit: the ongoing negotiations on Britain's exit from the Union, immigration and security.  A common feature of all three issues is the fact that union leaders are unable to find a solution. On the subject of Great Britain, the so-called negotiations have long degenerated into a series of blackmails, which do not, first of all, respect the will of the British, as expressed in the referendum. Moreover, the attitude of the negotiators representing the Union is more reminiscent of children fighting in the school yard than adults.  Immigration has traditionally remained a huge issue despite years of efforts to resolve it. I assure you that as long as you approach the issue in the light of your ideological complexes and refuse to face reality, the problem will not be solved.  Finally, as far as security is concerned, let us thank God that the caliphate is being defeated in Syria and no longer has the means to organise large-scale attacks, because the measures you have taken have had zero effect.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, Brexit is a negative development, but we can learn a very positive lesson. The main cause of the frustration of European citizens lies in the difference between the values of the European Union, which we all have in mind and know, and the policies that we often follow. And if it is something – and we are addressing the Commission – that will give meaning to freedom, security, justice and solidarity, so that European citizens in the run-up to the European elections also understand the role we are playing, that is: more democracy. I make it clear: there is no democracy and freedom, as long as Turkey is part of the European Union. There is no freedom and security, as long as we do not defend the European Union and borders, from small to large states. European citizens must be at the centre of the European Union!

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the debate and on that basis I would like to react to two issues: migration and Brexit. To start with migration, it should be obvious to all of us that we can only find a sustainable solution to the challenge of migration if it is a comprehensive solution. Yes, we are working hard to strengthen our external border protection, but those who believe that we will solve this issue just by strengthening the external borders are delusional. We can only solve this issue in a European way – and I believe by now every Member State understands that this cannot be done just individually by Member States – but we can only find a comprehensive and sustainable solution if it comprises all elements linked to migration. Not just a stronger protection of our external borders, but also agreements with countries of origin for the return of people who do not have the right to asylum, as well as forms of internal solidarity in the European Union and the revision of the Dublin Agreement.  Why? Because frankly it boils down to a very simple truth: either we find a solution internally for that challenge that effectively shows the understanding that we cannot leave countries alone simply because of reasons of geography, because they are closest to where the migration flows come from. Either we understand that, or we condemn ourselves to reintroduce internal borders in the European Union. It is as simple as that.  That is why the Commission strongly believes that we need to revise the Dublin Regulation, but we need to do it in a way that expresses the new realities, which were not known when Dublin came into being, and expresses the future reality that we will only solve this issue on the basis of European-wide solidarity. Just imagine what would have happened in 2015 and 2016 if all nations in Europe had said we just close our borders and we will not let in anyone. What would have happened to Greece and Italy if everybody had taken that attitude, as some nations have? It would have been a tragedy of incredible proportions, a human tragedy. So leaders at that time took their responsibility, sometimes at incredible political cost, but on the basis of the values I hope we continue to share.  Let me end on one issue about migration. Our sister continent, Africa, is at the core of the problem and will have to be at the core of the solution. No other parts of the world will have to take a greater responsibility for the future of Africa than Europe. Only if we understand that the future of Africa is the future of Europe, will we be able to solve the issue. In that sense, I honestly believe the challenge we are facing – To bridge the Mediterranean – is of the same magnitude as the challenge our grandparents faced to bridge the Rhine after the Second World War, and the challenge we faced when we were younger, to bridge the Elbe after the fall of the Berlin Wall. That is the magnitude of the challenge, and the sooner we wake up to that challenge, the sooner we will find a comprehensive solution to an issue, migration, that will not go away simply by refusing entry, simply by building walls, simply by protecting better our external borders.  On the issue of Brexit, the British people have voted, and that means that for now, we are all under the obligation to do as little harm as possible. That is in the interest of all Europeans, whether they are in the United Kingdom or on the continent. And I believe this means trying to find solutions for the problem we face. But let me be very clear: carving out parts of the four liberties is not going to bring a solution. Let me also be very clear. if somebody says ‘I want to leave your house but I’ll take the key, and I’ll come back in whenever I like, and take whatever I like from that house’, that doesn’t work. We have to make sure that we come to terms with the fact that the United Kingdom has expressed a wish to leave the European Union and that we negotiate in good faith to make this happen in a way that respects the integrity of the European Union, including its four freedoms, and respects the wish of the British people as it stands.  I want to make add two remarks. First of all, on the Good Friday Agreement.  How is it possible that people coming from the United Kingdom maintain that there is no link between the European Union and the Good Friday Agreement? The European Union is an integral part of the success of the Good Friday Agreement. It would not have been possible without the European Union. And you cannot just brush away that responsibility, which is a collective responsibility. The Good Friday Agreement was one of the most historic achievements of the United Kingdom, Ireland and the European Union, and we are all responsible for maintaining that legacy and for preventing the island of Ireland from going back to a past that I knew as a young man, and I hope I will never see again.  This Agreement was concluded 20 years ago, one month before I was elected to the Dutch parliament for the first time. And yes, Mr Farage, I was elected six times to a national parliament. I would like to see you try that in the United Kingdom at some stage – we’ll see. But again, the issue of Ireland – I want to stress what Jean-Claude Juncker said – is central to our responsibility to do as little harm as possible in these negotiations, and just to brush us aside in London is completely irresponsible; the Commission will never take the responsibility to do the same thing, and that is why Michel Barnier is doing what he is doing.  Finally, of course, at this stage emotions run high on all sides. I have some understanding for that, and you have to sort of forget some of the things that are being said with all these emotions. But, I represent a college of Commissioners, where more than one third of its Members have personal experience with dictatorship, with oppression and with dictatorial communist rule inspired by the Soviet Union. They have all fought to liberate themselves from this. One of my colleagues, Vytenis Andriukaitis, was born in Siberia. Why? Because his parents, Lithuanians, were deported by the Soviet regime to the Gulag. Vytenis did not know sunlight, what it meant. He did not know what the length of a day was. He had never seen an orange as a child. All these things that he has told me over the years show clearly what the Soviet Union was. And any comparison to the EU is not just misleading. It is insulting to what the Union is, to what we have become. (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honorable Members, thank you for your remarks and for your comments. I will convey them, of course, also to President Tusk. In our endeavours, whether on migration or on security, we should be clear that there is no silver bullet. We can only achieve results through a comprehensive approach and cooperation at the European level.  One of your main criticisms was on Dublin. You are for sure aware of the fact that mandatory allocation, which is at the heart of Parliament’s mandate, continues to be the main stumbling block in the negotiations in the Council and divides not only the Member States, but also the electorates which you represent. To make progress in finding a compromise, the Presidency, in particular Chancellor Kurz, has conducted bilateral talks with all Member States over the summer, in order to find a possible middle—ground. The issue was discussed at the informal meeting in Salzburg and we will have a discussion at the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 12 October. We aim to present the outcome of our efforts to Heads of State and Government at the European Council later this month. We are also working on the other files to find a solution to the whole package. For example, I would like to inform you about the Africa—Europe high—level forum on taking cooperation to the digital age, which will take place on 18 December in Vienna. Chancellor Kurz and the President of the Republic of Rwanda, Mr Kagame, will host this high level forum, which will bring together European and African Heads of State and Government, accompanied by relevant ministers and CEOs of highly innovative European and African companies to promote innovation and digitalisation as important enablers for our development and also for the future development of Africa.  There were also concerns with regard to Article 7 on Poland and Hungry. The Council is dealing with this issue, as it is on the agenda of the General Affairs Council on 16 October, as you might know.  Finally, when it comes to Brexit, there is still a high degree of uncertainty about the outcomes of the negotiations, but it is clear that the European Union will continue to strive for the best possible deal.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Before I close this debate, and while it is obviously the Chair’s duty to be impartial, the issues of Brexit and Ireland are sensitive to me and I welcome the comments made by Mr Timmermans. Perhaps I can close this debate with words from the grave of a famous Irish poet, Seamus Heaney, and make of them what you will: ‘All throwing shapes, every one of them, convinced he’s in the right. All of them glad to repeat themselves and their every last mistake, no matter what.’ (Applause) The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – One month after the informal summit in Salzburg there is no solidarity. While citizens want solutions to our problems, the European Council not only does not provide solutions, but accumulates failure after failure. Reform of the common asylum policy is a good example. It is unacceptable that heads of state and government do not unlock the reform of the asylum package after the European Parliament approved it by a majority. Migration is a global phenomenon and, if we want people to stop dying in the Mediterranean, the EU must act with humanity, dignity and credibility. On the other hand, the European Council also does not address problems at national level. When was the last time that social protection, workers' rights and child poverty were the main agenda items of a European Council? Unfortunately, the European Council is paralyzed by the continuing vetoes of the Member States. If there are no bridges for European solidarity to emerge, the current status quo is not feasible.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – The European Summit next month is crucial to the Brexit negotiations. These negotiations are not about 'the winner takes all'. What is important is that a social deal is finally struck. Because when both parties keep bluffing and go full on for the win, they will race blindly towards the precipice of March 29, 2018. Without a deal, one party will bear the brunt of this game, namely the people of the European Union. It's their future that's being squandered. A hard Brexit alone will cost every Dutch person an average of €300 a year, let alone the bill that the British get on their mat. That is why we need a trade treaty. A trade treaty that mutually guarantees social standards, respects European standards and values and protects all workers on the continent. In Salzburg a decent deal seemed further away than ever. I expect that at the forthcoming European Summit the Heads of Government will finally be danced out and will get to the point. Everyone's a winner with a social deal. Wake up all, it's not a game. It's about people and the real consequences of a bad deal for their lives.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. The mid-term review of the Austrian Presidency is modest. Instead of building bridges, they are torn down every week. "It was a mess" was the tenor of the international press after the summit in Salzburg. In his State of the Union address, President Juncker gave a clear mandate to the Austrian Presidency: to organise solidarity on the migration issue on a permanent basis. This means sensible solutions instead of incitement. We in the European Parliament have adopted our position on asylum reform. These are sustainable and realistic solutions: a common European asylum system, rapid procedures across Europe and legal entry routes. The second point is the motto of the Austrian Presidency: a Europe that protects! This means more than just fences and border protection. This means, above all, social protection! This is an area that the Presidency of the Council has completely neglected! The Austrian Presidency could make its contribution to a social Europe! But work-life balance or transparent and reliable working conditions – to name two of them – are absolutely not an issue! On the contrary – social policy developments in Austria also clearly show that social protection, the strengthening of workers' rights and also the fight against child poverty are not part of their work programme for the Austrian Government either in Austria or in the EU!

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. - Brexit is a tragedy. We see what a new form of populism brings. It is important to find status for Britons living in the EU, especially in the case of hard-Brexit. As far as Ireland is concerned, the EU will not accept an agreement that would set a physical border or disrupt the peace process. Europe must be a continent that helps people in need. Major shifts in migration policy are a positive impetus for the future. The Trans-Pacific Agreement is about building walls by the US, we want to build bridges – the same rules for all, e.g. for investment and security or for the joint definition of individual concepts. Investment in the EU is not always based on market principles, but also on the EU's want to guarantee free and fair trade.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – For the u u utym, the challenge ahead of this European Council is to take meaningful decisions guaranteeing the commitment of all Member States to a lasting and humane transformation of the Union's migration policy. I believe that there is no room for further procrastination this time, blocking Community decision-making without serious political discrediting of the EU, which would go hand in hand with an increase in the influence of anti-European, populist, nationalist forces in the EP election campaign and in shaping European political processes in general.  The basic conditions for this decision are now in place: migratory pressures have fallen below historic lows before 2015, largely as a result of previous EU measures, and the European Commission is finally making concrete proposals for effective joint protection of EU borders, strengthening Frontex and addressing crises in the Mediterranean.  The EP offers strong political support to the EiT for legislation on joint responsibility based on European solidarity, but member states' unity remains lacking. Europe's responsible leaders can no longer tolerate Orban and some of his other populist followers blocking decision-making on the reform of the common migration policy for their own power. The historical task of the current EiT is to thwart the 'the worse, the better' tactics of xenophobic nationalists, because the EU now faces more serious economic, social, sustainability and security challenges than migration, and that is what the EP election campaign should be about.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At first glance, the topics raised at the forthcoming European Council remain the same, but the content and details indicate some progress in each of the issues taken. At the informal leaders' meeting in September, the spheres of joint action that will increase the Union's internal security have been narrowed down and defined.  It is important that issues that have been raised for a long time during the European Parliament's deliberations, such as judicial cooperation and the exchange of experience on cybersecurity, are among the priorities of the common agenda of EU leaders. Especially in the face of the ongoing election campaigns in Europe, it is important that we share both technology and strategies to combat false content in the cyber sphere. We are also looking forward to further tangible results of pesco cooperation. The first group of approved projects was a positive step, but we need more commitment and ambition in the next call for security cooperation projects.  The issue where there is a lack of clear progress is the negotiations on the UK's exit from the EU. Both the negative tone of the Salzburg meeting and Prime Minister May's words that leaving the EU without any agreement is possible indicate that the situation is serious. For political and legal stability on both sides, it is necessary to lay down the conditions for exit. Otherwise, both sides drift toward the unknown.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The Austrian Presidency's motto is the Europe it protects. In order to give content to this mobilizing idea, it is important to take measures to make citizens feel more protected in the various plans, including access to social rights, employment, health, education, physical security and protection against new emerging environmental and digital risks. That's not what's been happening. The informal salzburg summit once again conveyed an image of disunity and inability to respond to the great challenges facing the European Union.  The European Council of 18 and 19 October is on the agenda of key issues such as migration, security and external relations. To live up to the momentum, the Council needs to move forward with concrete policies in areas such as reforming the Dublin agreement and advancing partnerships for humanistic control and management of migration. Important steps must also be taken to ensure that the forthcoming European elections will not be affected by digital mechanisms of instrumentalisation and manipulation.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, welcome to Strasbourg and to the plenary session of the European Parliament. I am particularly pleased with this visit, because you are the first Head of State of a Balkan country to speak before this Parliament. I am pleased to welcome you for the fourth time in just over a year, and the regularity of our meetings confirms a well-established reality: Montenegro is part of Europe, not only geographically but also because we share the cultural heritage, history and values that have forged our European identity. And as an Italian I cannot fail to recall how the history of Montenegro and that of Italy have intertwined several times. These meetings make it possible to anchor Montenegro and, more generally, the Balkans in the European Union. It is important to give your country a clear perspective. It must be said forcefully that your accession process to the Union is irreversible. Your leadership is essential in this process because it is a political path and not a bureaucratic one. You can count on my support and that of the European Parliament. We need to step up our cooperation to address security challenges and the threat of terrorism. It is our responsibility to work together, including to manage migratory flows. The Union must also be at your side in order to oppose, together with the influence of those who want to destabilise us. The agendas of extremists and fanatics, islamic radicalists, are contrary to our values. Your stability is our stability. We are also at your disposal to help you make the necessary reforms of administration and justice. They are valuable tools for consolidating a healthy business climate and for attracting even more European investment to your country. Now, Mr President, I would ask you to take the floor to speak to our Members of the European Parliament, to inform us of the situation in your country, but also to give us an image of what is happening in the Balkans. Mr President, you have the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of Montenegro. – (The following is a transcript of the interpretation of the original speech from Montenegrin into English) Mr President, esteemed MEPs, ladies and gentlemen, you have bestowed a great honour upon me by inviting me to address this highest house in European politics in my capacity as the President of Montenegro – one of the youngest and smallest European states. Thank you for giving me this opportunity to inform you of the achievements and plans for Montenegro, the country that is the frontrunner in the negotiating process with the EU, and the country that, since its independence referendum in 2006, has been approaching its strategic national goal in a determined, stable and dynamic way. That goal is full membership in contemporary Europe’s system of values.  I would also like to present our views on the future of the Western Balkans and the European Union. I would like to understand your invitation as yet another confirmation of the European Parliament’s commitment and support, not only to the EU prospects of Montenegro, but also to the EU accession of the region and the EU’s enlargement policy. So the question is: where is Montenegro today, 12 years on, as a country whose renewed independence was met by scepticism by many in the country and neighbourhood, but also in Europe and the world? I would like to draw your attention to two of our key achievements. We have strengthened our internal stability and ensured dynamic economic, institutional and democratic development. Internationally, we have been achieving – and over-achieving – our very ambitious goals. We have been a NATO member for a year and a half; we are a candidate country for EU membership, and there are only two remaining chapters to open. We are a responsible neighbour and an important contributor to regional stability and cooperation. And as a result of all of this, we are a destination for investments and an inspiration for many renowned foreign partners.  With the moral and political capital of an ex-Yugoslav republic that did not see a war on its territory in the 1990s, we are now developing a civic society of multi-ethnic and multi-religious harmony, without outstanding issues with our neighbours, which is confirmed by our border agreements with Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo, the first such agreement among ex-Yugoslav countries. Despite being one of the least developed ex-Yugoslav republics, our economy is the leading one in the Balkans today. Last year, we registered real growth in GDP of 4.7%, which is one of the highest rates in Europe. Throughout the period since the independence referendum, we have had average annual rate of real growth of the economy of over 3%, and the living standards of our population are now among the highest in the region. Twelve years ago, we were at 34% of the EU average, and last year it was 46%. All the other Balkan countries are below 40% and some, unfortunately, are even below 30%. From 2006 to the end of last year, our GDP grew nominally by 100%. Consequently, GDP per capita in current prices in 2017 was close to EUR 7 000, compared to close to EUR 3 500 in 2006. In August this year, the average rate was EUR 511, which is nominally around 80% higher than the previous year. The average wages in Montenegro are the highest in the region, but still, unfortunately, three times lower than the EU average. This is a consequence of the historical lagging behind of this part of Europe in terms of economic development. An important impetus to economic growth has been given by foreign direct investment in this period, with net inflows of over EUR six billion, or close to 18% of annual average GDP. We have also been registering very good results in tourism, which accounts for 20% of GDP. We have a population of over 600 000, and last year we had around two million tourists in hotel and private accommodation. Of course, we should recall that throughout a good part of this period, we had a devastating financial and economic crisis in Europe and the world, which has logically adversely affected our economy as well. Insufficient employment, especially of young people, is still the biggest challenge in terms of social development in Montenegro for the period to come. It is necessary to strengthen macroeconomic stability and improve our competitiveness internationally through further structural reforms. We have made a major step forward in the Euro-Atlantic Accession processes. Last year we became a fully-fledged member of NATO and, as such, we participated in the NATO Summit in Brussels and confirmed our readiness to contribute to the policies of the alliance as a responsible and credible ally. NATO membership for us is the greatest recognition of our enormous efforts in implementing comprehensive reforms and our contribution to regional and global stability through developing cooperation among partners.  Our NATO membership has produced positive effects, not only in terms of security and political stability, but also in other areas. We have more direct investments from NATO countries, and the share of tourists from NATO countries this year grew by 25%. Our NATO accession testifies to an important reform-based step forward for our entire society, economically and politically speaking, and of the results of the continuous efforts we are investing in building rule of law. As a candidate country, Montenegro has made much progress in the process of EU negotiations. In the six years of negotiations, we have opened 31 negotiating chapters and provisionally closed three. Montenegro has fulfilled all the opening benchmarks, in total 22 of them that were set for 13 areas, thus completing this demanding phase. We have also submitted 32 negotiating positions and we are preparing for Chapter VIII – Competition. We hope that the remaining two chapters will be opened in the near future. Apart from Competition, there is Chapter 27 – Environment. At the same time we are committed to fulfilling the closing benchmarks in all the areas in which these parameters have been defined.  One should not forget that the negotiating process with Montenegro started with the new approach in which Chapters 23 and 24 are opened at the beginning, and the whole process depends on the progress of these two chapters, which is the greatest challenge for the region. Already today, Montenegro behaves as a member of the European Union when it comes to the EU Common Foreign and Security Policy. We unequivocally adhere to the common EU positions, despite the frequent pressures we are subjected to because of this. Furthermore, Montenegro is continuously contributing to peace and security through the participation of the Army of Montenegro in NATO, EU and UN operations and missions.  When it comes to the issue of resolving the migrant crisis, Montenegro is in line with the principles of solidarity and humanity, expressing the wish to receive migrants from African countries within the limits of its capacities. That is an expression of our dedication to humanitarian goals forged in the time of wars in the former Yugoslavia, when refugees of all ethnic origins at times made up a fourth of our population.  Economic and social progress is directly linked to the results in the field of the rule of law. During the negotiations in this field, we have passed approximately 70 reform laws, strengthened the strategic framework and created institutions such as the Special Public Prosecutor’s Office and the Agency for the Prevention of Corruption. We have made progress in the fight against high-level corruption and organised crime. We know the importance of the rule of law for society as a whole, not only for the negotiations. We are working hard on fulfilling the provisional benchmarks, and we hope they will be recognised in the positive report and the closing benchmarks.  We are committed to enhancing justice, creating conditions for a full guarantee of the freedom of expression in the media, and cooperation with civil society; we are supported in this by the European Commission, the Council of Europe and the OSCE. We appreciate the financial, technical and any other form of assistance from the EU and its Member States. We also share our experiences with other candidate countries. We believe that the success of any Western Balkan country on the European path is the success of all, and we are convinced that the ‘regatta approach’, reconfirmed in the recent enlargement strategy, is a mechanism that represents a true incentive for the whole Western Balkans.  Integration of the countries of the region is a good strategy for the stability of the European continent. The enlargement process is important not only for the Balkans, but also for the stability and competitiveness of Europe. I underline this because it seems that the strong euro-enthusiasm, which was characteristic of Central and Eastern Europe and also of the Western Balkans, is losing momentum. There are two strong causes for this. It is the dissonant tones coming from different parts of Europe regarding the pace of the European enlargement, and also the unresolved problems and issues that have remained open in the regions since the Yugoslav crisis, such as the problems in the relations between Serbia and Kosovo, in Macedonia and in Bosnia and Herzegovina. These two causes are interdependent. The confusion and uncertainty in Europe feed the illusions of the proponents of regressive politics in our region, who still dream of reshuffling the region and seek support for these ideas from some important international actors. They are counting on the short memory of the international community. That is why sometimes one has the impression that the destructive tones are louder today than in the 1990s. That is why I believe that the European prospects of the region in the certain and foreseeable future – which were implicitly announced at the Sofia Summit and in the last speech of President Juncker – will be wind in the sails of the pro-European elites. Unfortunately, the results of the referendum in Macedonia are the best illustration of the problems I am referring to. Decades of neglecting the problem could not be overcome through the intensified Western support in the last few months. Also, the referendum was organised too soon and without enough preparation. Perhaps the domestic public should have been given more time to fully grasp the importance of such a decision.  However, one should not lose hope that, through a two-thirds majority vote in the parliament or through new elections, this outcome can be achieved. I hope that, in Brussels and in other capitals, this result will be understood as an alarm bell and a sign that it is necessary to take more decisive strategic policy steps. What remains is the hope that this will not reflect negatively on the dialogue between Serbia and Kosovo, which is already very complicated even without this. Additional efforts are necessary to ensure that the result is achieved, even more so when knowing that there is enthusiasm, both in Pristina and in Belgrade. The most important thing is that the dialogue has been established and that it lasts, regardless of occasional incidents and the political temperature that has been raised on both sides. I sincerely hope that all those involved in this process will take into account the traditionally fragile stability of the Western Balkans and strive for a solution that will be in favour of overcoming this historically burdensome gap between Belgrade and Pristina and, at the same time, not jeopardise broader regional security interests Unfortunately, there also remains the unresolved issue of the functioning of Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is a strong feeling of dissatisfaction with the results of political players – both domestic and international – in the 25 years of implementation of the Dayton Agreement.  Bosnia and Herzegovina will go to the polls soon, but regardless of the individual composition of the future three-member presidency, I do not expect either consensus to be reached or greater commitment of leading political structure and individuals to reforms that would take the country in the direction of adoption of the European system of values and integration. It will take a new, broader international action to achieve that goal, with emphasis on the constructive consensus of all keen neighbouring countries and the most relevant international community players, who have a special role in that part of the country. We understand very well the need of the EU to eliminate the causes of the crisis it is going through and to carry out the process of internal consolidation, but we do not think the answer to those problems is to stop or seriously slow down the missionary project of unifying Europe. On the contrary, I believe that full unification is the most important part of the answer to all problems that the EU is going through. Of course, we are not trying to overlook the numerous weaknesses in the EU’s architecture, but we do not want to fall into the despondency that suggests giving up on this vision. Therefore, I think it is necessary to consolidate the vision and fix the architecture. That is the road that will bring the best guarantees that Europe keeps its global competition. Everything else would lead to its weakening, and despite the differences in our views, primarily due to current differences in the level of development, it would lead to loss for all of us, the citizens of Europe. In addition, if the European Union misses another opportunity to integrate the Western Balkans, this would bring a big threat of political involvement of other countries, third countries, which do not share the same strategic goals as the European Union. This would hold our region back within the zone of conflict and would make the European continent insufficiently stable and disunited.  The process of enlargement and full unification of the EU is therefore an optimal path for Montenegro, for the region and for Europe as a whole. However, whether this will happen certainly does not decisively depend on us. We will do what we can do, with or without enlargement policy. Whether it moves quickly or slowly, we will pursue the Europeanisation of Montenegrin society with even greater commitment. Besides, we are already well-advanced on the track that resembles a one-way street. We simply cannot go in the opposite direction. Montenegro does not want to have any other option. When we speak critically of the European Union, it is because we believe that, as Europeans, we have the right to think and speak about a topic that is our common interest and responsibility, thus we also observe the deficiencies of European policy. We will certainly continue doing so in the future, because I believe that is how we contribute to the growth in support of the regional public for the European future of our states, not the stagnation or decline as is the case now.  We do not accept that we must speak of the EU uncritically, as if it were a new religion, but rather we see it as our joint home – the current one or the future one. In the worst case scenario, as the most important neighbour of all of us but without us being members. I am sometimes misunderstood myself, at home and in some European contexts, because of these statements that are tendentious or that are seen, due to lack of understanding, as euro-sceptical. This is not Euroscepticism. On the contrary, I consider the idea of a united Europe to be absolutely superior, and I see the European path for the development of the Balkans as a path without an alternative, but we expect everybody to accept that we in the Balkans are partners in the negotiation process with the European Union, and not an experimental laboratory of its administration. We in the region can complete this process of further unification with Europe much quicker and better if the vision is crystal clear and if the partnership is honest and in line with mutual respect. Everything that modern Montenegro has gone through is based on, and is fully in line with, the essential values that the European Union was founded on and continues to preserve, from preserving peace and multi-ethnic harmony in the 1990s, to the referendum on independence held in line with the highest European standards, and finally to the decisive and successful resistance to the brutal aggression in 2016, which aimed to take freedom away from Montenegro and divert it from the European and Euro-Atlantic path of development.  Therefore, we are right to emphasis Montenegro took a ground-breaking step forward after roaming the wastelands outside Europe, together with the region, throughout history. We have finally taken our ship of state into the direction of its natural European harbour, and we shall not give up on this intention of ours. The Western Balkans region is at a turning point too: it will complete its political and economic transition and join the club of European Union states, or it will continue to struggle with its interethnic and interreligious conflicts, complicated open issues, underdevelopment and low standard of living. Like a time bomb that can still jeopardise European security.  I believe I share the opinion of all of you when I say that all institutions and official authorities, as well as all individuals who are politically involved in any way at the national level or within the European framework, today have the responsibility to contemplate a better and safer future for a united Europe throughout the entire continent that is based on traditional values and embroidered with the spirit of the new times we live in.  It is very important that the forthcoming elections for the European Parliament are prepared and held in this positive atmosphere. The balance of power in Parliament will, to a great extent, define Europe’s path and determine the future of European nations. I want to believe that this path will be a joint path for us from the Western Balkans too. With this, I would like to thank you all once again. I want to assure you that you will always have a reliable partner in the small country of Montenegro, which sees the EU as a lighthouse we are getting closer to. (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, my dear Milo, as you can see, parliament's applause confirms our support for the work montenegro is doing to move closer to the European Union. We, as the Commission has repeatedly announced, hope that this path can be completed by 2025. Thank you again for attending this meeting, thank you for explaining the situation in Montenegro and the Balkans. Montenegro, I repeat, will always be able to count on the support of the European Parliament. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments pending voting time)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to inform you that today the Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled that the European Parliament has the power to exercise part of its budgetary prerogatives in Brussels rather than Strasbourg, in the event that this is dictated by imperative needs relating to the proper implementation of the budgetary procedure. As a result, we recognised that the European Parliament was authorised to adopt the Union's annual budget for 2017 in Brussels. On 10 September 2018, I imposed sanctions on Georges Bach, Guillaume Balas, José Bové, Edouard Martin, Claude Rolin, Maria Arena and Isabelle Thomas for the actions taken during the plenary session on 3 July 2018, which seriously disrupted parliament's work and caused the session to be interrupted.  On 11 September 2018, Maria Arena, Georges Bach, Guillaume Balas, Edouard Martin and Isabelle Thomas appealed against that decision. At yesterday's meeting the Bureau examined these appeals and confirmed the decisions on sanctions, which consist, in the case of George Bach, Guillaume Balas, Maria Arena and Isabelle Thomas, of the loss of entitlement to the residence allowance for a period of five days and, without prejudice to the exercise of the right to vote in plenary session. , suspending all the activities of Parliament and its bodies for a period of five consecutive days in which Parliament or any of its bodies, committees and delegations meet and, in the case of Edouard Martin, in the loss of entitlement to the residence allowance for a period of eight days and, without prejudice to the exercise of the right to vote in plenary session , suspending participation in all the activities of Parliament and its bodies for a period of eight consecutive days in which its bodies meet. These sanctions, having been suspended at the time when the appeals were lodged, are again beginning to apply from today.  Pursuant to Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure, on the basis of the conclusions of the Advisory Committee responsible for complaints of harassment concerning accredited parliamentary assistants and Members and having taken note of the written comments of the Member concerned, I have decided to impose a sanction on Giulia Moi for her conduct towards parliamentary assistants, which is described as psychological harassment. The penalty is the loss of entitlement to the residence allowance for a period of 12 days. The decision was notified to the Member concerned, who may lodge an internal appeal against that decision before the Bureau in accordance with Rule 167 of the Rules of Procedure. That action is suspensive in that action.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, my point of order is based on Articles 166 and 167 of the Regulation.  We have just heard a number of sanctions against our colleagues on the left. It will seem surprising that I am defending their rights. I consider it extremely important that before a Member is sanctioned, he is heard personally by the Speaker and that the same should be true in the exercise of internal remedies.  It is quite wrong, if not scandalous, that, in a Parliament such as ours, this right to be heard - which is provided for by the texts we have voted on, namely the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and the text on good European administration - in writing perhaps but also verbally - it is explicitly specified - and assisted by the person of his choice as...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Gollnisch, we have listened, we have understood. I must also inform you that all the people who have received sanctions have been heard by the President and the Bureau. Mr Forenza, please.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow this House will be discussing reception in the Mediterranean area. I would like to inform the House that in the meantime the crime of solidarity has been established and practised in Italy. The mayor of Riace was arrested this morning on charges of aiding immigration. I call on this House to show all its solidarity with a mayor who welcomes rather than rejects. To Mimmo Lucano all my solidarity.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am also referring to the sanctions raised by President Tajani. I cannot judge whether there have been any discussions. If that is assured, then that is the case for me. However, as the chairman of the S&D Group, I would like to make one thing clear: I know that the Members of my group in particular, who have been sanctioned for taking the side of the interpreters and for supporting or supporting actions that have failed to provide interpretation for a time, have not done so in order to undermine this institution. , but have done so in order to defend the right to strike, which is a European right. I would like to mention this so that the House can appreciate what it has been about.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Mr Bullmann.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Mr President, since this is me, in this case, but not only, because there are seven of us who have been sanctioned, I just wanted to inform this institution that I am honouring a disgraceful decision for the European Parliament. (Applause)

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted it to be added to the agenda, which tomorrow will be the fifth anniversary of the Lampedusa massacre, and for a moment of silence to be made to commemorate this anniversary too. I would like to take this opportunity to express my solidarity with the Mayor of Riace by supporting our colleague's proposal.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, under Rule 190(4), I ask Members to adjourn this vote as there has, so far as I can tell, been no impact assessment on the need for a hard border in the middle of Lake Lugano. The proposal extends the EU’s customs area but does not address the border, to police it.  We need to know if the Commission will apply its Northern Ireland approach and demand a hard border. Switzerland is, after all, neither in the customs union nor fully inside the single market.  (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Coburn, are you speaking on behalf of your political group? Does your political group agree?

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, my political group are generally in agreement with everything I say, sir.  (Laughter) (Applause)

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, with all the affection and friendship towards Mr Coburn, however, he clearly does not know what he is talking about. I therefore call for his bizarre proposal to be rejected.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, well sir, it seems there is one rule for Northern Ireland and one rule for Switzerland and Italy. How strange.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: However, excuse me, Mr Coburn, this is not a debate, we are voting here, you have made a proposal and the House has made a clear statement.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, I wanted to ask, as provided for in Rule 59(3) of the Rules of Procedure, to put to the vote the amendments tabled for the next dossier.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on: – the oral question to the Council on the EU’s input on a UN binding instrument on transnational corporations with respect to human rights, tabled by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (O—000078/2018 – B8—0404/2018); – the oral question to the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU’s input on a UN binding instrument on transnational corporations with respect to human rights, tabled by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (O—000074/2018 – B8—0402/2018); and – the oral question to the Commission on the EU’s input on a UN binding instrument on transnational corporations with respect to human rights tabled by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (O—000075/2018 – B8—0403/2018) (2018/2763(RSP)).

name: Mirja VEHKAPERÄ
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking today on behalf of the Committee on Development, which, together with the Committees on International Trade and Human Rights, has put an oral question to the Vice-President of the Commission, the Council and the Commission. The issue concerns the EU's involvement in the drafting of a UN instrument aimed at influencing the responsibility of multinationals for human rights.  The UN is currently carrying out an intergovernmental process to develop a global system within the framework of the International Human Rights Act to address business-related human rights violations. This is an important step forward. The EU must play an active role in the process.  The joint issue of the three committees is proof of Parliament's interest in the subject. It will help us to better understand the EU's current reservations about the ongoing UN negotiations. We are working with other European institutions to better understand their perspectives and concerns. We would also like to ask when and under what conditions we can expect a formal EU mandate to participate in the negotiations. What role does the EU intend to play next week when the next round of intergovernmental negotiations takes place in Geneva? I would like to remind you that the Committee on Development has also adopted a resolution on this subject, calling on the EU to take part in un-led negotiations. The aim is to reach an agreement that would hold multinationals that commit human rights violations to account. The resolution will be put to the vote here on Thursday. I look forward to the views of the other authors of the question.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. It is quite clear that we have more and more global value chains in international trade. 70% of international trade relates to global value chains. Of course, it is not possible to ensure that these global value chains run fairly with contracts with individual countries. We are increasingly in a situation where we have seen a violation of human rights and workers' rights in different countries around the world. That is why it is all the more important that we look at these global value chains and really make clear the responsibility of companies for these global value chains, be it smartphones or T-shirts. We have to get on with it. Global corporate responsibility must be the goal. By the way, ladies and gentlemen, we have, after all, introduced legislation in the field of conflict minerals that provides for binding care from the mine to the melting furnace to the product. And so, in many areas, it is necessary to enforce binding due diligence. That is why we also welcome the initiative of Ecuador and South Africa to enforce a binding code of due diligence within the framework of the United Nations. That is why we are also concerned, when there are votes from the Commission and the Council, that they want to withdraw from this discussion. No, the European Union must proactively influence this discussion and move it forward, so that we can ultimately take up this approach of the United Nations, which is already 40 years old, and enforce a clear duty of care for companies. Of course, there are also a few weaknesses in the approaches of Ecuador and South Africa, e.B. why only multilateral and multinational companies are taken into account. It is also possible to make proposals, i.e. to approach the matter proactively.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for human rights in the business world is a decisive issue for us, particularly as many companies operate in developing countries. Yet there is still a lack of a comprehensive approach to regulating respect for human rights in transnational societies. The United Nations in 2014, in a resolution of the Human Rights Council, specifically set up an intergovernmental working group, in order to create a legally binding instrument on transnational companies and, above all, to fill a gap between respect for human rights and commercial interests. Although the protection of human rights is one of the Main Objectives of the European Union in its external actions, in line with the Treaty on European Union, the European Union itself has been very reluctant with regard to the binding Treaty. It should be remembered that several Member States voted against the resolution on the creation of the working group in 2014. The European Union and the Member States must commit themselves to playing a key role in this process, maintaining a single clear position and a common negotiating mandate that are currently lacking. I would like to stress that, after many internal debates, we managed to put the resolution to the vote on Thursday with the European Parliament's position on this issue. Four years after the creation of the working group, I would like the Council, the EEAS and the Commission to somehow justify the absence of a negotiating mandate, allowing the European Union to participate effectively in the process. In view of the differences of opinion between the Member States on the need for an internationally binding instrument, we ask here today, Commissioner, what are the main issues that the Member States of the European Union consider problematic in this area, in a debate that must be very clear and transparent to all.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
