text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on the issue of the EU’s input into a possible international, legally—binding instrument on transnational corporations and other business enterprises with respect to human rights. I shall endeavour to give you briefly the broad EU view from the Council’s perspective, and afterwards the Commission will be in a position to elaborate on the topics concerned. I would first of all like to stress that advancing on business and human rights is an important priority of the EU’s human rights agenda, as set out in the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for the period 2015—2019, adopted by the Council on 20 July 2015. It should be noted that the recurrent element which is underpinning all our actions identified in the action plan is the United Nations Guiding Principles of 2011 as the first, and so far only authoritative global framework to address the impact of business on human rights. In its 2016 conclusions on business and human rights, the Council recalled the global consensus reached on the UN Guiding Principles adopted in 2011 and stressed that any possible further steps regarding the international legal framework for business and human rights at UN level must be inclusive, firmly rooted in the UN Guiding Principles, and address all types of companies, not only transnational. These three principles have always constituted our barometers for engagement in the intergovernmental working group process. President, honourable Members, I can reassure you that the Council, in particular through its Working Party on Human Rights, continues working on the business and human rights file, including on developing our common position on the process regarding a possible legally binding instrument. The EU is, at the same time, progressing on other tracks, notably the Working Group on Business and Human Rights and the Annual Forum on Business and Human Rights, specifically on efforts to achieve a coherent approach throughout the EU on access to remedy for victims of business-related human rights violations. The EU continues to offer its support to the accountability and remedy project led by the Office of the High Commissioner on Human Rights, recognising that the initiative may provide best practices that can be implemented at EU and Member State level, including on improved cooperation between states in cross-border cases. I’m looking forward to the debate and to hearing the Commission’s input.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to try to inform you of all aspects of this very challenging issue and to be constructive after the remarks on the Council side. The European Union is fully engaged in the ongoing discussions on Business and Human Rights. We are not only exploring possible future initiatives, we are also intensively working both internally and with partners to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. Already, 14 EU Member States have adopted a national action plan on business and human rights. Our policy is based on a mix of voluntary and regulatory measures that provide for tangible protection against human rights abuses. The EU is therefore not opposed, as a matter of principle, to discussing a potential legally binding instrument, and this is why we have engaged in the process led by Ecuador.  Nonetheless, we insist that the scope of the discussion should include all companies, not only transnationals or multinationals, as many human rights violations are committed by domestic companies. The draft text submitted by Ecuador last July contains important elements, including on access to remedy by victims of corporate abuse. Yet its scope is still too restrictive. Another prerequisite for the European Union is that the negotiations are based on the existing UN Guiding Principles. What is also clear at this moment is that the process is not yet fully ripe for negotiations. For the moment, the Human Rights Council is still divided on this issue. We nevertheless engaged in discussions in Geneva in the hope that process issues would be solved and a meaningful discussion possible.  What is, in our view, essential is a process that would be chaired in an impartial manner and that would be inclusive, transparent and predictable. We also ask that rules and established practice in Intergovernmental Working Groups are respected. We hope that we can count on the European Parliament to also signal the need for a better process. As the European Union, we have engaged in in—depth discussions with Member States, industry and NGOs on these very complex issues. We have done extensive work on the principles for EU engagement and on the possible format and points of substance of a possible legally binding instrument, and we stand ready to debrief the European Parliament at any stage of this process. We believe the added value of any possible legally binding instrument should be to ensure a level playing field for companies globally. Therefore, it is essential for a proposal to reach sufficient traction amongst UN member states. It is also important to ensure policy coherence and avoid the duplication of efforts. We are reflecting on which format of a legally binding instrument would stand better chances to achieve this level playing field.  These discussions are also a good opportunity to encourage others to upgrade their standards. The European Union can offer its experience on corporate due diligence in the field of human rights, including transparency requirements and public procurement rules. We need better prevention of abuses, and better access to remedy for victims when abuses occur.  The European Union has measures in place to ensure judicial and non-judicial access to remedy for victims, including access to justice and acknowledgement of victims’ rights, with a focus on provisions to clarify issues of jurisdiction, and to make international judicial cooperation and mutual legal assistance more effective. In addition, on access to remedy, the Commission is conducting a study aimed at collecting information on existing judicial and non-judicial mechanisms in the EU Member States concerning access to remedy for victims of business-related abuses. The results are expected by the end of next year, 2019.  To conclude, the European Union is committed to continuing a discussion with a view to finding feasible and sustainable solutions to the existing protection gaps, on a basis that ensures a true level playing field for all.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office, ladies and gentlemen, as the first article of the resolution which will be adopted by Parliament tomorrow says, the company plays an essential role in the process of economic globalisation through international trade in goods and services. As I have heard her colleague, Mrs Malmstrom, say many times many times today we cannot simply talk about imports and exports , and Mr Langen reminded us in his speech – but of increasingly complex production chains. Today, parts and components, raw materials from different countries, are assembled on a planetary production line. Moreover, Mr President, it is clear that businesses must be a key private sector ally in achieving the Millennium Goals and in helping developing countries. I, personally, have had the opportunity to witness many activities in the field of corporate social responsibility carried out by European companies. Moreover, in the field of human rights, in the recent agreements concluded by the European Union with countries such as Japan, Canada, Mexico, Vietnam and Singapore, or as we are negotiating with countries such as Australia, New Zealand or Chile, the fundamental element of these agreements is a democratic clause. And I understand, Mr President, that in this democratic clause and in this spirit public and private agents must act in the field of relations with other countries. Clearly, this does not mean that if, in a broader context, such as that of the United Nations, an activity is being negotiated in which the European Union can contribute its expertise, commitment and experience in the field of human rights, we must also participate. That is why, Commissioner, I am pleased to know that the Commission is involved and closely follows this negotiating process, but I believe that what is being raised in this debate is whether there is a formal mandate for the European Union to participate in this exercise, and obviously it has to be achieved through legally established procedures.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me be unequivocal on behalf of my group. We are not against voluntary guidelines and we are not against guiding principles, but we don’t think they are fit for purpose. We want binding instruments at the global level, because we have seen what happens to guiding principles, we have seen what has happened to the environment in Ecuador, we have seen what happens to workers in Bangladesh, we have seen how global companies still operate on the basis of corruption in many parts of the world, and we are not prepared to tolerate it. We want to ensure that we have a system in place at the global level where we can protect workers, the environment and consumers against the power of transnational corporations. It trips off the tongue easily, doesn’t it, when we say that Europe is a Europe of values. Well, if we’re a Europe of values in Geneva, we should be leading the way, not being dragged, as we were, slowly into this negotiation, but leading the way. I welcome where the Commission has now got itself to, but we should have been there before. I understand the problems we have with some of the Member States, but we should also acknowledge that some Member States are starting to unilaterally lead the way. The fact that France now has a corporate duty of vigilance law, the Netherlands has the Child Labour Due Diligence Law, and even the UK with its Modern Slavery Act, all show that countries are slowly coming round to the right way of thinking on this issue. As Bernd Lange rightly mentioned, at the EU level we are now in a position where we have the Conflict Minerals Regulation, which contains binding due diligence. This Parliament says that, even if nothing happens at the UN, we should be extending that to the garment sector to make sure we have due diligence in the whole garment chain.  I am pleased to say that we are also slowly making progress on our trade deals. The—EU Japan FTA includes, for the first time, a chapter on corporate governance. In relation to investment, while I have supported investment protection for industry, I equally think it’s time for us to ensure that investors meet their legitimate obligation to protect the folk that they meant to serve as institutions.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! I have looked at who has advocated the resolution of the Human Rights Council. These are countries such as China, Cuba, Russia, Vietnam. Who was against it? Austria, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Germany. So those who voted in favour do not have so much to do with human rights in their own countries, while the countries that voted against respect human rights. We must now also see what the practice of cross-border companies is. What are they doing? They offer higher wages, they have better working conditions, they have better health care and they have more social benefits than local businesses. Why is that? Not because they are so nice, the big companies, but because they deserve their workers to do well. Healthy and satisfied workers are more productive than dissatisfied workers. Next, you have to see there are spill-over effects. Cross-border companies have exemplary functions in many countries. This must not be allowed to fall under the table, as they affect others and then follow suit like others. And if I look at what is happening in the individual countries, when a large company in Germany is doing something that violates human rights – for example, supporting child labour – then, to a certain extent, this company is now often led to the slaughterhouse. That is not what you want in Germany! It would be good for the world if local companies were guided by the practices of cross-border companies. That is the reality! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. I would like to ask the colleague, in response to his very justified criticism of the Human Rights Council, to also look at the United States that has left. Does Mr Starbatty not also believe that we, as the EU, should withdraw our support now that things have become so crazy?

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have only spoken of the fact that I have noticed that those countries that do not respect human rights in their own countries voted in favour of this resolution, and that those who voted against the resolution respect human rights in their own countries. That is the crucial point, not whether the Americans do this or that.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President, the European Union is hammering home the fact that human rights must be respected. The work undertaken by the United Nations for four years now - it must still be remembered, Commissioner! - aim to put in place a binding instrument to regulate the activities of transnational corporations and all companies in general. I would like to greet the rapporteurs and my colleague, Lola Sanchez Caldentey, who insisted that today's debate should conclude with a vote on a resolution. The best way to help the United Nations move this debate forward is to support the obviously binding nature of these regulations. This is essential for the credibility of the European Union as a global player. In essence, ladies and gentlemen, the issue is primarily political. We need to be consistent with the models developed in the past. I recall that there has been a great deal of progress on the issue of conflict minerals, the regulations on wood and derivatives, the regulation on registration, assessment, authorisation of chemicals and restrictions on these substances. So, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is a normative power at the same time as it is an economic power. As such, it must position itself as a leader in the dissemination of best practices and in the development of global standards. The Commission and the Council do not have the right, Commissioner, Madam President, to avoid this debate, and that is why I would like you to clarify your position on the mandate. The absence of binding rules too often allows unacceptable human abuses... (the President interrupts the speaker)... I am a strong advocate of the market economy, but the market economy is not always spontaneously virtuous, I think it should be remembered.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, if a subsidiary of a Western company abroad is guilty of forced or child labour, where does that worker get it, where does that child get his right? Human rights violations committed in countries outside the Union or blindly permissible or simply ignored by European companies are often not prosecuted and certainly not in developing countries, where citizens struggle to achieve their rights or where governments cooperate with those companies because of economic benefits. The need for a globally binding treaty so that companies do not hide in another jurisdiction has been demonstrated so many times. It is therefore very good that the United Nations started a process in 2014 to obtain such a binding treaty. The fact that this draft text is now in place is nice, but a little more ambition is still allowed. Does this treaty really cover all human rights or not? And will crimes by state-owned enterprises and local businesses also be taken into account? And how are we actually going to enforce the treaty? What will the European Union do in Geneva? In the past, the European Commission was actually the brake on the negotiations. Does the European Commission finally have a mandate from the Council to start negotiations? I will be there in Geneva, with me more MEPs, and I hope to find the Council and the Commission on our side this time.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr. President, Chevron, ecuador; Shell, en Nigeria; Bhopal, in India... more than twenty thousand dead; Mango, Benetton, Primark and others, in Bangladesh.  They are just a few cases in which transnational corporations violate human rights and destroy the environment with total impunity.  Globalisation has entered developing countries as a sscorer and some Western companies do what they would never dare to do on European territory, things that we no longer allow to happen on European territory.  Why do we let some of our companies behave in that wild way, where we don't see them?  Moreover, it has so far been impossible to ensure that victims find access to justice and reparation to which they are entitled. That is why today we are facing a historic moment, because we have the opportunity for the Union to give decisive impetus to the binding treaty that has been being negotiated at the United Nations for four years now.  That is why I ask you to support the Resolution, already adopted in this Parliament's Committee on Development. Let us show the world that we are defenders of human rights and not quite the opposite. That's done by doing...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is unacceptable that in 2018 the international community should continue to see the systematic violation of human rights by certain multinational companies in developing countries. And even more serious is that the victims are not guaranteed any real means of judicial protection: human rights, the environment, the rights of indigenous peoples, the working conditions of men, women and children, all this constantly takes second place before God money. This complex issue and all its corollaries were addressed extensively in the report on corporate liability for serious human rights abuses in third countries, for which I was rapporteur and which was adopted by a very small majority in this House in 2016. Since then, however, the Commission, which has been repeatedly called for, has not followed up anything that Parliament has requested.  Now that the United Nations has promoted an international treaty on this subject, with a universal vocation, containing rules for corporate responsibility of a binding nature, we expect the Commission to follow up Parliament's repeated requests and actively support this initiative.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, yes, what are human rights still worth when we look at the United Nations Human Rights Council? Almost half of the members of that council violate human rights wherever they can, and that is clearly not a restriction on becoming or remaining a member. Members such as Congo, Saudi Arabia, Rwanda and Pakistan determine in their sanctions which countries would violate human rights and which countries behave properly. You can feel him coming, of course. Israel is the greatest human rights abuser and the best countries are Congo, where mass graves are still discovered every day, Saudi Arabia, where if you as a woman light up your burqa to sneeze, you are in prison for four years straight away, and I don't have to talk about Pakistan at all, of course. No, Mr President, the United Nations has turned the concept of human rights into a raw political instrument of power, and as a result it has lost all value. The EU is too cowardly to act against it and is therefore partly responsible for this degradation and therefore its victims. By leaving the Human Rights Council, the United States has opted for a pure interpretation of the concept rather than the corrupted infusion of the UN. The EU should follow suit.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today's debate concerns transnational corporations, business and the protection of human rights. As we know, the private sector is an important partner in achieving the SDGs and in mobilising additional resources for development cooperation, which is why private sector actors must adapt to the principles of development effectiveness and respect the principles of corporate responsibility.  Globalisation today affects all areas of life, including economic activity and the supply chain. Therefore, the role of corporations in ensuring respect for human rights is becoming more important and creates a situation where international standards and principles are crucial to avoid human rights violations in third countries. Unfortunately, there is still a lack of a holistic approach to corporate responsibility for violations of these rights, and victims face numerous obstacles to access to remedies, including judicial measures. Despite the European Parliament's support for the IGWG process and its request for engagement from the European Union, it has expressed concerns about the progress of the process so far and still appears to be threatened by obstacles preventing it from engaging in the negotiation process, resulting in a lack of negotiating mandate.  In the view of our political group, the Union and its Member States should join a new, potentially legally binding instrument if their demands are properly incorporated and its mandate should not go beyond what is legally established in the European Union.  As we know, there are countries that are not involved in this process. The effectiveness of the Treaty is conditional on the fact that the vast majority of states must ratify and respect it. The current form of the proposed resolution contradicts these demands on a number of points, which is why our group cannot support it and will table an alternative proposal. (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, there is no denying that globalisation and its extent have had positive effects. For example, they have taken hundreds of millions of people out of poverty. But it cannot be ignored that they have had many negative effects, including excessive power to transnational corporations. Some have behaved responsiblely, but many others, especially the larger ones, have not. They have frequently ignored labour rights, in some cases violated human rights, altered or destroyed the environment, or taken advantage of the weakness of the labour force, in some cases child labour. In order to frame the actions of these companies, a binding treaty affecting all companies has been negotiated at the United Nations, forcing them to act responsiblely and also allowing victims access to reparation. The problem we have is that the European Union is not a negotiating party within the United Nations and that Member States, in many cases, have not supported this process. Some who have supported it have not yet implemented national strategies. We need to become more involved as the European Union, and we are proposing that the Commission, the European External Action Service and the various committees involved in this Parliament work together to strengthen the European Union's position in the forthcoming negotiations on 15 October in Geneva. This matter deserves our backing. It is about defending the weakest when they are subjected to the power of the strongest.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, human rights violations by transnational companies are one of the biggest challenges of economic globalization. The search for cheaper labour and new markets often ends up where there is no adequate regulation to protect workers and consumers.  Raising awareness of the importance of ethical and socially responsible business is a process in which the Union, providing primarily strategic support to civil society, must engage more strongly. A binding UN instrument would be an acceptable solution if accepted and consistently applied by all global economic powers. But we know that's not realistic to expect. Without global implementation and an effective framework for monitoring and sanctions in case of violations, the instrument is meaningless and as such would only represent a noose around the neck of Western companies.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President, thank you, Commissioner, for being here.  The defence of human rights demands more than good words, it demands effectiveness. And when we talk about transnational corporations with centres in developing countries, we find that the instruments we have have not been complete and really effective.  We need to provide ourselves with legally binding tools. This has been established by the United Nations since 2014. As the place of origin of many transnational corporations, the European Union should have led the creation of these binding mechanisms.  But the Union still does not have a mandate to participate in the negotiating process, even though this House has approved it. This inaction, this disinterest is not acceptable from any point of view, and I know that some of this still sounds like interventionism, which seems uns liberal for politics to interfere in the field of private business.  But it is precisely the other way around: the liberal thing is to defend human rights around the world and it is not acceptable for our companies to do abroad what is forbidden to them here, which we would find intolerable here.  Economic globalization will be a beneficial process if accompanied by a globalization of rights and duties.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, it’s self-evident that the EU must take the lead in responsible business conduct globally but, in order to be able to do so, it must implement at home, and that’s why I need to emphasise the implementation at EU level of the universally agreed UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.  Where is our action? It’s much too late now. We have to undertake to establish binding due diligence for companies operating in Europe. We must make sure that the victims of European companies acting abroad will get access to justice, and this is work that is long overdue. So please Commission, please External Action Service, please let’s finally do that because that’s the only way we can be a global leader and take an active role in Geneva. There is no time to waste, because there’s nothing more compelling in the political world today than the requirement on responsible business conduct.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have already spent a lot of time in this House talking about protecting investors and their profits. Today, we are finally talking about the obligations that arise for companies. We can no longer accept business models that ignore human rights and environmental protection. Michael Frost, the UN Special Rapporteur on the State of Human Rights, deplores the further increase in intimidating violence and murders against people protesting violations by local companies. I therefore call on the Member States, the Commission and the High Representative to take an active part in the negotiations in Geneva in the UN Human Rights Council, to finally negotiate this treaty and to make it binding. Corporations must be able to be held liable if they commit violations of human rights. Nor must we allow loopholes for subcontractors and suppliers. The example of Chevron/Texaco against Ecuador shows to this day that only concrete, transparent and binding rules and treaties can guarantee these sustainable goals. I would like mr. Starbatty, who .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, as we all know, the EU is committed to using external trade as a weapon, a tool to further EU policy. But trade agreements are supposed to be about trade and to mutual advantage. Trade agreements are not there to signal virtue backed up by economic threats.  The recent agreement with Canada, took up to seven years to negotiate. It was dragged out by the EU’s attempt to impose conditions that had little or nothing to do with trade. And in passing, I have to say, fortunately, the topic of the Athabasca oil sands was glossed over, otherwise the EU would still be negotiating today, and we’d be into eight years of negotiations. In the meantime, profit and jobs would suffer.  It’s bad enough when the EU tries on this tactic with rich countries, but these tactics are especially damaging when used against poor countries, and we’ve seen this with Sri Lanka, a country that had suffered civil war followed by a tsunami. Nevertheless, Sri Lanka had its trade preferences removed, entirely for political reasons. Human rights is one thing, extraterritoriality and the politicisation of trade is quite another.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us remember that the European Union has obtained international legal personality through the Lisbon Treaty. It was, so to speak, by a coup d'etat opposing the vote of the French and Dutch peoples that this personality was granted to him. The European Union therefore has no place around the UN negotiating table.  Corporate social and environmental responsibility is an important issue of the United Nations. It may seem insufficient, but what can it replace? In fact, abuses, scandalous practices and crimes stem from the practice of globalisation without a free trade rule, without protection, to this intrinsic logic of the European Union, with its open single market treaties. We denounce the effects, we love the causes...  Moreover, these regulations would give you a right of interference that you would use to condemn our European states, our European companies, while you would accept the practices of China or Turkey.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – (2) Mr President, the creation of a Treaty which has legally linked multinational companies to respect for human rights is an old aspiration of world civil society that has been coming since the 1970s. This aspiration relates to the insufficiency of the rules adopted voluntarily by undertakings, on the one hand, and the difficulty of clearly determining the judicial scope of states in the case of undertakings operating in third countries, on the other. Globalisation has made this system more complex by weakening traditional borders and by promoting the geographical mobility of businesses. The potential negative effects of multinational activities are particularly worrying among the most vulnerable and unprotected communities, such as indigenous communities and peasants.  In 2014, the establishment of a UN intergovernmental working group to draft a binding treaty proposal led by Ecuador and South Africa gave new encouragement to this old aspiration. The activities of this group were, however, accompanied with great skepticism. The truth is that there was no commitment and enthusiasm from the countries of the European Union on the part of several actors. Nevertheless, this initiative is beginning to bear fruit with a first treaty proposal prepared by Ecuador.  The great challenge is that the Treaty covers the multiple situations of the potential negative impact of human rights that arise from business activity indirectly, through its branches, subsidiary companies and companies or contractors. It is in this dimension that the European Union must concentrate its efforts and contributions. We are convinced that this Treaty can take us to a new level with regard to the regulation of globalisation, and it could pave the way for responsible and sustainable globalisation, right away with guarantees of access to justice and reparation.  That is why the European Union, in fidelity to the values that inspire it, must aspire to play a decisive and even leading role here. To this end, we should call on all Member States to overcome their divisions in relation to this Treaty and to make a joint effort to approve it.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, respect for universal human rights is in Europe’s DNA and should be the foundation of everything we do, from trade to development cooperation, from the way we shelter refugees to the approach we take towards new technologies. European leadership, also in making sure EU—based companies respect human rights no matter where they do business, is important. We have many examples to illustrate that. The exports of digital surveillance systems to dictatorships, slavery in the garment and conflict minerals industry, and North Korean forced labourers working here in Europe. But too often accountability lacks and if that’s true for Europe, imagine the disregard for human rights in the rest of the world.  So while we need to do what we can and show leadership, it is an illusion to imagine Europe policing the rest of the world. Governments in third countries need to be brought on board with ambitious human rights agendas and their companies should take responsibility too. I’m very interested to hear more about what our European position towards the UN efforts on a binding instrument should look like, knowing that bringing any topic to the UN can also lead to a watering down or a hijacking of our well—intentioned high standards.  We must be mindful of what the end result could be, also with an eye on the level playing field and watching out that it is not other markets without regard for human rights that will be happy to take over our position.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: – Mr President, human rights are among the EU's core values. This is in Article 2 of the Treaty of the European Union. But in practice, human rights are still often violated, including by companies. It is therefore urgent that we conclude a treaty that forces companies to respect human rights, even if they operate across borders and thus escape national legislation. We have John Ruggie's guidelines, but they're not binding. That is why a global UN convention is needed. The European Commission does not seem to realise that it is not a party to this process. It's a UN treaty between countries. The best role that the Commission could play in this regard is to support the Member States and encourage them to speak out in favour of a binding treaty. I would also like to call on the Austrian Presidency to take its role very seriously.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a world so interconnected and ravaged by global inequalities, there are enormous challenges that we face at international level. That is why we call on the EU and the Member States to support the UN process in establishing a binding instrument for respect for human rights by transnational companies. Voluntary instruments are not enough, the activities of companies, especially in developing countries, can lead to serious violations of human rights, not to mention the possible negative effects on the environment, for which there is often no compensation for the populations affected. If we are to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, multinationals must also align themselves. Some of the multinationals that humiliate work are the same multinationals that oppose the ecological transition and that evade taxation by hundreds of billions of euros a year by stealing our future. Well, it is not just an industrial strategy, but an attempt to impose a model of society that crushes rights and people, which is why we must establish common standards and effective remedies that are accessible to all people who see their rights violated.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, today’s questions on the UN binding treaty come down to a very simple point: is the EU serious about responsible business conduct? By putting sustainable development at the core of the EU’s trade strategy in 2015, the Commission created high expectations, but what we’ve seen is the EU working actively for global rights for investors, but dragging its heels on binding human rights rules on multinationals.  Within this UN initiative lies an opportunity to deliver a real trade policy for all, but why wait for global rules? We could lead the field by introducing horizontal mandatory due diligence to clean up all of our global supply chains, guaranteeing that European consumers and businesses are not inadvertently supporting human rights violations here or elsewhere. Europe urgently needs a renewed mission to connect to voters. Let it be for decency. Let it be for rights for people and rules for business.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, four years after the creation of the UN Intergovernmental Working Group on Transnational Companies, a first draft of the text has been presented. Although the Commission is laying the foundations for an approach that is genuinely close to the victims of human rights violations and responding to the demands of the countries of the South, it still needs substantial work. I would like to stress that with this question we are not only looking for answers, but we want to stress how essential a Union contribution is in the development of this binding instrument. Every day, in our institutions, we work to combat violations of workers' rights, land grabbing, pollution and environmental damage, protection of community rights; we are working to reduce asymmetries, to combat corruption and all kinds of exploitation. We hope that the Union's daily efforts will be put at the service of the Intergovernmental Working Group through active participation in the work on the final text.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the prosperity of business has one limit: human dignity. Respect for human rights is a fundamental value and principle of the European Union. The right to life and physical integrity, access to the earth, decent work are fundamental elements that cannot be entrusted to voluntarism. Too many legal loopholes allow companies that violate these principles to go unpunished. And worse, too many victims, most of them women. They lose everything. That they cannot access e-justice or reparation for damages they deserve. We can't , experience proves it to us – keep it that way. The European Union has to lead this process. And that is why I ask you, I demand that the European Union have an urgent mandate to negotiate a binding international treaty on business and human rights. Let's stop looking the other way. Let's look at the victims. They need us. The European Union has to lead this process.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The starting point for this discussion is the frequent violations of human rights standards by transnational companies. The guiding principles for human rights and business are already a first step in the right direction. Nevertheless, I have serious concerns. The rules are neither binding nor enforceable. It must therefore be in all our interests to develop a binding instrument within the framework of the United Nations in order to involve as many states as possible. Only in this way can we refute the Conservatives' argument that European companies would suffer competitive disadvantages. Unfortunately, however, since the EU does not have a formal mandate to take an active part in the drafting process, I call on the Member States to finally adopt a single line and to work with great commitment and ambition for a binding instrument for the protection of human rights.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, despite increased awareness and understanding on this subject, human rights abuses linked to business are a problem which, unfortunately, remains relevant.  As highlighted in the resolution accompanying the oral question, the increasing internalization of business activities and supply chains reinforces the role played by companies in respecting human rights, while leading to a situation in which the establishment of international rules and cooperation has become necessary.  I strongly support the development of a binding international treaty on business and human rights and stress that we must continue to call on the European Union and Member States to participate constructively in this process and to ensure a coherent position on this subject at all levels, in all trade policies, relations and agreements. , while including rules on corporate responsibility for human rights violations in trade and investment agreements.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, putting in place binding rules that oblige companies to respect human rights is urgent. In many countries around the world transnational corporations take advantage of the soft legal framework that applies to their activities so as to favour their interests over human rights. This is also the direction of travel regarding Theresa May’s hard Brexit. The land rights of indigenous people in particular are continuously violated and our own European companies are among the worst when it comes to human rights records in foreign countries.  I am saddened to see how difficult it is to reconcile the business world and human rights. It’s urgent that we revise our business models and build a fairer and more inclusive paradigm, for instance through the development of social enterprises. Businesses should work for the common good, for the many and not for the interests of the few. I urge the European Union and the Member States to ensure the process for a binding treaty on business and human rights is kept alive, and to genuinely fight for the primacy of rights over private interests. Women, workers and indigenous peoples must be protected.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. I have a short announcement. When I chair the plenary, at least, I will not be giving space during the catch—the—eye procedure to anyone who has not been present for the debate. I think that colleagues know who I am talking about. I will make an exception today, but for me a debate is a debate and that means one has to be present. Catch—the—eye procedure

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I have always advocated transparency, so the direction of the debate, where this transparency is considered one of the most important elements, I consider important and valuable. On the other hand, I have always advocated equal opportunities to do business, including for those companies that we call transnational or transnational. On the other hand, I believe that some of the demands that have been made in this House unfortunately put this effort in the bin. First of all, unrealistic expectations – unrealistic legal expectations, including those relating to possible rights of appeal, rights to fight for workers' rights – are formulated as if their purpose were to throw those rightly formulated at the beginning of the demands in the bin. And that's what I'm paying attention to.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this oral question has been raised from the Parliamentary Committees on International Trade, Development and Foreign Affairs, but it could also have been raised perfectly from the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs because it affects a backbone of the European Union's external and comprehensive action — the commitment to fundamental rights — and is a requirement of the Commission's responsibility to obtain from the Council a negotiating mandate from the European Union European Union to fill the gap in international rules with which multinationals exploit defenceless people , particularly vulnerable children and women – in their commercial actions, whether in Uzbekistan, either in Bangladesh – as this European Parliament has shown – or anywhere in the globe.  The message is therefore clear: Commission, European Union, fundamental rights, human rights everywhere, also enforceable to the social responsibility of multinational companies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the issue of the violation of fundamental rights, and in particular labour rights, on the part of multinationals has been discussed several times in this Chamber.  We know that multinationals, applying the outsourcing logic in order to reduce labour costs and, above all, to make over-profits, transfer their funds to developing countries, where they do not comply with either labour legislation or legislation on workers' safety and hygiene. Many times, in fact, we have seen child labour and violation of labour rights. I believe that it is time for the European Union itself to stop pretending on this issue, because these waste products are imported from the developing world and multinationals are accumulating super-benefits, at a time when they are not even paying workers serious wages.  Concrete measures are therefore needed, and I think that is also the subject of our debate: the measures that our Parliament and the Commission must take.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his "So tired of just being good enough sometimes. You want some culture and sell your country. But culture includes us and our blood. Selling the country to mining companies, it's called genocide." These words come from the Sami activist Sofia Jannok, from Fall One, everyone falls. In my country, Sweden, the indigenous people, the Sami, are denied their human rights. It is a clear case where the interests of forest companies and mining companies take precedence over the rights of people and nature. So how are people and the environment affected? Forestry and mining are transforming the landscape, depleting biodiversity and making it more difficult for reindeer. The huge open cast mine of the mining industry affects land and water and creates huge amounts of hazardous waste. Sweden must ratify the ILO Convention 169 on the rights of indigenous peoples. It's time for justice!

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, we are discussing the rights of workers of multinational companies around the world. Because Parliament is showing a very positive attitude to defending these rights – which I applaud – and all the important things have been said, I would like to refer to some details that I think will complete the picture.  Apple, ladies and gentlemen, has 1,600,000 employees and therefore pays 2.6 % of its revenue. Employees are paid 1.5 euros per hour. Their monthly salary is equivalent to half the value of an iPhone: around EUR 600 for two, i.e. EUR 300 per month, which means, as I said earlier, EUR 1.5 per hour. They work 60 hours a week, six consecutive days and more than ten hours a day. Net income of $14 billion, according to 2010 data – I guess much more today – that Apple derives in just one quarter is equivalent to the 11-year salary of 300,000 employees.  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 5 July 2016, this House approved the report for which I was rapporteur and which had as its object human rights and corporate social responsibility. That text called for a binding feature of those clauses relating to human rights and called for greater commitment by the Commission in the United Nations, precisely in support of the Treaty. I can therefore only be firmly in favour of the resolution already adopted in the DEVE Committee and strongly demand, for my part too, that there be a greater commitment on the part of the Community and the Member States to a binding nature and a binding treaty on corporate social responsibility and the responsibility of multinationals. Finally, the glyphosate case, which, as you know, we have discussed a great deal and which we are discussing a great deal in the PEST Committee reminds us of how urgent it is.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, no one can deny the fact that large companies operating in third countries systematically violate the human rights of workers. But the solution will not be provided either by the creation of new agencies that will absorb additional funds or by the dubious value of legal aid, as often the judicial system of the countries in which these violations occur is perhaps more corrupt than the companies it is called upon to try.  Only two actions can answer this very important problem: in the long term, we must seek to normalise the functioning of these states, because – to put it in their own name – most of them are run by corrupt politicians who do not count their citizens at all, in other ways ensuring their vote, in those states of course which retain at least the face of a democracy and are not simple and clear dictatorships.  In a more immediate time, however, I propose a ban on the operation within the Union of companies that violate human rights, as well as a ban on other companies from any transaction with them. Only if we hit them financially will these companies be forced to change their practices.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, unfortunately, in modern times too, we see cases of human rights violations in the field of work as a sacrifice on the altar of profit. For the most part, supranational and multinational companies are guilty of these violations, exploiting their links to corrupt politicians, as well as the lax legal framework prevailing in the countries in which they operate. For this reason, we witness the transfer of the production of companies, especially ing, to countries with low labour, in order to reduce labour costs and earn more money. These companies often use young children at work and generally force workers to work long hours and under bad conditions. That is why the Member States, but also the European Union as a whole, must lay down strict rules so that they are applied immediately, and also do not allow the exploitation and sale of these products in their countries.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this very fruitful debate and for their contribution in this really challenging field. I would like to reply and make some remarks on some of the observations.  First of all, let me underline what I said in my opening remarks. The European Union is not opposed, as a matter of principle, to discussing a potential legally—binding instrument, and this is why we have engaged in the process led by Ecuador. The second point, also on your observations. We nonetheless insist that the scope of the discussions should include all companies, not only transnational or multinational, as many human rights violations are committed by domestic companies. Some of you raised this issue.  My third point is about the European Union’s position on this specific legally—binding instrument. The European Union is a staunch supporter of the United Nations in a rules-based global order and we expect all EU Member States to comply with these obligations and implement them strictly. Full implementation of these existing human rights obligations would help to respond to the numerous cases documented by civil society organisations and human rights defenders. We believe that any possible further steps regarding the international legal framework for business and human rights at UN level must be inclusive, firmly rooted in the UN guiding principles, and address all types of companies whether international or domestic, as I have already said.  In the world of today, it is only within a multilateral framework that we can ensure that all the victims of human rights abuses resulting from companies’ actions receive the same level of protection. The European Union has a strong track record in agreeing with and implementing the UN Guiding Principles. We need to acknowledge progress also by a number of European companies to implement these Principles, and expect others to follow. However, we should continue to explore options for filling the gaps in their implementation, for increasing respect of human rights by private operators and ensuring access to remedies both multilaterally and bilaterally. We should also see how we can best promote a global level playing field in line with international standards in this area.  Let me add that in the current challenging global context multilateral cooperation is more important than ever and it is essential that the European Union and the UN speak with one voice when it comes to upholding democratic values and the universality of human rights. This is the challenge.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Commissioner, thank you very much also for responding to concrete elements that have been raised by colleagues.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as already mentioned by the Commissioner, the European Union is not opposed to discussing a potentially legally binding international instrument on business and human rights. I think I am also repeating what you have already said when I say that any possible further steps regarding the international legal framework for business and human rights at UN level must be inclusive, firmly rooted in the UN guiding principles, and address – as you have already mentioned – all types of companies, transnational as well as domestic. Let me also reassure you that the EU will continue to cooperate with all stakeholders globally on initiatives to ensure implementation of the UN guiding principles on business and human rights, including through national action plans, and to promote accountability for human rights violations and the need for an effective remedy for all victims of human rights violations and abuses.  With regard to your question on the formal mandate for negotiations, the Council will take a formal decision on the opening of negotiations if, and when, it receives a relevant recommendation in accordance with Article 218.  To sum up, thank you for your fruitful statements. This has been a very useful debate, which demonstrates the high degree of convergence between the views of Parliament and of the Council on the importance of ensuring an effective level of protection for victims of human rights abuses resulting from companies’ actions, and of improving their access to effective remedies. This much—needed progress must, in the first instance, be achieved through clear commitments from all states to implement a duty to protect human rights and to abide by their existing international obligations. Thank you again for your fruitful statements and for your attention.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2)). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 4 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Corporations, being one of the main players in economic globalisation and international trade, are required to comply with all applicable laws and international treaties in force, including human rights.  Unfortunately, there is no comprehensive approach to corporate accountability for human rights violations, and victims of human rights violations involving multinational enterprises often face numerous obstacles to access to remedies, including judicial remedies. The involvement of the EU and the Member States, in collaboration with partners, is major for the implementation of the UN guiding principles on business activities and human rights.  Both the EU and its Member States must contribute actively and constructively to the rapid development of a legally binding international instrument regulating the activities of transnational corporations and other transnational enterprises, in order to prevent and remedy human rights violations and ensure the necessary remedies.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In view of the increasing globalisation and internationalisation of economic activities and supply chains, the role of businesses in respecting human rights is crucial and must be more noticeable and regulated by law.  International standards are of paramount importance in preventing human rights violations in third countries, but despite so many discussions and negotiations on this issue, a common approach to how transnational corporations comply with them has still not been developed.  I would like to express my support for the work of the UN Intergovernmental Working Group to develop a binding instrument governing respect for human rights in the activities of international companies. The efforts made so far are a major step towards protecting and promoting these rights.  Furthermore, I believe that negotiations on the future Treaty must be conducted in the most transparent way possible and include clear objectives and measurable indicators for the participation of the European Union in the next negotiating rounds. I call for the role of the European Parliament to be clarified so that the Union's contribution to the work of the intergovernmental working group is as real and constructive as possible.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU support to UNRWA, following the US withdrawal of financial support to UNRWA (2018/2852(RSP)).

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this plenary is taking place a few days after the High Representative co-chaired a ministerial meeting in New York on the UN Agency for Palestinian Refugees. At the meeting, which I also attended, the European Union reaffirmed once more its political and financial support. UNRWA is essential to peace in the Holy Land. It is serving millions of Palestine refugees and preserving the very possibility of a Palestinian state. The ministerial meeting was an opportunity to underline the importance of guaranteeing full financial support to UNRWA, and we managed to mobilise very significant resources that reduce the funding gap enormously. This means that Palestine will continue to be assisted by the UN Agency. The Commission proposed additional support to UNRWA of EUR 40 million. The EU and its Member States collectively provide almost half of UNRWA’s budget. We have all invested over EUR 1 billion in funding over the last three years. We are, and we will continue to be, strong, reliable, and critical supporters of the Agency. Supporting UNRWA is, above all, a humanitarian responsibility, but it is also in our collective interest for the sake of peace in the Middle East. First, millions of people, many of them extremely young, rely on UNRWA for essential services such as education, health services and food assistance. This is true in the West Bank and Gaza, but also in countries such as Jordan, Lebanon and Syria that host a large number of Palestinian refugees. Thanks to these funds, half a million children can go to school every day, millions of patients receive health care, and thousands of people have access to jobs. Second, UNRWA’s activities are particularly important for the people in Gaza who face a complex political and humanitarian situation. At last week’s ad hoc Liaison Committee meeting on Palestine in New York, we recalled that our priority must be to avoid another escalation and to restore a political horizon for the people of Gaza, but this will never be possible if we don’t also address the humanitarian situation right now and remain committed to assisting the most vulnerable people in Gaza. Finally, without UNRWA it would be even more difficult to reach a negotiated two-state solution. A just, fair, agreed and realistic solution for Palestine refugees is a final status issue that only the two parties can resolve through negotiations, with the support of the international community. Today, the Agency is reforming itself to be more effective, efficient and to have a perspective for the future. UNRWA has expanded its donor base and taken internal management measures to increase efficiency and reduce costs. Next year will be an even tougher year for UNRWA. In this context, we need to stress once more the crucial importance for UNRWA to intensify its efforts to put in place cost saving measures and reforms, including refocusing UNRWA’s activities on core services for the most vulnerable refugees. We are engaging with UNRWA to explore synergies with other potential service providers to safeguard key services to Palestinian refugees.  Precisely because we believe that UNRWA is essential, we want it to be more effective and efficient than it is today. We will do our utmost to ensure that UNRWA and its staff continue to operate until a just, fair, agreed and realistic solution to the plight of Palestinian refugees is finally reached. Without UNRWA and without the two—state perspective, there would just be chaos and violence for both the Israeli and the Palestinian people. We need a multilateral framework to support negotiations, we need a collective engagement to push for political progress and we need the region and the entire international community to continue to play their role. The European Union will double down on efforts to work with our partners – the US and other regional and international partners – towards our common goal of a negotiated two—state solution.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, in February we discussed this same issue in the Chamber after the Decision of the United States Government to freeze 65 million of its contribution to the United Nations Refugee Fund. On that occasion, Mr President, we express our concern. Concern that was shared with that expressed by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, recalling that this agency is not a Palestinian agency but a United Nations agency. On 31 August, the United States Government decided to definitively withdraw 368 million out of 1.2 billion. The next day, the spokesman for the European External Action Service of the European Union recalled with satisfaction the opening that same weekend of several schools in which more than five hundred thousand children from Palestine, Syria, Lebanon and Jordan will be educated. Today, the European Union is running with the main budgetary effort in basic needs, humanitarian aid and social development, and we are truly proud of that, and we congratulate the Commission. That is why, Mr President, we must regret this decision by the United States, which joins the long list of encounters with the European Union, but in this case it affects more than 5 500 000 people, men, women and children who we simply cannot abandon. Clearly, this does not mean that the greatest measures of financial control, budgetary control and accountability of these funds do not have to be required, but we understand, Mr President, that this withdrawal by the United States not to join this international effort on behalf of the Palestinian population is clearly not in the interest of the influence that this country has been exerting in the process of seeking a just and lasting solution for the conflict in Palestine. And so, Mr President, we hope that the United States, on the basis of strictly humanitarian reasons, will reconsider its decision.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all, I thank the Commissioner and also the high representative for the effort they are making to try to balance what is a very serious financial crisis of an organisation which deals, as the Commissioner has said, with the most vulnerable — children, sick people , of the elderly— and of educating young people and young women.  The Trump Administration's decision goes far beyond abandoning frail people, people who need help. The Trump Administration's decision rightly repeats that idea of growing hatred—hatred and disaffection.  Abandoning girls who are going to schools, who need, more than ever and more than anyone else, education as an instrument to survive, to be able to improve, to be able to withstand even the situation in which they live, to isolate them from the education system, would be practically like laying anti-personnel mines.  The decision is very serious, it is very profound and it is very political. It's not just financial. It is a decision that seeks to move forward on the path of making the two states impossible, making Palestinian youth increasingly abandoned, increasingly far removed from the values of solidarity and justice.  That is why, in addition to appealing to the financial effort — which I know the Commission is doing, which this Parliament has to do and also the Member States , I would like to call for the United States to return to the path of solidarity and peace-building.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, a strict comparison between the objectives and working methods of the two UN refugee organisations UNHCR and UNRWA exposes the great failure of UNRWA. UNRWA is not promoting, but blocking a solution to the Palestinian refugee problem, which has been going on for almost 70 years. It is precisely the American decision to stop funding UNRWA in its current form that offers the international community an excellent opportunity to drastically change the essential aid to Palestinian refugees in a responsible manner. And that requires new rational criteria for Palestinian refugees - no longer automatism - and now also places the exclusive responsibility for the integration of Palestinian refugees in the Palestinian territories with the Palestinian Authority itself. Replace UNRWA in Gaza with UNHCR. Look what happened - I have not heard a word from the Commissioner - what happened to the unrwa staff yesterday, fled to Israel. Give, Mr President, UNHCR also the mandate on Palestinian refugees in Lebanon and Syria. In order to keep an eye on the Two-State solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, yet standing EU policy, Brussels should support Washington in this wake-up call to the Palestinian leadership. The Commissioner was just talking about reforms of UNRWA. Insiders tell me how abuse is being taken here. Well-off Palestinian families are holding their hands and UNRWA should not be a job machine, right? Grow fairer workplaces instead of [unintelligible].

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, this debate is not so much about Israel and about Palestine. Maybe not so much about the United States. But it is about the decisions of one man, President Trump, his unilateral decisions and their negative consequences. First, and we all know that, there was the decision to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem. Then there was the decision to discontinue some of the financial assistance to UNRWA and finally to implement the overall cessation. Colleagues, if you as a state fund one-third of an organization and you decide to stop it unilaterally, then you don't, colleagues and Mr. De Belder, to encourage reform. That's bullshit. Then you do it because you want to shut down the organization. And when he took office – we all remember that – President Trump said, "I want to work on the ultimate deal." His actions, on the other hand, seem rather partisan. He recently expressed his support for a two-state solution, but how? The conclusions I draw from his actions is that by penalise one party he wants to get them back to the negotiating table. "Leverage," as you might hear him say. Now, if President Trump thinks that way he will go down in history as the person who is implementing a two-state solution, then he is completely wrong. Because UNRWA, ladies and gentlemen, and the Commissioner has said it, is fundamental to the future Palestinian state. It is in favour of the education of the children, for the food packages, for the health care of the Palestinian refugees. That is why, Commissioner, I am pleased that Europe is taking responsibility. That we closed a piece of the hole. But there are three things we need to keep doing. One, continue to show commitment to the Palestinian refugees. Two, unrwa guide in the necessary reforms. And three, of course, on speaking terms remain with the United States of America. They must help to achieve this two-state solution.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! Once again, my group thankes UNRWA for their amazing work. It will be disastrous for Palestinian refugees if this aid is not guaranteed. However, we need to see it together with the situation in occupied Palestine, which has now reached a new low. Read the press: Palestine is on fire, roads are flowing with blood. Just a few examples from the last days: on Friday, 7 Palestinians were killed in Gaza; On Sunday, there were several attacks by settlers against Palestinians in East Jerusalem; Yesterday, 93 Palestinians were wounded in Gaza, seven were killed, including a child; Yesterday there was the largest demonstration to date by Israeli Arabs against the Knesset's recently adopted Racist Nation State Law; Today there is a general strike everywhere in Palestine, also against the Law of the Nation State, but also in support of the village of Khan al-Amar, which Israel will smash despite protests from all over the world, including a strong resolution by this Parliament last month.  What is the EU's response? A worried mumble and a few extra euros. But we even have very close ties with Israel. We cannot simply blow israel's systematic violations of both international law and the EU's own laws, and the violations are getting worse. Commissioner, the European Union must now comply with its own legislation and demand that it be respected by those with whom we cooperate. We must do so for the Sake of the Palestinians, but we must also do so for the Sake of the European Union. When we flout our own laws, we undermine ourselves as the rule of law.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the US decision to suspend funding to UNRWA adds to a series of inflammatory actions by the Trump administration culminating in the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of the Israeli state. A deeper aim, of course, is to derail efforts to find a two-state solution and to cancel the right of Palestinian refugees to return to an independent state of their own.  Schools, hospitals, refugee settlements and health care programmes that relieve 5 million refugees are now under threat of collapse if the necessary funding for UNRWA is not found immediately, while in excluded Gaza 80% of the population is fully dependent on UNRWA support.  We call on the European Union and the Member States to take the initiative and mobilise additional funding for UNRWA so that it can continue its work smoothly. At the same time, the Union has a duty to put pressure on Israel to put an end to the settlement policy and to end the inhumane blockade of Gaza. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today there are over 5 million Palestinian refugees registered in the UNRWA area or in the Middle East. UNRWA was formed in 1949 following the exodus of Palestinians driven from their lands in order to provide their help. It has also contributed thanks to European support for the livelihoods of four generations of Palestinian refugees. There are certainly things that can be improved in the governance of UNRWA, but I strongly disagree with the trump administration's cut, which confirms itself as promoting a totally counterproductive political line to peace in the Middle East and the two-state solution, as demonstrated by the decision to move the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. The 300 million cut in the contribution will lead to disastrous practical consequences: school classes of 60 children, deprivation of livelihoods for thousands of families, loss of health care for Bedouin communities. And our Europe, a bulwark of universal respect for human rights, cannot bow its head and pretend nothing. Now more than ever, we need decisive, strong and courageous diplomatic action.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Israel's security is part of Germany's state, Angela Merkel has said. And Mr. Trump has not only recognized the capital, Jerusalem, but now he has also cut off the funds to UNRWA. Well done, Mister President! By way of comparison, the UNHCR, with 9,300 employees worldwide, takes care of all refugees except the Palestinians. UNRWA, with 30,000 employees, takes care of this. We are talking about 5.2 million so-called Palestinian refugees, with only 750 000 originally displaced. The rest inherited his status. This is a 200-page report by UN Watch, which is a 200-page document of anti-Semitism and glorification of Jewish murderers by UNRWA staff. But UNRWA is also promoting the right to return these so-called refugees. Eight million Kashmiris became refugees when India was founded, 12 million Germans were displaced after 1945, millions of Poles. Now let us imagine that we have allowed all these refugees and their descendants a right to return for decades. Fortunately, we did not do so, because otherwise we would not have solved the problem, but we would have perpetuated it. That is exactly what UNRWA is doing. It is a disgrace that the German Federal Government, of all people, has promised to take over a substantial part of the American share of UNRWA. We should join the United States in removing all funds.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, the devilishly good, according to Mr. Tsipras, American President Trump, by stopping funding the aid program to the Palestinians, is brutally seeking to force them to accept fait accompli under promoted imperialist arrangements in the Middle East and Cyprus, by transferring the American embassy to Jerusalem, by recognizing Jerusalem as israel's capital, by legitimizing the occupation , settlements, murderous Israeli apartheid policy.  The European Union and its governments are again hypocritically whispering a few words. They are not relieved of their enormous responsibilities. No sanctions. They continue to develop relations with Israel, to back it up, not to recognise the Palestinian state, despite the decisions of their parliaments, to recognise Israel as a gendarme of imperialism in the burning Middle East.  A classic example is the SYRIZA-ANEL government, which launches economic and military relations with Israel, with joint energy and military plans against the peoples of the region, with military bases it grants to NATO assassins. Their designs stumble upon the will of the Palestinians, imprinted on the face of Ahed Tamimi, the 17-year-old who was jailed for eight months for protecting her family's life when she attended the festival of the KNE, the youth of the Communist Party of Greece in Athens.  Condemnation by concrete measures of Israel, an end to occupation, settlements, freedom for Palestinian political prisoners, a Palestinian state on the border of '67 with East Jerusalem as its capital!

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which President Trump's decision to stop American payments to UNRWA joins a long list of such unilateral decisions, where large sections of the international community are shaking their heads or bewildered. We already know that this US administration is unfortunately not an honest broker between Israelis and Palestinians. But I do not think that this decision is in Israel's interest either. Or does anyone think that it would be to Israel's advantage if the young Palestinians were taught not in UN schools, but in Hamas schools? The only consolation I can see at the moment is that it seems that the international community, the other donors, met on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly last week on Thursday to fill the financial gap. It is alleged that this has reduced the current deficit from 446 million to 64 million. Of course, you have to look in detail at what unRWA's tasks have to do. Of course, such an organisation can also become more effective. But from now on to withdrawing substantial financial support does not help anyone. That is why I hope that, in the debates with the United States, we will perhaps be able to reach a different decision with the next administration at the latest.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It is important that we continue to support UNRWA, because the aid on the ground – many have already done so in detail – is really vital to life and survival. However, it is also important for ourselves and for our fellow citizens, who we represent, that we clearly show that we stand by our word, we stand by our commitment and our values, even if others suddenly see it differently. If we are not successful in the efforts to find a negotiated solution in the Middle East, then we should not and will not be outdone, at least in the field of humanitarian aid. That is why we would like to thank the Commission and also the Member States, who have reached into their pockets to make up for the sudden hole that the United States has ripped.  We should ask our partners in the United States to reconsider their decision. After all, international cooperation or cooperation in international bodies does not only work when some people are in charge and the others do what the big American brother wants. No, it happens that other majorities are formed in such international organisations. And you have to endure that, everyone has to endure that.  Secondly, the more money Germany – because I come from Germany – or the Commission has to put in, the longer it will take for this 2% target to be reached, because peace (the President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! The definition of insanity is to do the same thing over and over again and expect a different result, and that is what can be said that Europe's approach to the Israel-Palestine issue has been throughout.
