We continue to get stuck in the same groove, and it is worrying somewhere worrying to hear the great support there is for an organisation like UNRWA in this Chamber - an organisation that has been repeatedly taken for fraud, for corruption and for anti-Semitic messages in relation to their employees; A UN organisation which is almost of a state in the state, where there are so exorbitant numbers on the payroll that it is almost a completely faction of the Palestinian Authority. This can then be compared to the fact that, apparently, the only place in the world where refugee status can be inherited is Palestine. Moreover, the great political interest in this relatively limited geographical area in the Middle East also means that all debates on Israel and Palestine come to and deal with the same themes, the same old conflicts, instead of looking at the facts surrounding the organisation. This organisation has not earned continued Western support. That is why I think it is a good thing that President Trump has decided that Americans no longer want to support UNRWA. I hope that the Danish Government will also stop its support. And one might also hope that one day it would come to such a sense that the European Union will stop ours.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr. President, the suspension of U.S. funding to UNRWA is an indecent blackmail by Trump in favor of the Israeli far right. All United Nations reports are constant on extreme conditions in Palestine, but UNRWA does not replace Israel's obligations in occupied Palestine under the Fourth Geneva Convention, which holds it responsible for meeting all the needs of the Palestinians. Gaza will be inevitable by 2020, where Israel also prohibits access to all members of this Parliament. The democratic clause in Article 2 of the European Union-Israel Association Agreement obliges Israel to respect democratic principles and human rights, being an essential part of the agreement. So it is not enough to support UNRWA. Either we apply the democratic clause or we remove it from all our agreements. Because the European Union will pay for Trump's blackmail to a humanitarian disaster, but we are not facing a humanitarian disaster. This is a political problem. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much, my colleague. It's always nice how we're tinkering with Trump because he's cutting funds. Why did we not act when a refugee camp with Palestinians in Syria was cut down so far that hundreds of children were starved to death there? We were in charge of bringing in and should have provided the UN with funds. I think we always have to compare the same with the same. How would you do the same... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Javier NART
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Gericke, there is nothing unequal about determining that a country must comply with international legality and international legality is the Fourth Geneva Convention.  What it says about Syria I share, but a crime in Syria does not exempt from a crime in Israel.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago, together with other MEPs, I was in Lebanon and we had the opportunity to visit one of the Palestinian refugee camps, the one in Beirut in Shatila. I can assure you, it is a terrible site. Thousands of people living in very poor conditions packed into just 0.4 square kilometres. We had the opportunity to talk to mothers and fathers of the school children in the only school to be found in the neighbourhood. We also talked to the doctors running the healthcare centre. They all implored us to keep UNRWA alive. Without UNRWA support these people, who are the last of the last in Lebanon, would be totally abandoned and left homeless. Let’s not follow the argument of the Trump administration; UNRWA has no ideology other than human dignity and human rights and takes no sides in the conflict between Israel and Palestine. UNRWA just honours international commitments taken 70 years ago, and the European Union and its Members States cannot let UNRWA fall.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for 70 years NOW UNRWA has been giving life to Palestinian refugees. Ten days ago I visited Palestine and saw schools, hospitals and social services closing one after the other, refugee structures understaffed, the tragic consequences of the reduction in humanitarian aid. These are the immediate results of the US criminal decision, which supports Israel's crimes and the deportation of millions of Palestinians, depriving them of little help.  Ladies and gentlemen, education funding is perhaps the international community's minimum contribution to the regime of mass persecution experienced by Palestinian refugees; little counterweight to the extreme violence, pain and injustice caused by the occupation; little counterweight, ladies and gentlemen, so that survival is not their only dream, so that their future is not a hostage to Israeli politics.  The European Union, Commissioner, has a historic duty to make up for the economic vacuum of US withdrawal. Political will is needed, not just donor campaigns.

name: André ELISSEN
text: Mr President, we are talking today about the level of the European contribution to the Palestinians. Now that the United States has rightly decided to put aid on the back burner, the so-called refugees must look for a new sugar daddy, and the European Union is eager to continue to play that role. UNRWA has a budget of more than EUR 1 billion per year. There are plenty of stories about hiring Islamic terrorists, funnelling European funds into the pockets of corrupt Palestinian leaders and expressions of extreme Jew hatred. And what is the European Commission doing? He is fine with it all and continues to distribute many hundreds of millions of euros a year. Unsellable and unacceptable. Unfortunately, my own country, the Netherlands, faithfully transfers many tens of millions of euros annually. Money that we can spend much better in our own country. Mr President, it is clear. As far as we are concerned, every euro to the Palestinians is one euro too many. Stop funding hatred towards Israel, stop perpetuating a so-called refugee problem, and stop any kind of support for the Palestinians.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, the Middle East in general and, in particular, the Palestinian question require dialogue and agreements, not unilateral acts. The situation created by the abolition of US aid to UNRWA inevitably requires an increase in the contribution of the European Union and its Member States. We have no other solution. I welcome the position expressed to us by the Commissioner. Food, health, basic education and infrastructure services cannot be neglected. The southern Mediterranean is our neighborhood. What happens there immediately affects Europe. We've seen it with the Syrian conflict. We see it, too, with the situation in Libya. Destabilization in the Mediterranean affects us directly. In addition to the Member States, I hope that other countries, such as resourced Arab countries, will also increase their contribution to UNRWA, which suffers from a chronic deficit, which is now aggravated. I am concerned that these kinds of Washington decisions can be used to increase radicalization among Palestinian refugees. I am also concerned that with these and other similar decisions the United States will continue on a line of self-margination in a region where until recently they were the key player. In the end, Russia and Iran could increase their role in an area where U.S. influence continues to decline. The European Union, in addition to increasing its contribution to UNRWA, must seek to intensify dialogue with Washington and make it see the risks of these unilateral acts in such a volatile and at the same time important region for Europe and the West.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: – Mr President, in the Committee on Budgets on these dates we always talk about the financing of UNRWA, or rather the underfunding of the agency, because every year we receive its financial reports and see the economic hardships they face.  The problem with numbers is that they are very cold and hardly put eyes and face on them, and for that, it is better to go on the ground. So in this mandate we have traveled to Palestine, Lebanon and Jordan to see it right there, and there you can see their eyes and faces.  And there you realize that the budget negotiation, which cost us so much, had an indisputable purpose: that refugees and especially children who are victims of wars and senseless political disputes have their most basic needs met: a roof, food, education and health care.  And that, something as humanitarian as that, is what Trump just denied. And the truth is, you can't be more miserable.  And if Trump has no heart, Europe must show that he does and not only with words, but with his budgets, and do so without cracks, without rebates and without miseries.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I believe all of us can agree that we cannot fund an entity without scrutinising it thoroughly. We have obtained well-founded reports that UNRWA has been funding school textbooks full of incitement and full of hate, and even EU money is funding these school textbooks. They should meet the UN standards of education and promote peace. Regretfully, we have seen alarming changes in the Palestinian curricula, which are turning in the wrong direction. Moreover, in your answer to the written question of the group of MEPs, Commissioner Hahn, you admitted that for the current result—oriented framework there are no specific targets linked to the curriculum reform process. Humanitarian efforts have become harmful to any kind of peace in the area. We need to make sure the UNRWA meets basic conditions in order that further EU funding can be justified. The US cut has made the EU the only major donor of the UNRWA. This fact will make the EU more accountable for the outcomes.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Mr President, the decision of the United States to withdraw from UNRWA funding is a new fact and a political fact. Palestinian refugees have rights under international conventions: it is about guaranteeing them, but not at any cost. Their fate will only really improve when a final two-state solution is imposed between Israelis and Palestinians. In this context, these refugees could even be entitled to return. But we must not be naïve. The European Union as a perpetual funder is far from our view; this issue must remain, in our view, the essential responsibility of the United Nations. Let us not forget that these camps are infested with propaganda and Islamist groups, especially in Lebanon, where the army has recently made arrests. Also, the utmost vigilance is required. Before opening the funding floodgates, I call on European leaders to seriously consider the destinations for possible additional funds and, of course, to finance other priorities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I consider the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to be one of the most pressing disputes in modern history. Here in the European Parliament a few years ago, the Israeli President declared that European reconciliation is an inspiration to Israel and the Palestinians.  I believe that there will one day be peace, and that there will be reconciliation. These countries need the help of other actors to do this, and one of them is UNRWA, which has an irreplaceable place in resolving this conflict, especially in terms of humanitarian aid.  The United States has decided to end funding on grounds of inefficiency, and I ask the European Commission to check very carefully, strongly, what purposes it is used for in the event of an increase in the contribution. I agree with my colleague Škripek that it is unacceptable that these funds should be used for unilateral propaganda.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the UNRWA spokesperson said that the choice of the US administration will have a devastating impact on the lives of five hundred thousand children receiving an education from the agency, three and a half million sick people going to its medical facilities and one million and seven hundred thousand people in food insecurity and tens of thousands of women, children and disabled refugees. Over the past seventy years, this agency has provided essential aid to more than 5 million Palestinian refugees. Trump's decision represents a serious u-turn against the Oslo paradigm, which is also supported by the European Union. The agency is not only indispensable for Palestinian refugees, but also represents the fate of the two-state solution. Supporting and contributing to its financing means working for the stability of the Middle East, which is also crucial for the future of Europe.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, as rapporteur for humanitarian aid in this Parliament, I have visited refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and also Palestine. Refugee camps on land occupied by another country. In all of them I have seen the meritorial work carried out by UNRWA, which is dealing with a crisis that is already going on for more than seven decades and which has no vision of a solution in the immediate future. Someone has pointed out that we are facing a political and humanitarian crisis, but it is worse. We are facing the use of a humanitarian crisis to obtain political gain. That's what the United States has done: cutting off support for people in need to impose their policy in the Middle East, and that is unbearable from a humanitarian perspective.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I have twice as many requests to speak as we have set aside for the procedure for spontaneous speeches that follows. I shall therefore allow a colleague to speak from each Fratkion, taking into account who has spoken in the spontaneous speech procedure. Spontaneous speeches

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, the $300 million cut in US funding to the UN refugee assistance agency in Palestine is regrettable and represents a financial blow to primary health care, educational services and emergency aid to the more than 4 million Palestinian refugees living in the Gaza Strip , in the West Bank, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon.  The arguments put forward by Washington on the weight of the financial burden of U.S. contributions to this $1.1 billion U.N. agency in 2017 are intended to camouflage what constituted a politicization of humanitarian aid and are also shocking by the dual criteria of a country that, in the same year, allocated nearly $4 billion for military aid to Israel. For all this, I would like to congratulate High Representative Mogherini, both for the announcement of the strengthening of the Union's financial contribution to this agency and for the continued political support for the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict essential to security in the Middle East and peace in the world.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I very much welcome the Commission's proposal to guarantee EUR 40 million more in EU aid to UNWRA. In particular, supporting the education of children and young people among Palestinian refugees is important in order to ensure normality, stability and peace in the region. This was also postulated by the Israeli military. Back in February, I negotiated a European Parliament resolution in which it spoke out in a non-partisan way against the US UNWRA cuts and in favour of increased EU financial support for the UN Refugee Agency. Humanitarian aid must not be misused for political demands. I continue to call for the EU not to give up, together with other Member States, to address other nations of the world in order to close this financial gap. Germany has already pledged to increase its contributions from 81 million euros to 100 million euros this year. I welcome the fact that Germany is clearly behind UNWRA here, both politically and financially.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestinians in the Middle East has been doing an important job over the last 70 years. It operates in Lebanon, Syria, the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and has certainly provided important services. It supports vulnerable people, supports education, education and it is certain that the reduction in its funding and the problems in its operation will affect, as has been said, at least 500,000 pupils and 400,000 sick people.  This does not mean, of course, that there should be no control, transparency and accountability in the operation of UNRWA, but these cannot be the reason for stopping it. I think the European Union is right to support the functioning of UNRWA. And it would be good if the Arab countries, which finance billions of euros of football teams in the English and French leagues, put their hands in their pockets and strengthen UNRWA.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to expressly congratulate Vice-President Mogherini on the role played by the European Union in the process of expanding the donor base and the contributions of the essential activity of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East.  The new funds secured are the best response to President Trump's irresponsible conduct. The unilateral decisions he has taken in the area, justifying decisions such as blocking most of the funds with which the United States contributed to financing this agency, are a weapon of mass destruction of the delicate balances and values that seek to build peace and stability, of the tools that enable the international community to be fulfilled to assist Palestinian refugees.  I welcome the European Union's responding to this devoidness, short-sighted, unconscious and populist short-termism that characterizes the American president, with speed, efficiency and leadership.  Europe, the best. Trump, not America or the United States, the worst.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, the UN agency for assistance to Palestinian refugees suffers the most dramatic crisis in history. It's a dramatic and cruel situation. Cuts in schools, hospitals and emergency food care have very serious symbolic political and material implications. It means that they will not have access to basic services, but politically, as the Commissioner said, it also means advancing the idea that these people should assimilate and forget the right to return, it means removing refugee status at five million, it is a political decision. In Gaza it's much worse. There 8 % of the inhabitants depend on humanitarian aid. There's a lack of water, electricity, services. It was already difficult to live in Gaza with the occupation. If you cut the funds, it's even worse. We denounce the inability of the international community and complicity with Trump and that Europe is no longer complicit because it does not help for peace.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: " Mr. President, President Trump's decision not to fund UNRWA is not only a cruel measure for those who were driven from their legitimate lands, but is a political torpedo against the international concert. It is to move from unmimbled support for the illegal occupation of Palestine to openly assuming the racist project of more extremist Zionism, which seeks the disappearance of Palestinians. The European Union must financially support UNRWA so that it does not collapse, but what is necessary is that the reasons why this agency was set up are over. Firmness is needed with Israel, the occupying and disrespectful power of international law. That firmness that the European Union employs with other small countries. Palestine must be recognized as a state and its viability must be called for and demanded with United Nations resolutions, a state bordering 67, with East Jerusalem as the capital, and the return of refugees.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today a million Palestinian refugees in the Gaza Strip are in danger of being left without food or water. Three and a half million people who are probably denied primary health care. This is the shame that is happening, ladies and gentlemen, just a few hours' flight from us, despite the human rights clause included in our agreement with Israel, the occupying power. And since the United States cut UNRWA's funding, as many as 364 million became 64 million in January 2018 and totally suspended since last August, the tragedy is even more serious. As the Eu ropean Union, we have helped to plug the loophole with EUR 40 million, but the agency is still in deficit by a further EUR 64 million and is in danger of not being able to complete the activities planned for this year. We cannot give in to this blackmail. We need a further collective effort on the part of international donors, but above all we need to give a lifeline for those Palestinian refugees who do not want to give up their dreams, who do not want to give up their future.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, it is an inalienable right of States to choose freely, on the basis of their own internal democratic procedures, how to spend their resources and how to shape their external relations. And these final decisions deserve respect and acceptance from all sides.  By going beyond its mandate and acting independently as an international arbiter, the Union projects human rights, democracy and the rule of law selectively, as leverage, serving geostrategic interests of specific countries, without insight or long-term planning.  Its actions, by not respecting the principle of non-interference in internal matters and the sovereign decisions of third independent States, demonstrate once again the inability to understand and expose its absence from international geostrategic balances. On the contrary, it continues to be attracted by developments, further neglecting its main reason for existence, which is the steady improvement of the living conditions of its citizens. Among other things, who asked the Union to replace the UN?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very fruitful exchange and I would like to thank honourable Members for their interventions. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in using the EU’s diplomatic power and EU instruments to their full potential in support of ensuring the sustainability of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) core services to vulnerable Palestinian refugees.  We will continue to look at how best to use all the instruments available to us in humanitarian relief, stabilisation and development assistance, and political dialogue but please allow me to make some clarifications due to one or other comments or statements by honourable Members.  First, UNRWA is not something which founded itself, nor is it an NGO. It was founded based on a UN General Assembly Decision from 8 December 1949 as a reaction to the Palestinian refugee disaster in the late 1940s. Its mandate is renewed every three years. So the whole construction is based on a UN General Assembly Decision, meaning a multilateral agreement.  There is, by the way, a clear mandate, a clear task and in that respect UNRWA is different from the tasks of UNHCR. UNRWA deals with providing necessary support, in particular of education and health treatment, and other things but in particular these two areas, for refugees, definitely in a medium-and long-term perspective as this has been continuing now for many decades, whereas UNHCR is dedicated to supporting, to helping the short-term challenge of certain refugee situations all around the world.  This was, by the way, clearly presented by the current UN Secretary-General, Mr Guterres, last week in New York, at this event I already mentioned in my introduction, and Mr Guterres is very well placed to speak about this because before he became Secretary General of the UN, he was for 10 years High Commissioner for Refugees and chairing UNHCR.  Having said all this, I think we should say what is happening. The US is breaching international agreements – international agreements – and, by the way, bilateral contracts between UNRWA and the US about the funding of UNRWA. Only in December last year, the administration signed a contract with UNRWA about further financing and only a few weeks later they decided to cut or to stop immediately payments to UNRWA. This is a decision which again does not respect multilateral agreements and contracts.  Finally, as was also said by some colleagues, some Members of this Parliament, on the textbook issue, here once again a clarification. Our support to UNRWA is the payment of salaries and pensions for teachers in the West Bank. We are already working to tackle the deficiencies in the Palestinian Authority (PA) education system with an EU-PA dialogue linked to EU financial cooperation. The EU insists that Palestinian textbooks meet UNESCO standards for peace and tolerance in school education. This was in the EU-UNRWA strategic dialogue.  The EU consistently requests clarification on UNRWA handling of non-neutrality buyers and non-violence issues in textbooks. In the recent review of support to the two-state solution, I proposed linking disbursement of funding to the implementation of agreed reforms, which could also be extended to curricula.  May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important file on the international agenda.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Commissioner Hahn. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The debate is actually closed. It may not be appropriate, but I would like to say this now: it is very thankful that the Commissioner has responded to individual requests for comment. However, I find it absolutely inappropriate – it may be that, on a case-by-case basis, of the 30 speakers who have now been registered in the debate, at the end, when the Commissioner replies, fewer than ten are still there. Less than ten! All the political groups are affected. There are no particularly noble and no less noble ones. As I said, there are individual cases. I think we should certainly develop a bit of culture. Because certain things have to do not only with respect and respect, but simply with children's room. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. UNRWA is a United Nations agency charged with providing assistance and protection to some 5 million Palestinian refugees. In 2016 and 2017, the EU and its Member States totalled €424 million and €391 million to UNRWA, making the European Union the main source of aid for the Agency. In March 2018, the Agency raised about $100 million in new contributions. Only the EU, through the EU High Representative, Mogherini, announced a contribution of €82 million for the 2018 operating budget. President Trump has decided to stop disbursing more than $300 million from which he financed UNRWA; the reasons for the funding cuts relate to cost disproportion, an unsustainable business model and inadequate fiscal policies. How many Palestinian refugees are assisted? The criteria for Palestinian refugee status need to be reviewed. Of those 5 million assisted by UNRWA, only a part can be considered refugees. The Agency has never condemned the ideology of Islamist organisations. There is no reason why the ANP should not take care of those Palestinians who should be citizens of the State of Palestine that Ramallah aspires to be or become.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The United Nations Agency for Palestinian Refugees provides basic necessities to more than five million Palestinian refugees in the Middle East, and especially in Gaza. Following the Trump Administration's announcement to cut its funds, UNWRA is in an unprecedented financial crisis. The U.S. decision last September is a $360 million reduction for your budget. Saving UNRWA must be a priority to alleviate the lives of hundreds of thousands of Palestinian refugee families. In 2019, donors, especially the EU, will have to advance and increase funds to maintain schools, clinics and food aid in Gaza. Most EU Member States are already committing to this. In addition to the limitations on UNWRA, the serious humanitarian and specifically health situation in the Gaza Strip must be highlighted. We Members of the European Parliament are still unable to access Gaza because the Israeli authorities are preventing official delegations from this Parliament from taking an interest in the situation and fate of our humanitarian aid and EU cooperation.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – During my visits to the region, I was able to convince myself that UNRWA is doing an excellent job in the Palestinian territories. The organization is vital for the basic infrastructure of the Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank – schools, hospitals, food supplies! In addition, there is financial support for 400 000 Palestinian refugees in Syria. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to continue to promote UNRWA and its appropriate funding. The announcement of an increase in EU funding is to be welcomed: if the US fails, Europe will have to pledge its support all the stronger, all the more decisively. As we now know, the EU cannot rely on the role of the US as a neutral mediator in the peace process– but above all the people affected on the ground. The European Union must be prepared to play this role. However, this can only be achieved with a genuine, common European foreign policy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The us' cut in funding for UNRWA is part of a broad maneuver of explicit support for Israel's criminal policy against the Palestinian population and international legality. This us-Israel offensive aims to derail the two-state solution to the Palestinian issue, a solution that has been proclaimed in UN resolutions for decades. It aims to impose by force a single state, of a confessional and racist nature, in virtually the entire historical territory of Palestine.  In view of this situation, it is unacceptable that the European Union, which claims to be so respectful of human rights, does not question the association agreement with Israel, which provides for the importation of products manufactured in illegally occupied Palestinian territories. It is also unacceptable for the EU to fund joint research programmes with Israeli companies through Horizon 2020, the results of which are used later in war and torture against the Palestinian people.  The palestinian people's struggle for the creation of a viable and sovereign state of Palestine is just. Its implementation means that the major powers and the EU cease their explicit or implicit support for Israel's genocide policy.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Yemen (2018/2853 (RSP)."

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the war in Yemen has been raging for more than three years now. It has taken a tremendous toll on this country, where millions are suffering the consequences of the conflict. We see images of Yemenis eating tree leaves and parents forced to watch their babies starve to death. This is completely unacceptable. The figures are appalling: almost 18 million are literally starving. The UN recently warned that they may be unable to prevent a massive famine – unless the security situation improves. The escalation of hostilities along the coast has worsened an already disastrous situation: civilians and civilian infrastructure continue to be targeted, in clear violation of international humanitarian law. More than half a million people have been displaced from Hodeidah, where several hundred thousand more remain trapped. Public salaries in the northern part of the country, controlled by the Houthi, have not been paid in years. Instead of going to school, children are being recruited to fight on the frontlines. With the collapse of basic services, Yemenis have been deprived of health facilities and drinking water. This has led to the worst cholera epidemic ever recorded in the country. The war has also disrupted imports of basic commodities, driving prices up and pushing more and more Yemenis into poverty and destitution. Smuggling and war profiteering are thriving on the back of a suffering population. Lawlessness has allowed terrorist groups like al-Qaeda or Daesh to gain a foothold in the country.  The war has also had an impact in the region. Saudi Arabia has become a regular target of missiles coming from Houthi-controlled areas. Maritime traffic between the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean has been affected, as several ships have been targeted by rockets. But perhaps more importantly, the war has increased regional tensions. Indeed, Yemen remains a catalyst for instability and regional turmoil. There is no easy fix for Yemen. A political settlement will require concessions from all sides, continued banking and diplomatic pressure from the international community. That is why we believe it is more crucial than ever at this time to lend as much support as possible to the United Nations and their Special Envoy, Martin Griffiths. Let me thank him for his attempt to resume consultations in Geneva among the parties. It is unfortunate that the Houthi did not attend. As Griffiths put it, resumptions of talks are always a delicate, fragile moment. Our support, from the EU and our Member States, is now truly essential. We will therefore continue to call on the parties to remain engaged in the UN-led process in view of achieving a comprehensive political settlement to this really unacceptable war.  We will not just ‘declare’ our political commitment. We are looking into ways to provide concrete support to the UN Special Envoy team in areas identified by Mr Griffiths. The idea is to add value to his ongoing work and complement his efforts where needed. Furthermore, the European Union is already contributing EUR 173 million of development assistance to several projects in Yemen, ranging from rural resilience, health and nutrition, food security and support to displaced persons. These projects are meant to lay the groundwork for a stable Yemen by supporting crisis-affected communities and helping maintain the basic functions of local authorities. Likewise, the EU has allocated EUR 233 million in humanitarian aid alone through our partner organisations since the beginning of this conflict in 2015. Our humanitarian aid has been directed to the areas most in need and we have continued our advocacy efforts in international fora, even last week during the UN General Assembly. In this regard, we believe that the mandate of the Group of Eminent Experts set up by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights should be renewed. Its last report points to violations of international humanitarian law committed by all sides. Accountability is crucial, not only to a real resolution of the conflict, but also to an effective and inclusive reconciliation process in Yemen. The people of Yemen have suffered for too long. Building a more cooperative regional dynamic is in everyone’s interest – and it is becoming more and more urgent. This is my view, dear colleagues, and thank you for your attention.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –The consequences of the ongoing conflict on Yemen have passed the critical level. Casualties amongst civilians, destruction of civil infrastructure, which includes schools, medical facilities, water systems and transport routes, and the horrific humanitarian situation can no longer be accepted.  We supported the efforts made by the Special Envoy, Mr Martin Griffiths, and we consider it essential for him to have access to all relevant parties in Yemen. The EU’s intention is to help the Yemeni population, and this is why we need to support the efforts in identifying a political solution as soon as possible using dialogue and negotiations. We need to understand that all parties in the conflict must comply with their obligations under international law. All parties must attend the negotiation meeting; they need to end the recruitment of children; they need to seize the current escalation and effectively involve the United Nations. We can no longer accept the Iran-backed Houthi rebels’ systematic refusal to engage in dialogue. You must strongly call on Iran to cease any military support and push Houthi rebels to an effective dialogue. We must also strongly condemn the launch of ballistic missiles by the Houthi rebels against the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the use of sea mines. The European People’s Party is deeply concerned by the reports of the denial of freedom of religion and aggression towards the Bahá’i faith by the Houthi rebels. We cannot endlessly repair the damage without understanding and addressing the causes, and we can no longer ignore the obligation to ensure effective, impartial and independent investigations into all alleged violations of human rights and humanitarian law. As the Commissioner has already said, the EU will continue to provide humanitarian aid and put pressure on all parties for a political solution.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Mr Commissioner, it was difficult to imagine in our debate in the first part of this year that the already dramatic humanitarian situation in Yemen could further deteriorate. Sadly, we are here today to remind the international community that Yemenis are dying every day under indiscriminate bombing and shelling, and our so-called economic partners on both sides are contributing to this violence. The brutal and bloody long-term conflict in Yemen is about to get even worse, as the violent and indiscriminate attacks and blockade on civilians continue. As a consequence, today 75% of civilians are already completely dependent on humanitarian aid, and more than 17 million people are facing food insecurity. The Saudi-led blockade on all Houthi controlled territories since November 2017 prevents all other imports from entering the territory. The humanitarian aid is proving to be insufficient, and the Houthi rebels have themselves blocked the delivery of humanitarian aid. Considering the dire humanitarian situation on the ground and the grave risk of further regional destabilisation, the S&D Group calls on all relevant actors to put pressure on the coalition to halt any further assaults and to allow humanitarian aid to reach the people in need in order to stop any further starvation and death. We condemn the violent attacks on all sides, condemn the belligerence and call on the proxies, including Saudi Arabia and Iran, to immediately stop all armed forces and militias under their control, as well as to prevent any indiscriminate attacks against the civilian population. Finally we call for an investigation into war crimes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When discussing the situation in Yemen, it is worth remembering a few basic facts. First, the current conflict began three years ago with the overthrow of a legitimately elected president by Shiite Houthis backed by Iran. Secondly, of course, war crimes are committed by both sides, it is important to be honest and objective here, but it is worth remembering that there was a UN Security Council resolution a few months ago in February condemning Iran's participation and Iran's violation of the arms embargo and it was vetoed by the Russian Federation. Thirdly, the conflict in Yemen is a breeding ground for terrorist groups such as al-Qaida, and Hezbollah is training rebels in Yemen. Finally, speaking on behalf of the ESSC, we in the draft of our resolution call for negotiations and a peaceful end to the conflict.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, why is it that in the face of the worst conflicts, whether it is the conflict in Syria or Yemen as we’re discussing today, EU Member State governments fail to reach a common EU position. I would ask the Commissioner to also convey this question to the Austrian Presidency, because we need to solve the fragmentation – and therefore the lack of maximum EU efforts – as bloodshed on an unprecedented scale goes on and on. Twenty-two million people need humanitarian assistance, and 8.4 million people are on the brink of starvation. It is 2018. Children are being bombed, recruited as soldiers, or facing all kinds of epidemics that can also kill them. Babies too weak to cry are dying, and this is all because of a man-made problem. It is a crying shame.  We should focus, of course, on reining in Iran as it helps the Houthi rebels. But just as we do not allow the sale of weapons to these militants, an embargo should finally be adopted vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia. When the Dutch Government, along with the Canadian Government, sought an independent investigation into what was happening in Yemen, Saudi Arabia pushed back. But the fact that France and the United Kingdom helped water down the work of allies is unacceptable. The Saudis led, and Europeans followed. Frankly, it is an image I never wish to see. Instead, all focus should be on ending the bloodshed and the violence, so we support the UN Group of Eminent Experts, as well as the Special Envoy, Mr Griffiths. I believe that a referral to the ICC, or to other mechanisms for accountability, is very much needed for peace.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The UN believes that the conflict in Yemen is the world's worst humanitarian disaster at the moment. During the three-year civil war, tens of thousands of people have died, many have fled and 22 million are in need of humanitarian aid. Both government troops and rebels have been accused of war crimes by human rights organisations. Under the EU's common arms export rules, we are not allowed to export to countries at war. Yet almost all arms-producing EU countries do so, more or less, and in those countries that first decided to stop arms exports, it has resumed shortly thereafter. The Spanish Head of Government even stated on a television broadcast that Spain has no responsibility for what happens to the weapons supplied after they leave Spain. He's wrong. In many EU countries, civil society is pushing to stop arms exports. This has led to stricter arms export legislation in my country, but not to an end to exports. Sweden also continues to export. Parliament has often spoken out in favour of an embargo. It's needed now. Jobs and the survival of European companies are often used as an excuse, completely contrary to the common framework. How can European jobs be more important than putting an end to the suffering of the Yemeni people? Europe is very much involved in this war.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I really regret the hypocrisy of this Union. On the one hand, you are asking the Member States to increase humanitarian aid, but you know very well that refugees are being provoked by wars, and yet you look the other way and many States, such as Spain — mine - continue to do business with arms sales. Kill to keep killing.  The report of the United Nations expert group confirms what we already feared: the Saudi-led coalition is responsible for indiscriminate bombings of civilians and infrastructure, hospitals, school buses, etc. Its de facto blockade deliberately delays the entry of goods and medicines. Kill, in addition to bombs, hungry, with anger to the civilian population.  Listen to this Parliament: start the procedure for applying an embargo on arms sales to the countries involved— to all — in this conflict.  Our Foreign Minister has stated that the next shipment of weapons from Spain to Saudi Arabia will be four hundred precision laser bombs and that these do not cause collateral damage. Let's not be cynical: there are no indolore bombs. Let's open our eyes at once.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk in this House about the humanitarian disaster in Yemen, reference is often made to the hypocrisy that undersoes the bloody conflict. Today I want to give you two emblematic examples: last Friday, the UN Human Rights Council voted in favour of extending the mandate of a group of eminent experts to investigate human rights violations in Yemen. This group of experts had adopted a report accusing the parties in the conflict, as early as 28 August between them, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, of possible war crimes. It is not surprising that Riyadh and Abu Dhabi voted against it, it is much more so that both Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates sit on the Council, the world's most important body for respect for human rights.  Even more absurd is the situation in our own house, as you all know, the European Union has adopted a binding common position on arms exports. Sales to Riyadh would at least violate two of the eight criteria of the position, but if you violate there are no sanctions and that doesn't seem to matter to anyone. Recent cases and controversies in Spain and Germany are emblematic, emblematic of the reportage released on Friday in which a story of corruption and sale of Leclerc tanks by France to the Emirates is documented. Those same tanks are now actively used in the conflict for defensive purposes, thunders the Minister of Defence, long live hypocrisy! Other countries are involved, including my own, I hope for a little longer, but on the other hand, no Member State wants to give up its rich contracts, well aware that its non-exports would simply be replaced with peace of position, indeed common hypocrisy. In the shadow of this hypocrisy, more than 15 000 dead and 17 million people starving, among them, more than 5 million children and a new offensive in the Hodeida area with over half a million people fleeing. Ladies and gentlemen, every time a child dies, all humanity dies, and in Yemen this happens every ten minutes. It is no longer enough to keep repeating the usual trite and shredded phrases, and our large humanitarian aid is not enough either. We need a strong signal and I repeat that the High Representative must immediately take an initiative to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, the dirty war in Yemen is one of the tragic facets of a Middle East in the grip of a dynamic chaos largely fuelled by western powers.  It is not for us to take sides in this conflict between Yemeni tribes for political, historical or religious reasons, but we cannot ignore the diplomatic choices of Western governments, especially French ones, blindly following their Saudi ally for fear of juicy arms contracts flying.  Our governments are hard-working defenders of human rights in condemning Syria and its Russian and Iranian allies who are fighting unsusc thinking against Islamist movements. On the other hand, they remain in an embarrassed silence about the hundreds of thousands of bombs dropped in Yemen and the humanitarian embargo imposed by the Arab coalition formed by Saudi Arabia. On the rubble of the Middle East, the jihadists are thriving, which our governments then pretend to fight. To get out of this situation, let us put an end to this hypocrisy as unbearable as it is dangerous.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the curse of Yemen – let me say this – is due to the fact that this country has enormous strategic importance and position. Located at the southern end of the Arabian Peninsula, it controls the Bab-el-Mandeb Strait, which is a channel through which trade takes place, but also transports oil from the Red Sea through the Gulf of Aden to Europe and Asia. That is why it is 'reasonable' for many countries to want to control this region.   After 2009, Saudi Arabia reappeared in 2015 as the head of an Arab coalition to support Sunni President Hadi against Shiite Huthi rebels, who are discreetly supported and sent weapons from Iran. This attempt at sovereignty in the region enables the militants to fight. The Huthi have now balanced the situation and so they are all fighting against everyone and fighting with representatives as well.  But this situation affects the only losers who are civilians: 10,000 dead, 40,000 injured, 2 million have fled their homes, 7 million are at risk of famine and another 1 million are infected with cholera. This situation cannot end – and here there is hypocrisy – because all the great powers of Europe and ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In April this year, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres described the situation in Yemen as follows: "Yemen is the world's worst humanitarian crisis. More than 22 million people, or three-quarters of the population, are in need of humanitarian aid and protection." Indeed, the panel of experts set up by the United Nations Human Rights Council has found that international humanitarian law in Yemen is being violated by all sides. As the previous speakers have already said, I share the view that there can be no winners in this conflict, which over the years has increasingly become a proxy war for regional powers. What happens next? In my view, three brief comments. Firstly, it is regrettable that the Huthi delegation did not show up in an attempt to resume peace talks in Geneva. Special Envoy Martin Griffith's efforts to bring the parties to the conflict together for talks in October must also be supported. As I said, this conflict can only be resolved politically. Secondly, the first objective on the road to peace should be confidence-building measures between the parties to the conflict. This concerns, in particular, intra-Yemeni dialogue without the involvement of other regional powers. Thirdly, independent investigations into human rights violations are necessary, and they are also in the national interest. The most serious violations of human dignity, as unfortunately happen every day in Yemen, must not be without consequences.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you only have to look at the map to see the strategic importance of Yemen and to see how this dirty war is being waged by distant interests, by those territories that set the United States and its Saudi ally against Iran and that enrich arms manufacturers around the world. It is precisely these interests that condemn the population to live well below acceptable living standards. In a state of more than 24 million inhabitants, in fact, 75% of Yemenis depend on humanitarian aid, hunger and epidemics are used as siege weapons, actions that can be identified as war crimes. I think we have to tear apart the veil of indifference that hides all this. We must be clear in our political judgment towards our neighbours, both towards the coalition and towards Iran, and we must loudly denounce the responsibilities of the various European countries to this conflict. This is where European hypocrisy is revealed and it is here, I believe, that we have an extra responsibility, as the European Parliament, to point the way forward for a political solution to this conflict.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I could not support your words more today. We really are, as a parliament, facing the grave danger that our text will leave us open to misrepresentation. Our intentions and actions must be to support international efforts for peace. The world’s worst humanitarian crisis, according to the United Nations – Yemen is a theatre of conflict where almost every immediate neighbour has found itself drawn in due to remote interests sowing discord and destabilising not just Yemen itself, but the entire neighbourhood. Saudi Arabia finds itself targeted with missiles, Houthis utilise public facilities to have cover; all the time remotely supported and directed. The propaganda machine seeks to distort and detract, so that the world is misinformed. Within that vacuum grows extremism. The ultimate agenda of which is to cause chaos. That should not be our agenda, and neither should we allow anybody to misrepresent our position.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the only way to end the conflict is to support a negotiated and political inclusive settlement. It is regrettable that the last round of consultations in Geneva has not been successful. We support Mr Griffiths' efforts and call on the European Union to play a facilitator role. We missed an opportunity here in Parliament in May, before the Hodeida assault and the worsening of the situation. It is essential to put an end to the blockade, which has claimed more lives than the fighting. Particular attention must be paid to indirect causes of civilian deaths, which are referenced and documented. According to UNICEF, more than 247,000 malnourished children have died since 2016, and another 200,000 will die as a result of the blockade. Yemen has more than three million internally displaced people, plus those in Hodeida. Unfortunately, funding for the resilience programme in rural areas has been delayed due to a lack of adequate funding. We are still talking about the worst humanitarian crisis! We must welcome the honourable position of the European Union in the Human Rights Council and resolution L21, which has just been voted to extend the mandate of the group of experts. We must help this group and counter the intimidation campaigns that are being launched by the coalition against its members, and in particular against Kamel al. (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we know all about the horror in Yemen: war crimes, millions of people at risk of starvation, thousands of civilians killed, school buses bombed. Of course, we support the UN peace process, humanitarian aid and humanitarian corridors, but, Commissioner, for the European Union to be credible, for the European Union to be an actor of peace, its Member States must not be actors in war! When Germany, Spain, Great Britain and France are indirect belligerents of this conflict, providing weapons to facilitate these atrocities, we lose all credibility - and these Member States do so in violation of both European and international law. Commissioner, as the European Parliament says, we must defend an embargo, go before the Member States, go to the Council, publicly demand an embargo on arms sales and demand that Europe stop participating in these atrocities!

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proxy war continues in Yemen where no one wins and the only ones who lose are civilians, dying in their thousands. Yemeni civilians are, in fact, the real protagonists of this war, in a country that is now nothing more than a huge battlefield. Perhaps for some it is a game, perhaps for others it is enough to liquidate the collateral damage and the deaths of 6 600 civilians and the destruction of an entire country to justify a humanitarian catastrophe of this magnitude.  None of the parties to the conflict has achieved or is close to a military victory, but bombs continue to rain down on the heads of the population. This war reminds Vietnam of its total futility, where the only results in the end will be only the dead to count and the rubble of a country to be rebuilt. A war in which there is only one winner and it is the arms industry, even ours unfortunately. In the light of the ongoing humanitarian tragedy, I call on the EU to press for the Saudi-led coalition to stop the bombing and lift the embargo immediately. This blockade is, in fact, preventing access to humanitarian supplies and other goods that are absolutely essential to the population, which is the only one paying the price for this war.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, ‘the state is not in control of its natural resources. The state is simply handcuffed and cannot do anything’. This statement was made by Ahmed Ghaleb, former head of the Yemeni tax authority two days ago. It sums up the disastrous situation in this benighted country.  Let’s be clear: this is a proxy war between Iran and the Saudi-Emirati alliance, with only the Yemeni people suffering from indiscriminate attacks. So many decisions on Yemen, yet few taken by Yemenis themselves. So little interest shown by the international community in local political groups, apart from the discredited Hadi regime, has seen the splintering of normally homogenous groups. The Southern Movement, which was a broad church, has been marginalised and split into so many groups that what could have been a stabilising force has become a group of warring factions. On Sunday, seven people were killed through intra-Houthi fighting. We must engage honestly with local political leaders, respecting their concerns. Peace can only be built up from the base of local society in Yemen and we should not prejudge political outcomes before genuine discussion.  Finally, the Yemeni rial is at an all-time low. Demonstrations are planned throughout the country as ordinary people rise up against this further disaster. The crash of the rial can be blamed firmly on the international community and particularly the Gulf alliance. If there is civil unrest, we can anticipate further loss of life, and the people to suffer will be the ordinary people of Yemen. Hence, all solutions should be on the table.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I think a few figures speak very clearly: 22 million Yemenis are in need of humanitarian assistance and protection, and 18 million are food insecure. They lack everything: food, medicine and education. Moreover, the deadlock observed after the failure of the Geneva negotiations, in which the Houthis simply refused to take part, only increases the number of dead, wounded and displaced. In this context, the European Union continues to provide development assistance to Yemen by prioritizing interventions aimed at stabilizing the country and I congratulate Commissioner Stylianides for his commitment and action.  However, there is another important plan on which an essential role could be played: the diplomatic plan. I really believe that the European Union is particularly well placed to steer things. We must therefore continue to call for a return to the negotiating table and encourage all parties to engage effectively in a political dialogue under the aegis, of course, of the United Nations.  Indeed, today, it is of paramount importance that this commitment be translated into de-escalation in the various conflict zones, including Hodeida, and safe, rapid and unhindered access to the delivery of commercial and humanitarian supplies.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, there are tens of millions of people in the world fleeing hunger and war. And there are some countries where the same people run away from both things, from hunger and from war. This is the case of Yemen, a poor country among the poor, one of the poorest in the world. Three out of four Yemenis are at risk of malnutrition. The population currently in Yemen is at certain risk of starvation is equivalent to the people of Belgium. It is equivalent to the joint population of Hungary, Latvia and Lithuania. The priorities we need to address are, first of all, to reduce hunger and malnutrition. Second, avoid continued cholera outbreaks. Third, protect civilians. But an immediate diplomatic effort must be made to allow access to humanitarian aid. Seven and a half million Yemenis are unavailable for the arrival of this aid. There are now more than one hundred and fifty non-governmental organizations working to help this at-risk population, but it will not be the humanitarian actors that end the war. It will have to be a determined diplomatic action that pushes both sides to reach the agreement being promoted by the United Nations.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, this tragic war has been ‘escalating virtually on all fronts. The level of confidence is at its lowest and [the] human and humanitarian cost is ever rising’. These are the words of the UN Special Envoy for Yemen, Martin Griffiths, to the Security Council last month. They sum up the continuing disaster unfolding in Yemen in a war that has tragically claimed the lives of at least 10 000 people since fighting broke out in 2015. Furthermore it is estimated that a staggering 22 million – 75% of the population – are in urgent need of humanitarian aid often encompassing the most basic of needs such as access to food, water and medicine. The Saudi—led offensive, particularly since its push this summer into Hodeidah region, has worsened the humanitarian crisis. According to estimates from the charity Save the Children, cases of cholera have increased by 170% since June, which in a country that has seen its public health facilities – largely as a result of bombing of hospitals – decimated, poses the real threat of a worse and more deadly epidemic. It is clear that talks must now resume urgently, not only to find a lasting resolution to the conflict but also ensure ways of alleviating the humanitarian disaster situation. In this regard, it is of paramount importance that the Houthi faction engages in the UN—led process in Geneva. I will also re—echo my previous concerns regarding the conduct of the Saudi—led coalition in its air campaign offensive and also the use by Houthis of human shields, claiming so many lives of civilians. The incident that saw 40 children killed in a bus attack in Saada last month is in the... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, the protracted civil war in Yemen has gone on for far too long. Internal conflict, exacerbated by regional powers, has had an unbearably high human cost. Only in August, 40 children were killed by a Saudi air strike using a bomb supplied by the United States. The UK Government continues to approve munitions knowing that they are being used in such crimes. It is brutality of the highest order that Saudi Arabia and Iran are using the people of Yemen as a field for their indirect proxy war. Both sides must stop their operations and use their influence to bring their proxies and allies around the negotiation table. As for the UK and US, we must seriously examine our role in such grave abuses of crimes of war. Our role cannot be ignored any longer.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Human Rights Watch has accused the Saudi-allied military alliance in Yemen of another war crime by bombing a school bus and killing 38 children, publicly accusing the alliance of continuing the gruesome series of killing civilians at weddings, civilians at funerals, civilians in hospitals and civilians in schools. It's hard to perfider! One of the largest humanitarian disasters is currently taking place in Yemen. We all know who the perpetrators are, we know who is supplying the weapons and, ladies and gentlemen, we are doing nothing. Backed by the West, for example, the weapons from the US, France, Spain, the United Kingdom, or Germany, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are funding militias in Yemen that have ties to ISIS and Al Qaeda. This war is about the annihilation of the Huthi ethnic group. This genocide must be stopped! The US and the belligerent EU members – Britain, France, Germany, for example – must stop supplying arms, and the troops fighting there must stop supporting the atrocities and genocide. Foreign troops out of Yemen! Then there will be peace there.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the dramatic situation in Yemen has already been discussed in this House on other occasions.  The first article of the draft Resolution to be adopted tomorrow expresses our concern at the devastating situation in this country, which has been presented to us by the Commissioner and which has been described to us by other Members: 22 million people in a humanitarian emergency – 5 million children – and 77,000 children dying each year. This situation is really unsustainable.  That is why, Mr President, apart from expressing our concern and seeking culprits, what we should do is to seek solutions.  First of all, we have to deal with the humanitarian emergency. That is why it is important to recognize the efforts of the United Nations and its negotiating tables for the country. Secondly, Commissioner, thank you for the efforts being made by the European Union, and particularly the Commissioner, who is joining us today in this debate. And thirdly, also thank many regional partners who have made important contributions available to the United Nations to try to alleviate this situation.  On the other hand, Mr President, it is very important to stop and end violence, to ensure that international humanitarian law prevails and, at the same time, to try to protect civilians.  Finally, I believe that the Commissioner has explained this in a crystal clear way, we must support the efforts of the special envoy of the Secretary-General of the United Nations to try to make the two sides sit at the negotiating table, to get the Houthi rebels to be part of this Geneva process and, at the same time, to ensure that the two sides sit at the negotiating table, to get the Houthi rebels to be part of this Geneva process, and at the same time , Mr President, to give our competition as a European Union to try to achieve a Yemen that is stable, that lives in peace and that is as far away from extremism as possible.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, it is high time that we debated Yemen given the neglect of this crisis politically and financially by the European Union and the Member States. This is extremely concerning given that it is one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises. Two million people displaced, continued famine and cholera outbreaks exacerbate an already dire situation. I believe Europe has been compromised because of the arms sales to Saudi Arabia, including by the UK’s Tory government, and it risks being complicit in possible war crimes in Yemen. I believe we really have to stand up in a meaningful way and stop selling arms to Saudi Arabia.  Along with other colleagues, I deeply regret that the Geneva consultations had to be abandoned last Saturday, so I have some questions for the Commissioner. Three points. Firstly, we need a ceasefire to stop the killings and move from hostilities to negotiation. What has the EEAS done to find a political solution to the conflict? Secondly, what are the outcomes of the political consultations on regional issues with Iran on Yemen? And thirdly, any peace deal focusing on the north, and not the east and the south, will not succeed in the long term in finding a political solution. How will you ensure Yemen’s future territorial integrity?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as has already been said here, the third year of the fierce civil war in Yemen, which is actually a conflict between Western-backed Saudi Arabia and Iran on the other side, continues. Alongside Syria, it is the bloodiest conflict in the world today with tragic humanitarian consequences. It's kind of a party to the world's mainstream, perhaps because the world powers here are playing their games, including the US, the UK, and France. Unfortunately, we really do not see any truly effective political activity here either by the UN or by the European Union. All we can and must do at the moment is save lives, and I thank the Commissioner for talking about this. We're putting out a fire that others are burning. In fact, the EU is transforming into the largest humanitarian organisation. It is, of course, good that we are helping, but there is a lack of prevention and just saving is not enough.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the humanitarian situation in Yemen continues to deteriorate and has now become one of the worst in the world. Recently, the UN Special Envoy for Yemen stated his concern about the possibility of an imminent famine. This extremely worrying situation must be urgently addressed by the European Union and the Member States.  France and my country, the UK, have consistently been called out in this Chamber for their arms sales to the Saudi-led coalition. Their complicity in this war is unacceptable. They must be held accountable for their contribution to the US extra-judicial killings programme through the sharing of intelligence.  The EU must continue to link up efforts with the United Nations and support a political solution achieved through multilateral diplomacy, with all parties involved sitting around the table. In the meantime, the EU must also put all its efforts into finding temporary humanitarian solutions for the people who are suffering on the ground from a war they did not choose.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, everyone has already said it: Yemen, for four years the scene of a terrible conflict and the images that reach us do not lie. Emaciated babies, too weak to cry. Officially, 8.4 million people are threatened by famine. It's actually a real humanitarian disaster, a real "lost generation" growing up there, a lost generation. Younger children who are actually recruited to be child soldiers, who are susceptible to abuse. In fact, in Yemen there is a real breeding ground for recruitment by terrorist organisations. Commissioner Hahn, we must raise our voices, everyone here, loud and clear, is united as Europe. Let's stop recruiting child soldiers. Where is the arms embargo against Saudi Arabia? Where is the European strategy for Yemen? Where is the European pressure against the ongoing blockade? Let's work on it together.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: "Mr. President, how can we be so hypocritical? They are the contradictions of capitalism, which first speaks of tragedy, that he sees photos to share on Facebook of dead children and who is then able to export weapons to Saudi Arabia. Like those sold by Spain during the Government of Rajoy – the third largest exporter of the European Union, with nine hundred million euros – to the Saudi-led international coalition. The king himself even took a picture.  There is a clear breach of the Arms Trade Treaty. Civilians are indiscriminately bombed, and that's forbidden. The minister of the current Government also made a statement saying that precision weapons do not cause side effects. Weapons always cause side effects. Always. Four hundred bombs sold, in this past September, of laser precision. Civilians are indiscriminately bombed. It is our shame: a humanitarian disaster of hunger, epidemics and wars. That's why, Commissioner, do a study and stop this war. Do an arms export study. And stop. And lay down the weapons that are killing people.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, my dear Commissioner, I think that the situation by MEPs was not needed for your ears, because I am sure that, even if all the information you have received from here is added, the tragic information you have is unfortunately more.  But I think there is something that needs to be done and it has been said many years by colleagues: Can we clearly tell Member States to stop sending arms to Saudi Arabia? Can we clearly tell Member States that this thing must stop? If we cannot do this, then I feel a futility at the repetition and re-exploding of all the evils that are happening in Yemen.  11 million kids are hungry... What else can one say? Schools are being bombed, marriages, thousands of refugees, life has turned into hell. The situation is shocking, in the expression of a United Nations representative. So if you want to do something, it is to say clear words to the Member States that contribute to this evil.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, Yemen is currently facing the worst humanitarian crisis in the world, UN Secretary-General António Guterres said, adding that the situation in Yemen is catastrophic.  Unfortunately, Member States of the European Union continue to approve arms transfers to Saudi Arabia, ignoring the will of the Council and the European Commission to impose an embargo on the sale of arms by European Union countries against Saudi Arabia.  Vulnerable groups, women and children are particularly affected by ongoing hostilities and the humanitarian crisis and the number of civilian casualties continues to rise. According to the UN, 8.4 million people are on the brink of starvation in Yemen, whose population depends mostly on food that is barely imported. Needs have increased further and 13 million people are now starving.  Unless the warring sides return to the negotiating table to end the war in this poorest country in the Arabian Peninsula, where Saudi-backed government forces are fighting Iran-backed Houthi rebels, no matter how much money the UN and European Union give, the situation will not improve.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, in Yemen Saudi Arabia and Iran are clarifying their differences. Only they make them clear at the expense of one people, in a region where actually over 23 million people are in a humanitarian crisis. We have thousands of innocent people who have been killed. And that is the first thing we need to take into account.  The second is that there is a huge export of arms from the war industries of the Member States of the European Union to Saudi Arabia. So if we want to stop this clearing of Iran's accounts with Saudi Arabia that is taking place in Yemen, we must demand that the sale of arms to anyone involved in this war be stopped and, above all, that arms be exported to Saudi Arabia by the Member States of the European Union. That's it. That must be our decision.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, it is the crimes of capitalism that impose barbarism. It is the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia and supported by the United States, the United Kingdom and France that has bombed civilian targets, killing hundreds of people and dozens of children, as in last August's attacks. It is the weapons produced in those countries and in others in the European Union that have killed some 16,000 people, two-thirds of them civilians, and injured more than 55,000. Yemenis face the world's worst humanitarian crisis, 8.4 million severely affected by famine, a situation that is exacerbated by Saudi Arabia's restrictions on imports of food and fuel. It is these countries that silence war crimes and repression within Saudi Arabia itself, putting on that murky regime of a so-called modernization. It is time for the peoples to mobilize for peace, for the end of a gigantic crime against the Yemeni people and against the cynicism of imperialism, the European Union and its military powers.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as I underlined in my opening remarks, in Yemen, we face not a regular humanitarian crisis, but a real humanitarian catastrophe. As I have always said, unfortunately, in humanitarian problems and in humanitarian crises, we do not have humanitarian solutions – we have only political solutions. This is why, as the European Union, we focus on some initiatives, diplomatic initiatives, including behind the scenes, to promote a ceasefire across Yemen, and of course, above all, our strategy remains peace in this very painful situation in Yemen. We have made a lot of diplomatic efforts and taken a lot of initiatives, but up till now the situation remains as you describe.  I heard many suggestions from you regarding the situation, but you know that in such a situation, you have to be pragmatic. We have to see the situation on the ground and our role as the European Union, as a regional and global actor, in order to be and to stay result oriented. Frankly, what I see in Yemen, what I can handle every day, is a very painful experience, as my compatriot Takis Hadjigeorgiou said, but at the same time, I would like to remind you that in some critical decisions, including inside our institutions, especially within the European Council, we need unanimity. So you can imagine that it is not easy to find common European positions in many of our efforts, initiatives or decisions. We have to continue to provide humanitarian and development assistance. I already gave you specific figures about our contribution in this difficult situation. We remain the biggest humanitarian and development donor in Yemen, but we have to accept the hard reality: our efforts and our initiatives to change the situation on the ground, unfortunately, have limits.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: We have received seven motions for resolutions, tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 4 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. It is one of the world's greatest humanitarian tragedies in Yemen, with 9,245 people killed and 52,800 injured between March 2015 and the beginning of 2018. At least 5,558 were civilians as of December 14, 2017. Three-quarters of the population remains suspended from humanitarian aid, including eight million people in an even more serious situation: "that is, they don't know when they will have their next meal," according to Mark Lowcock, the UN under-secretary-general for humanitarian affairs.  Added to these dramatic circumstances are deplorable sanitary conditions. As a result, 2,248 people were killed by cholera between April 2017 and January 2018.  But perhaps most astonishing is the indifference of the international community, even though humanitarian aid can no longer be delivered on a drip-feed basis in the face of blockades. It is therefore urgent to guarantee its delivery to its beneficiaries, at the risk of bearing a historical responsibility in the increase in the human toll.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The war in Yemen has been going on since 2015 and, unfortunately, there are many indications that it will be extremely difficult to end the conflict quickly. The war has already killed tens of thousands. Unfortunately, they are largely civilians, including children. Recent reports by Save the Children are particularly worrying.
