Up to five million children are starving or seriously under-eating, tens of thousands are unlikely to be rescued and they will simply die of starvation later this year. This is one of the major humanitarian disasters we are facing in the world today. I am therefore of the opinion that the political efforts to resume the peace process, which have recently been undertaken by the UN, must go hand in hand with increased humanitarian aid. I hope that the rebels will be able to get the rebels to join the talks, but it is equally important to reach out to the civilian population without undue delay and provide them with the support they need to survive.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. – Yemen was established in 1990, after a long bloody conflict, by merging traditional mountain resorts from around the northern capital Sana'a and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, the former British colony of Aden. Not only two different parts of the country, but also a different interpretation of the Muslim religion: Sunnis and Shiites have long divided the country. Political instability culminated months ago with the conquest of the capital by the militant Shiite organization al-Houthi and the president's flight to Aden. Sunni forces have received massive military support from saudi arabia's military, and this one is slowly but surely progressing in heavy bombardment of a number of rebel-held areas. In particular, the world public is watching with concern the heavy fighting in the port of Al-Hudajda, where humanitarian aid has flowed into the northern part of the country. The whole thing, of course, has a broader background. Shiites have the support of Iran, Sunni Saudi Arabia backed by a broader coalition of Arab countries. Somewhat out of the world's attention, which highlights in particular the problem of food and medical shortages, the main reason why rivals for Yemen have been competing for years is Bab-al-Mandab, the strait in the strait that connects the Red Sea to the Indian Ocean. Whatever the outcome of the conflict, millions of the country's population will once again be poorer and more economically dependent on aid from abroad. But what Yemen now urgently needs is immediate help to stop the fighting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - The civil war in Yemen is in its fourth year and, in addition to the casualties, the country is in dire humanitarian and security situations. In addition, the political crisis is also ongoing. Hostilities and violence and the attack on civilians in Yemen must be stopped immediately. Any attack on civilians is contrary to international law and the perpetrators of such attacks must be held accountable. It is important to support the UN Special Representative, who is trying to bring all parties to the negotiating table, because only that can be reached for a possible solution to the conflict. It is necessary to ensure that humanitarian aid is reaching crisis areas immediately.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – The Republic of Yemen is one of the poorest Arab states in the world, and the non-subsiding war, unfortunately, continues to strengthen instability not only in the Republic of Yemen but also in the neighbouring countries of the Middle East. Successive air strikes in the town of Hodeidah have again claimed dozens of lives and many have been injured. I strongly condemn the attacks on civilians. The European Union expects all parties to ensure the protection of the civilian population and to stop the exploitation of innocent children, as carriers of the future generation, and I believe that the need is a swift response from the entire international community to protect them.  I call for a swift resolution of the humanitarian aid blockade for war victims. The direct consequences of armed conflict are large scale and unless something is done, they are a direct threat to the entire population. Yemenis went through the worst cholera in modern history last year, with more than a million cases (half of which were children). I believe that swift action by the European Union as a leader of peace and dialogue is needed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Miriam Dalli's report, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting emission performance standards for new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles, as part of the Union's integrated approach to reducing CO2 emissions from light commercial vehicles, and amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 715/2007 (reformation) (COM(2017)0676 – C8-0395/2017 – 2017/0293(COD)) (A8-0287/2018).

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you, Commissioner Cañete, and all the shadow rapporteurs for the way we work together. I am proud to be standing here to defend the Committee on the Environment’s position on legislation that respects our climate targets, the environment, public health, industry and competitiveness. I am proud because together we realised that the way forward is to ensure the environmental integrity of the industry as a whole. We agreed that real driving emissions are a necessity, and that any emission values that the European Commission bases itself on have to be measured values and not simply values declared by the car manufacturers. We agreed that we have to move from measuring emissions at the tail pipe to analysing the whole life cycle of a vehicle. That, together with the well—to—wheels approach, can really promote cleaner technology and cleaner fuels. We agreed that investment in recharging infrastructure is to be promoted, and battery and battery cell manufacturing close to vehicle manufacturing sites should be supported. I am for more ambition than what the European Commission is proposing. I am for more ambition, because we have studies that clearly show that we need to take decisive action. More ambition will stimulate innovation and investment in the European Union. It will create jobs in the years to come, particularly if the European Union embarks on a long-term strategy that seriously attracts battery production investments to the European Union. This is confirmed by the European Commission itself. I did not want to speak about numbers, but I want to set the record straight. Let’s take a 40% CO2 reduction: we would be creating 69 000 jobs in the EU if we imported batteries from outside the European Union. If we had to produce batteries within the EU, we would be creating 92 000 jobs. With a 40% CO2 reduction, there would be 12 000 fewer jobs in the automotive sector over a period of 12 years until 2030. However, at the same time, in its blueprint for cooperation on skills and the automotive sector, the Commission is saying that there will be 900 000 employees, who will retire or leave the sector between 2017 and 2025. Because workers are a priority, we are proposing a gradual transition complemented by targeted programmes to ensure that no one is impacted negatively. An ambitious proposal is all about car manufacturers having the right incentive to invest and create quality jobs right here in the European Union. I ask two questions:  why are car manufacturers investing seven times as much outside the European Union as they do within the European Union when it comes to cleaner cars? Why are car manufacturers, telling their workers’ councils that they cannot invest in battery production in the EU because of high salary costs, but then Chinese companies open battery production sites in the EU paying EU salaries. As far as I’m concerned, the answer is simple: there aren’t the right incentives for the industry to invest in cleaner cars. And we have a choice: we have a choice between attracting investment to the European Union or letting other continents take the lead, with all the disruptive effects that this will have on our industry, on our companies and our small producers, our environment and our cities. This is the time to act. This is the time to show that, for us, it is not a question of industry versus the environment, but an issue of making sure that we address both the environment and industry together. We have the opportunity to act tomorrow in our vote in this plenary.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here today for the debate on the Commission proposal setting CO2 emissions standards for cars and vans for the period up to 2020. This is a key proposal to implement the 2030 climate and energy framework, to continue delivering on our commitments under the Paris Agreement and to contribute to the transition to a low carbon economy.  This is not just essential for the climate, but also for Europe’s economic prosperity and global competiveness. With the adoption of the legislative proposals on the 2030 climate and energy framework, thanks to the excellent work of all our institutions, the European Union is turning its global commitments into reality and is determined to continue as a world leader in the fight against climate change.  Under the Effort Sharing Regulation the Member States now have binding emission reduction targets up to 2030 in the sectors not included in the European Union Emissions Trading System – that is transport, buildings, agriculture and waste. Now it is time to make sure that at European level we have the right regulatory framework in place to contribute to meeting these targets. With almost a quarter of the European Union’s total greenhouse gas emissions coming from transport, this sector has a vital role to play in this transition. While Europe has reduced its emissions by some 23% since 1990, road transport emissions have grown by about 20% and today, transport accounts for more than 20% of Europe’s total emissions and this continues to grow.  The Commission’s legislative proposal setting the new CO2 standards for cars and vans for post-2020 is therefore an essential instrument to address this. Your vote tomorrow is instrumental to allow the adoption of the proposal during the current legislative term and we need to give a clear and stable regulatory signal to industry as soon as possible because this will stimulate the right investments in the transition towards zero emission mobility.  I want to thank the rapporteur, Ms Dalli, for her hard work on this proposal, putting together the position of this Parliament, as well as for our constructive discussions and cooperation. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their work.  I want to underline that the Commission proposal, underpinned by a thorough impact assessment, is both ambitious and realistic. It strikes the right balance between the three main policy objectives that cannot be considered in isolation: firstly, achieving environmental benefits, secondly, bringing savings for consumers and finally, safeguarding employment and competitiveness in the European Union.  The Commission proposal allows for a smooth, gradual and realistic transition to zero emission vehicles. The pace of the transition is essential, as the automotive sector is crucial for Europe’s prosperity, providing jobs for 12 million people in manufacturing, sales, maintenance and transport and accounting for 4% of gross domestic product.  We need to give sufficient time to achieve this reformation, to undertake the necessary investments and to reskill and upskill the workers in the current automotive supply chain. Our target will have positive impacts on the overall economy. At the same time, the number of jobs will remain stable in the automotive sector.  Our proposal will also bring significant environmental benefits. The proposal is projected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from road transport by around 22% between 2005 and 2030, contributing to our necessary efforts to implement the Paris Agreement. We have already agreed, or proposed, additional policies which will further reduce emissions from this sector, including the recently agreed Renewable Energy Directive, as well as the proposal on CO2 standards for heavy duty vehicles, the revised Eurovignette and the Clean Vehicles and Combined Transport Directives.  From the side of consumers, the 30% target will bring significant economic benefits. Consumers will save money – up to EUR 400 for the average new car bought in 2025 and more than EUR 1 400 in 2030.  Let me conclude by saying once again that the Commission remains fully supportive of the efforts of Parliament and the Council to conclude positive discussions on this proposal still this year. I look forward to continuing to work with you on the proposal and bringing it to a positive successful conclusion. This is what our citizens, our consumers, our companies and our workers expect from all of us.

name: Karima DELLI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Transport and Tourism Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, transport accounts for more than 20% of Europe's CO2 emissions, and 70% of these emissions come from road transport. As a result, air pollution causes the premature death of 500,000 people in Europe every year. If we don't change, we're going into the wall. Meeting the COP 21 targets would require a 70% reduction in emissions by 2030. There, a 45% reduction is proposed by 2030. This is better than the Commission's proposal, but it is far from enough. What are you telling us? That it's too ambitious. But it's too ambitious for whom? For governments, for the car lobby? I say to you, we European Parliament cannot compromise the climate, the health of our citizens, or the 12 million jobs in the automotive sector in Europe which are already threatened by international competition. Clean mobility is not a threat, but an opportunity for the health and conversion of the automotive sector.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Let me make one thing clear right at the beginning: this is not a question of climate protection, yes or no. All the proposals we will vote on tomorrow will help to achieve our climate targets. The question, however, is: what happens if we try to overshoot the mark once again? In other words, what do the excessive demands of some colleagues mean for consumers, the economy and jobs? The answer is very clear: they would be devastating. The softening of the 45% target from the Committee on the Environment to the 40% target with a binding electric quota will not change this much. The punishment system for zero- and low-emission vehicles alone will cost us dearly. The Commission has calculated what the proposal of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy would mean. The economy would lose EUR 1 450 if a vehicle were sold, every consumer would have to pay EUR 1 000, and 60 000 people would lose their jobs. It is often said here that new jobs might also be created and that people could simply be put into retraining. I have met with the representatives of the trade unions and industry on this, and it is quite clear that thousands of jobs will be lost. We must prevent this. Only in the European Parliament has this news still not got it right. I firmly believe that we can define ambitious objectives, protect the climate and, at the same time, strengthen the competitiveness of our industry and thus safeguard jobs in Europe. We do not need ideology, quota or prohibitions, but openness, innovation and technological neutrality. That would be good for the climate, that would be good for the consumer, and it would also be good for the workers. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has made major concessions in the course of the negotiations. Let us vote in favour of the 35% target tomorrow and reject the penalty system for the e-car quota.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this is an absolutely crucial file and that’s why, Mr Commissioner, we need more ambition than the Commission proposal offers – to make sure that we can get our climate goals, but also to make sure that we can reduce the cost for consumers and improve the air quality in our Member States.  Some, like Mr Gieseke, argue that increased ambition will lead to a loss of jobs. Well, it’s not the case. The Commission’s own impact assessment states that with a 40% reduction, total EU employment will increase by 69 000 to 92 000 jobs. In any case, colleagues, regardless of electrification, if you look at what will go on in the sector on everything that is to do with automation and digitalisation, fundamental changes need to occur in the sector. That’s why I am so proud that, under the leadership of Ms Dalli, there are many issues on just transition within the proposal of the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) that we should all support. What workers should be really be afraid of is that we lose out in the automotive sector; we lose our leadership on technology. Ms Dalli mentioned it already. Why are European car manufacturers making so much effort in China to make electric cars and not do so within Europe? What do we want? To be left with all technology that is killing our people because of the effect on climate and air quality? That’s why we need to have ambition. It’s encouraging to see that not just in the progressive forces in this Parliament, but also in the Council, there’s an increasing amount of membership that wants to improve the targets in this regulation. That’s why I’m really saddened that Ms Merkel, whom I respect a lot and who used to be a climate Chancellor, will now miss her national climate targets by 2020 and 2030 by putting the brakes on this ambitious legislation. So please, let’s vote tomorrow on the ENVI proposal.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Flemish N-VA delegation will vote tomorrow in favour of ambitious standards. We support at least 40% less CO2 and 40% new green cars by 2030. This is indeed essential in the fight against climate change, but also for air quality in our cities and our municipalities. And when you launched your proposal here last year, I did not hide my disappointment here in plenary, and I stand by my position: weak CO2 standards undermine the climate targets. My own Member State must emit 35% less CO2 by 2030. Without the necessary technology to reduce CO2 at source, this will not be possible and we are also fully supporting the demand for a technology-neutral greening of the new fleet. This is an important link in attracting investment, in stimulating innovation and improving air quality. Our citizens have a right to clean air. If the European Union is in the right place to compete with China, then our producers must offer sufficient low-emission and emission-free cars. We should invest in this, not in shoddy software to circumvent the standards. I hope we learned our lesson after dieselgate.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after the COP21 meeting in Paris, we decided that we were going to stand for these principles, and therefore we created a framework which consisted of emissions trading, effort sharing and LUCF. That is the framework. When you speak about effort sharing, we know that effort sharing is also already included in a social manner; that Finland has 39%, Sweden has 40%, Denmark about 40%, and Bulgaria 0%. We took into account the different possibilities of the different countries. That, I think, is fair. What we are now doing is trying to take a further step, and this step, if you look at the figures, is very important. If we fail in transport, then transport will kick back on effort sharing, on agriculture and on the budgets of the Member States if they are not able to reach the goals. That is what we are actually now deciding on; we are deciding on the way in which we will go forward. Therefore, if you look at the figures, transport is the only part of CO2 that is rising. All the other curves are going down, but transport is rising. We have to take measures, and the only way you can take measures is to have clear—cut and ambitious goals; that’s the 40%. We also have to fix all the other things, and remember that when we speak about efforts sharing, it is running until 2030. To be able to look at effort sharing, we need something in between. That is 2025, which is in this year, so there is just one way to go, and that is forward.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you said that the European Commission would work seriously and ambitiously to implement the Paris climate agreement. I have to tell you, I cannot see that. You said only last week that you are not adjusting the European Union's overall climate objective to the Paris Agreement as intended – three years after Paris. The EU Commission has failed to adjust its own climate targets and is heading to Katowice without an adjusted target. It is therefore not at all surprising that you are not ambitious in this important area of legislation that we are discussing today. Their own experts have told them that a CO2 reduction target for the automotive industry must be at least 60% by 2030. They have submitted 30% by 2030. The recommendations of science and the Commission's proposals have never diverged so far during the time when I am co-advising on climate policy.  I must also thank the rapporteur, Mrs Dalli, who has really achieved something good with the compromise we have reached in the Committee on the Environment. However, this compromise must now at least be defended, so that we can see if we want to represent something good from this House in the international debate. The car industry, together with some governments, is on the brakes. This is not surprising, it has a system, as we have often experienced. But the trade unions, Mr Gieseke, are already discussing something differently. We have heard from the trade unions that they know full well that our industry will be left behind in international markets if we do not engage ambitiously and consistently in innovation, climate protection and environmentally friendly cars. The workplace argument has played a very big role all along. And I want to tell you that I have rarely seen in a debate such a manipulative approach to figures as these job losses as in recent weeks. It is outrageous to operate with figures on job losses that would occur if we were to discuss reduction targets such as 80% by 2030. No one has ever discussed this dimension, and yet Mr Gieseke is arguing in this way. Job losses, which will affect industry in the European Union in the foreseeable future, are due to digitisation and increased productivity, as always.  And there is no interference at all from you, Mr Gieseke. Scaremongering about climate protection is what you are doing, and that ultimately leads to The European markets being taken over by Chinese manufacturers.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter LIESE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, Mrs Harms, I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Harms for her excellent work and for the work she has You criticised the Commissioner for not proposing to increase the target of 40%. I was at the climate conference in Bonn last year and systematically asked all the partners we spoke to: is there any debate in the other countries at all – let us leave the United States completely, but in Japan, Russia, South America, Brazil, for example? There is no debate anywhere. And do you not also believe that, before we criticise the Commissioner here, who has already described a way, we should do more to involve other countries in the first place?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure. It was also Commissioner Caete who hailed the Paris Agreement as a great success. If, three years later, we are responsible for the most important legislation that we still have on the table, and if this legislation is not based on what we committed ourselves to in Paris, then I think that is really bad. In addition, when we talk about the car industry, we talk about climate protection technologies that are available. This is the area where we have technology, where we must also advocate innovation and not systematically slow down innovation.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, full support for the position of the ENVI Committee. Here, too, we must bear in mind the burden-sharing: transport must play its part, or else too much weight will be placed on housing and agriculture. We cannot give any freedom to the car industry unless we want to pee on our own climate policy or on the cereal of our children or grandchildren.  Transparency for the car industry led to a diesel scandal, so we must now give a spanking to the car industry so that new processes genuinely move forward. If we want to save hundreds of millions of euros in European health care, we must take this legislation forward. We can also use the money saved for new innovations in the climate, environment and health sectors, which are also creating new work that has been greatly needed here. I would like to say that climate promoters will also create more needed new jobs in their country than those who are constantly opposed.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow's vote is of historic significance. Our choices will shape the future of road transport, which is called upon to play its part against climate change, for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. But not only that, tomorrow we will clarify which car industry we want in Europe, at home, if we remain anchored in the dogma of fossil fuels and if we import clean propulsion technologies and systems from third countries, I am thinking precisely of China where, ironically, European manufacturers themselves are investing much more billions than in Europe. Or, if we want to accompany the automotive sector in that transition towards zero-emission mobility, already invoked, today, by European citizens and companies who denounce the shortage of clean models on the market. Ladies and gentlemen, I will conclude by reminding you that in order to reap the social benefits generated by efficient vehicles, including cleaner air and increasing employment opportunities in the green economy sectors, it is necessary to preserve the balance found in the Committee on the Environment. The 5 Star Movement is on the side of ambition.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is right to aim for an ambitious plan to reduce CO2 emissions from the transport sector, but this plan must have realistic objectives and not lead to an increase in costs for European businesses and citizens. The current proposed targets force the market towards the electric option only. The electric car is not in itself the wrong choice, but the market and technology are not ready. We need an important adaptation of the electricity grid, the creation of many charging points, more efficient alternative solutions for the construction and disposal of batteries and possibly in Europe and not across the border, as is happening at the moment. Despite the important buying incentives, electric cars currently account for only 1.5% of sales and from 2014 to 2017 their market share increased by only 0.9%. Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises also absolutely need more flexibility to implement the new targets. Let us not forget that light commercial vehicles are mainly used by these realities that have already been tried for years of crisis and cannot always afford to invest in the latest generation vehicle.  What is the point of the electric car in environmental terms, if part of the energy to power it, in Europe itself, is still produced from coal-fired power stations? We need a strategy that safeguards the principle of technological neutrality and keeps the way open to a fair mix of technologies, which can really contribute to the reduction of CO2 emissions and to a calculation system that takes into account not only the CO2 emitted by the vehicle, but the overall balance of the vehicle's life cycle.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, I think we all agree that it is necessary to reduce emissions as quickly as possible. We must be very careful, however, if we are trying to correct a problem that we ourselves have created, we will eventually end up in an even worse situation.  I see there's a lot of support for electric cars. Have we really considered what it would mean to have all the cars in circulation today, especially trucks, replaced by electrics by 2050? Have we calculated the huge amounts of electricity that would be needed if this change occurred? How will these quantities of electricity be produced? Certainly not from wind or solar power, as, in order to do so, we would have to set up panels and generators throughout Europe.  Many countries today face energy shortages. It is therefore reasonable to assume that in the future the situation will get even worse. Will car emissions ultimately be replaced by emissions from the power plants?  To sum up, we clearly need to work even further towards reducing emissions. However, this should be done after careful and objective studies in order to minimise the risks that may arise. Above all, these studies must be independent and their results must not be predetermined before they are carried out, just in order to serve political purposes.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It's about driving a car, and I'm in favour of giving gas – giving gas in innovation and giving gas on climate protection. I am against us giving too much gas in this debate. Because if we look at where we come from, we have to take a bit of gas away. We had extreme positions on the table. Mrs Harms, you said that there was never any mention of 80%, but your group has already tabled 75%. That is not so far away from 80%, so really not. We have had Miriam Dalli's proposals: 50%. We have the committee proposal of 45%. And then the independent analysis of the European Commission, which I hold in high esteem, says that we will then have job losses and losses for the economy in Europe. That is why it is good that we are now moving on another piece and that many groups no longer support this 45%. I would also like to ask that we look again at the amendments tabled by the Committee on the Environment on the malus. According to the Commission's analysis, this is once again a burden of around an additional 5%. That is why I would be grateful if the committee's motion did not get through with the 40% benchmark. This is an additional tightening-up, and that is not technology neutral. That is why it would be good if we could also correct this tomorrow. The Commission has calculated that, if we adopt the Commission proposal, this is the contribution of the car industry to achieving our 40% target. We can discuss other figures, and we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are prepared to go higher. But I would like to say again – and Mrs Harms did not reply to this: the debate on doing more than was decided in Paris is not being conducted in any other part of the world. That is why we should not criticise our Commissioner, but he travels the world and initiates this debate in the other countries in the first place. For this we should support Miguel Arias Caete and not criticise him. Thank you, Miguel, Commissioner, for doing this! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure – On the subject of gas: the amendments tabled by your group amount to the fact that bonuses and malus and crediting systems will further weaken the already very weak reduction target for 2030 for conventional drives, so that, in our estimation, conventional drives in 2030 could be worse and more damaging to the climate than today in 2018, on the basis of your proposals. Do they call it the gas when it comes to climate protection?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. So, first of all, we have increased the target to 35%. This should be taken into account, please. And we do not want to weaken the proposal, but we want to support innovation – just as I said. The malus is not provided for in the Commission proposal. That is why we do not want to see it in the final text. This is not technology neutral. The other amendments also aim to promote the plug-in hybrid transition technology. Not everyone can drive an electric car from tomorrow, there needs to be a transition, and we also want to promote it. That is the point.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree that we must set our targets so that the Union achieves its objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. At the same time, it is important to enable and create the framework for European industry to innovate and retain its world leader in this area.  However, we must take into account, first of all, the social aspect, so that this process does not negatively influence employment, and that the targets and objectives we propose are realistic and, at the same time, reflect the real technological and development aspects. The proposals to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by imposing targets on car manufacturers are indeed ambitious, but the question is: are they also realistic? Because we must also take into account the way in which the market relates to the changes we are imposing, to the purchasing power of the citizens of the European Union, but we must not ignore the infrastructure either. I believe that the Commission's proposal to reduce carbon dioxide emissions – which is an ambitious one – can, however, be improved so that, on the one hand, we can achieve environmental objectives and, on the other hand, see what the negative impact is and reduce it on the car industry.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, the automotive sector is undoubtedly the driving force behind European industry. That is why I am very concerned about the objectives presented, which, with their ambitions, are entering the automotive market very brutally. They leave the customer's decision aside and dictate to manufacturers how much they have to sell under penalty and what the product should look like. Beautiful targets are set, but they don't think about how to ensure that enough electricity is available to meet them, which these cars will need.  At the same time, there is a lack of a fundamental technological change in the storage of sufficient electricity, including a truly fast recharging. The solution is not force political gestures with which we have our negative historical experience. A massive strong support for research and development in this area would be more sensible. Only new technologies and innovations in transport can bring about a major turnaround. All the revolutionary technical inventions we use today have gradually been promoted in the free market. They became successful on the market only when not only customers were prepared for them, but also the whole company. If the European Union wants to skip all this, it means that we are going the wrong way in a politically controlled market, against free competition in an open competitive environment.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Mr President, in essence, this debate is about a question: what kind of car will the future consumer prefer? Will it be the high CO2- and NOx—emitting combustion engine vehicle with quite high maintenance costs and very high fuel costs, or a zero—emission car with almost no maintenance costs and very low fuel costs, if any? I think we all know the answer: the good old combustion—engine car that served us so well for 130 years is ready for its well-deserved retirement. That also means that if in Europe we want to build tomorrow’s car, we have to develop it much more quickly than we are doing now. Market forces as we have seen are not sufficient, so the legislator should help. Therefore, highly ambitious CO2 targets are essential for the survival of the European car industry, and that we get climate and clean air for free with that is a wonderful side effect.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, fascinating debate. Maybe just that everyone is aware, as we speak here in the plenary, in Korea people are discussing a report that will be published next week on 1.5 degrees. It will be very clear that our entire economy needs to go to zero emissions by 2050. The Commissioner agrees with that, I even see him nodding.  So that means that all the sectors need to deliver because not every sector can go to zero emissions. To my EPP friends I would say that one of these is agriculture. Once we are going to discuss agriculture I know pretty well the agriculture sector will say, not us. Okay, then we need to do it where it can be done. And the transport sector, within the transport sector, CO2 standards on cars is the most cost—efficient measure we can take now. So we should do that, and even the Commission did some studies on it. One of them was a study which showed that if you go to higher targets, with these being 6% emission reduction annually, then you have the highest societal savings. By the way, the Commission forgot to publish this one right away – later on corrected it, but forgot to publish it. That can happen of course – pure coincidence. Then last week’s non—paper – even that paper showed that with the reduction target that the Committee on the Environment (ENVI) is proposing, 151 000 more jobs will be created. Even that politicised paper of the Commission showed more jobs when you go for higher ambition. So do we want the investments to go into the EU or out of the EU? That’s the decision. Hopefully we will support the ENVI proposal.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen! Tomorrow, we should vote for a 45% reduction in CO2 emissions from cars by 2030 and for a mandatory electric quota with a penalty system. It is a question of stopping the progressive global warming that is threatening the whole of humanity existentially. If we do nothing about global warming, it will soon cost millions of lives. I say to the German parliamentarians of the EPP: stop walking the aisle of Chancellor Merkel and stop believing the lies of the car industry! The German government blocked stricter CO2 rules long enough, specifically in the interests of the German automotive industry. Have you learned nothing from the diesel affair and Chancellor Merkel's lip service? Many citizens are rightly outraged that this House too often acts in the interests of the corporations. And then you are surprised that the people out there are talking about a bought political elite in Brussels? Really, it is time for the EU to pursue consistent climate protection and no longer be a henchman of industry.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, I recognise and fully support all initiatives that aim at improving air quality and life for European citizens. However, I strongly oppose the content of Ms Dalli’s report as, in order to combat climate change, it imposes extreme reductions in emissions standards for new cars and new commercial vehicles in Europe.  I would like to remind colleagues that EU measures to reduce CO2 emissions, even if fully implemented, would have a trivial effect on the Earth’s climate, and even if they are implemented, it is unlikely that other major emitters such as China and India will follow suit. Several global studies have shown that the costs of implementing policies to mitigate climate change significantly exceed any possible benefit.  For this, and several other scientific reasons, my colleagues and I refute anthropogenic climate change, and disagree with the current EU energy and climate policy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am also to some extent amused when a Green party in this House talks about scaremongering in connection with CO2 emissions and climate protection. The scaremongering, I think, is probably more on your side. But let us return to realpolitik. These targets here are unrealistic in terms of real policy. To a certain extent, we are also allowed to drift. We let ourselves be driven by some Greens, but we are also driven by competition outside Europe, which is very massive in our car market. In any case, it is undisputed that we must adapt our car market and, of course, the emissions of motor vehicles to the challenges of the 21st century. To achieve this, we must create framework conditions and create a fair framework. That is our job. Anything else can be done better by the companies themselves.  It is somewhat short-sighted to commit to a battery initiative here. First of all, the electricity comes from the socket, but it is not produced there. That seems to pass you by. And secondly, at the end of the day, there will be a very, very large number of batteries that someone will have to dispose of somewhere. I don't know if you've thought about it, I don't think so. There are also numerous other alternative energy and propulsion options. In the end, I fear that the cost of this whole brimborium will be paid by the consumer again. In Austria, especially in Graz, my own country, one in nine jobs is in the automated sector. Let us not destroy it, let us not destroy it, and let us not listen to the enemies of our own automotive sector.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that this debate is reaching a balance. It started from a not particularly balanced level, I was rapporteur for this file, both in the Committee on Industry, Public Health and Energy and in the Committee on Transport, and I have to say that, during the discussions, there were moments that were described as theatrical and picturesque. I have had colleagues who, compared with the Commission's 30% proposal, which we considered balanced, had the courage to propose targets at 75%, saying that perhaps it was still not much. Today we have reached a point where the future of clean mobility in Europe is finally on the subject, accompanied by the future of European industry. We must discuss as politicians not our obsessions, but how to transfer into this, which is a categorical environmental imperative, the possible industrial challenge that we face.  We have an automotive sector that has made us great in the world and that employs so many of us Europeans, we must create the conditions for those jobs that will be changed as a result of the inevitable change in the structure of mobility to see a new outlet, for example, the issue of batteries has been mentioned, so having a European battery industry will be a major challenge.  These things are done with an appropriate, moderate and competent approach. Those who have to propose themselves in these debates are hurting the European Union. Those who talk about the Union talk about gradual processes accompanied with intelligence and competence. It seems to me that your proposal goes in this direction.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The transport sector must become climate neutral by the middle of the century in order to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement. There is global competition between Asia, America and Europe for the cars of the future, there is no doubt about that. And if you offer the best technologies, you have the best cars, you have the world markets, you have the markets of the future. I want us to continue to produce cars in Europe in the years and decades to come, and I do not want us to have to import these cars from overseas. I believe that, with this legislation, we are shaping the transport of the future in Europe. It will have other types of propulsion, it will become much more environmentally and climate-friendly, and it will also provide new technologies and new jobs. Because there is always talk here of electric cars, I am sure that, as an intermediate step, we will also take hybrid and plug-in cars with us and perhaps also operate car gas and natural gas in the shorter term, which can reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We Social Democrats, of course, have in mind climate protection, but also jobs. We have highly skilled jobs in Europe. This must also be further developed into new productions. And we are also thinking of the companies that may have to make a radical change. That is why we have also proposed a Just Transition Fund so that we can help cities and regions, but also certain companies. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question. You speak about changes being made to the automotive sector and state control and provision to ensure this happens. In your vision of the future, do you see a situation where the countries outside of the EU that may not apply the same rigorous policies as yourself to the climate – are still using petrol and diesel and so on – will EU manufacturers have a loophole where they can manufacture to export to them or will your state control of this clamp down on those exports?

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I am chairman of the China delegation here in this House. I have been observing for years what this great country alone is doing, which has really introduced quotas from year to year and which wants to serve world markets. As has already been mentioned here, South Korea and Japan have been offering hybrid cars for some time, where Europeans are still stuck on diesel. So the legislation we are legislating here, sir, applies to all the cars that come onto our market, which are manufactured here, as well as, of course, to imports. There is no preference for imports over cars produced in Europe.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, I am pleased that the rapporteur is showing more far-reaching ambitions than the Commission has so far shown. I think it is really time for the transport sector to take responsibility and work substantially on a REDUCTION in CO2 and to prevent the back and forth with ambitions between, for example, the transport sector and the agricultural sector, so as to 'who finally takes the real responsibility?' So I think we really need to take a step forward to get rid of fossil fuels and I also see that car manufacturers really want that. Car manufacturers are also thinking about the near future and there is a desire among car manufacturers to take a step towards 0 emission vehicles or at least vehicles that have significantly lower emissions than what we are talking about now. So i think we can get car manufacturers on our side for such a shift and such a change. In short, Mr President, I support the rapporteur's commitment and I think it is good for all of us and also for air quality.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Mr. Speaker, Mr. Commissioner, there are many outstanding issues related to this Regulation. For example, that proposals for emission reduction targets are often not accompanied by appropriate measures that could achieve these targets.  What is the position of this proposal for a regulation across the network of EU laws concerning renewable sources and emissions reductions? Will it be technologically possible to reach these goals in such a short time of five and ten years, respectively? And finally, how much does this cost and how will it affect the competitiveness of the European economy?  I support my ALDE group's compromise proposals of a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions and a 35% share of low- and low-emission vehicles, but I think the Commission's proposal, namely the Opinion of the Transport Committee with a 30% reduction and a 30% share of low- and zero-emission vehicles, is also a step in the right direction.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The EU should be carbon neutral by 2050 in order to limit global warming to a maximum of 2 degrees. Road transport currently accounts for 27% of emissions. At the same time, passenger car traffic is expected to increase by 42 per cent by 2050. It is clear that if we are to live up to the Paris Agreement, we must forcefully reduce emissions from the new cars that come onto the market. At the same time, however, conservative parties seem to believe that strong climate action is hurting the industry, but in reality the opposite is true. It is no coincidence that Tesla is based in California, which not only suffers from climate problems in the form of drought, but also has an ambitious climate policy that in turn breeds innovation and industrial development. In Sweden, for example, we provide long-term investment support for the transition in the energy and industrial sector. We believe this is in favour of industrial development. Like every industry, the car industry also needs clear policy objectives if we are to succeed, and it is policy that must guide and provide strong incentives for green conversion so that we can bring new electric cars to market. Now is the time – now it is up to the evidence – for the Conservative parties that claim that the EU should act in the field of climate change to show that they are serious about keeping their promises. We can no longer lag behind. Now is the time for europe to lead.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Miriam Dalli, on the report before us, which sets ambitious targets for reducing CO2 emissions from new vehicles. We therefore welcome these proposals, as they will play a decisive role in our fight against climate change and for the protection of the environment.  Particularly positive is the proposal being put forward to harness technology and measure car emissions in real road conditions in order to avoid future scandals with car manufacturers, such as the dieselgate scandal.  It is equally important that appropriate measures are taken in good time to deal with the impact on employment. We therefore support the proposal to promote targeted programmes, retrain and upgrade workers' skills in order to maintain quality and decent jobs.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Mr President, I think we agree that co2 emissions in the transport sector must be drastically reduced. We have endorsed the Paris climate agreement and I think we must now keep our promises. That is why the 30% reduction proposed by the Commission is an absolute minimum. And we, as a group, are prepared to go beyond that, to increase that ambition considerably. We need to get the warming under control. We don't have a choice. But in the meantime, ladies and gentlemen, of course, we must drive and look back, as it is called. In other words, ensuring that the price of cars does not rise too quickly, because that would of course backfire. And as Mr Leinen rightly pointed out, ensuring that the negative effects on employment are also taken into account, that they are limited. In short, ladies and gentlemen, a more ambitious reduction would be a very good thing to send the signal, including to other continents, that we want to take action and also to continue to take the lead on this climate problem. I would therefore assume that this is feasible, that this is reasonable and that we can reach a good agreement on this in the short term, Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is not difficult to live up to or bask in the glory of climate agreements if you do not intend to live up to them. It is therefore now in the legislative process that it is up to the parties and politicians who really stand for ambition. Passenger and vans currently account for up to one fifth of Europe's total CO2 emissions. Climate emissions must be reduced in all sectors of society if we are to achieve both the EU and the Paris Agreement's climate objectives. That is why this regulatory framework is one of the most important climate legislation for the EU at the moment. Sweden is one of the countries in the world that is most dependent in the national economy by the automotive industry. In fact, we have the most employees in this industry per capita. We know how important it is to create the right conditions for a viable and greener car industry, both today and in the future. That is precisely why the Swedish position of social democrats, both here and in the Council, has been a high ambition. We are pushing to give a clear signal to the market that it pays to invest in climate-smart vehicles and take the lead in development. Everything else – low ambitions – is actually a dead end for the car industry. You end up in the backwater of global competition, and I do not want to see the European car industry there either. For tomorrow, we have a good and possible vote with a good report, for which I would like to commend the rapporteur, Miriam Dalli. It is important to vote for ambition tomorrow. It's up to the evidence.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is common ground that the European Union is to make a major contribution to reducing overall emissions and combating climate change. But we cannot proceed recklessly in this fight, with the bath spilled and the child. Our targets for the automotive industry, which employs 13 million Europeans, must be realistic and feasible. We must not allow this traditional sector to lose its competitiveness in global markets. Let us encourage innovation, let us give the green light to all new technologies that use fossil-free fuels, but let us not over-requirements and do not put our efforts in just one direction. A direction that could make car manufacturers a scapegoat, albeit for the sake of surely noble goals.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, since you don't see things the same if you come from a country that produces cars or not, I'm going to talk about Spain.  Spain is the second largest passenger car manufacturer and the first commercial vehicle manufacturer in Europe and, speaking of figures, has seventeen car factories plus the supplier industry, contributes to the trade balance with 10% of GDP and is the most important in export with more than 34 billion euros.  Moreover, from 2005 to date, no other sector has made environmental progress or similar investments to do so, such as the automotive sector.  The levels of reduction being raised by the European Commission are already very ambitious. For this reason, it seems disproportionate that even higher levels of reduction are being discussed that far exceed the strategic framework.  Of course, the sale of zero-emission vehicles must be encouraged, but the high price of vehicles and the lack of recharging infrastructure means that the percentage of sales of these vehicles is very low: we are around 1%, according to 2017 data.  In this regard, the system for incentivising zero- and low-emission vehicles proposed by the Commission is positive. However, the establishment of a malus penalty system, as approved by the Committee on the Environment, is neither appropriate nor in accordance with the principle of technological neutrality.  I believe that the 35% reduction by 2030, as proposed by the EPP, together with a number of flexibilities, is an ambitious and reasonable position.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, I would like to pay tribute to my good colleague, Ms Miriam Dalli, for her excellent work on this because it is very, very important that Parliament sends an extremely clear signal to the Commission that we want the highest ambition when it comes to CO2 emissions from cars.  We have to get real. I listened with interest to the previous speaker saying that ambition has basically reached the point that it needs to. We have to get real about where this transition is going. It is inevitable that zero emissions transport will be the solution to the problems we face, not just on climate but also, of course, on air quality. At the moment our own car manufacturers here in the EU are investing seven times more in China than they are doing in production here when it comes to electric vehicles. If we decide to carry on with business as usual, if we decide to carry on with existing technology, we will effectively destroy our own domestic car industry.  Let me be clear, I am talking from a position where my own car industry is coming under existential threat in the form of Brexit, but of course when it comes to legislation on CO2 the targets that we are talking about are not unachievable. Under a 40% reduction, we are looking at 10% penetration for electric vehicles across the EU – 10%. Are we really saying that 9 in 10 cars in 2030 will still be petrol and diesel driven and that this would somehow represent a success?  We have to be real. We have to go for the highest ambition because this is good not just for the environment but for consumers and our own industry and jobs.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. All countries have signed the Paris climate targets, and now, in principle, all countries must implement them. We know that CO2 emissions in the transport sector have been constantly growing, even though we have already had reduction targets. Now, as you can see in the debate, the countries that produce cars are finding it heavier than those that do not produce cars. This is perhaps in the nature of the matter, and this will probably be reflected in the Council. It is about jobs. Right. The fact is that many people say that diesel needs more jobs than e-mobility. Of course, this is also about competition with China. We do not want to lose jobs because the cars are now produced in China. We have an infrastructure for alternative energies under construction. Far too slow from my point of view. After all, if we had this more quickly, we would have a technological neutrality as we want it, much stronger and much more likely on the streets. I am against the malus system, I do not think that is a good thing. Basically, it should be said, since we have noticed that the objectives we have are of no use if more and more cars come, it would be best to have strict emissions trading for the whole sector. Unfortunately, this is not up for debate, but that would perhaps help us.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I think there is one word in this debate that is unspeakable, namely 'trust'. Trust us as parliamentarians, but also as customers, in industry. I think that here this case of "Dieselgate" is constantly echoing so badly. Care must be taken of the environment and climate, and incentives should be created for the production and use of low- and zero-emission cars. I believe that environmental objectives can also be reconciled with jobs and economic growth. This applies not only to manufacturers, but to the wider automotive sector, a large part of which is made up of small and medium-sized enterprises – and we should not forget them.  We have a dilemma here as to whether the proposed reduction target of 35-40% will maintain such synergies? I don't think that's the main thing. The most important thing is our will that we want to do it. The most effective solutions are those which are widely accepted not so much by producers, but above all by consumers, also by the wealth of their portfolios. Too high a reduction rate can raise such a price too rigorously, and as a result, it can, in countries where there are lower incomes, temporarily even increase CO2 emissions, because there will be no money to buy new, relatively more expensive cars. I think we all agree that electric cars are the most energy efficient. But on the other hand, let's not say that other technologies are worse. Hydrogen, biogas – I think, especially in the next generations – the second, third and fourth generations – should also be accepted.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Today, the Danish Government has proposed that by 2030 we in Denmark will completely stop the sale of petrol and diesel cars. Look it's ambitious! So when I listen to the debate this evening, I think it is a pity that some people think that a 45% reduction target for CO2 emissions by 2030 is too ambitious. We need to ensure that we comply with the Paris Agreement on climate change, and we cannot do that without the transport sector contributing. We have to be ambitious. And we must also be ambitious, because if we do not make demands on our own car industry, we will be overtaken by industries elsewhere in the world. The most ambitious thing is to make demands. It is ambitious to call for a 45% reduction. I fully support the approach of the Committee on the Environment in this area.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: – Mr President, as a CDA, we want co2 emissions from passenger cars and vans to fall significantly by 2030. All sectors must contribute to the goals of the Paris Agreement. The sacred cow, the wagon of people, must also contribute to the achievement of these climate goals, just as this house also demands great sacrifices from agriculture, the common cow. Climate innovation provides additional opportunities and jobs for the automotive sector and other high-tech companies in Europe. Economic growth and sensible, ambitious climate targets simply go hand in hand. More ambition, combined with the sealing of loopholes in legislation, will strengthen the strength of our European automotive sector. More ambition will create more jobs for the European economy, both for car makers and for innovative companies in the field of electric car mobility and hydrogen production. More ambition also means less dependence on oil dictatorships and cleaner air in cities. European manufacturers are already investing heavily in electric car production in China. Let's not be left behind. All sectors must contribute: construction, industry, agriculture and certainly the transport sector, without loopholes. It would not be good if the transport sector would emit even more as it does now by 2030. That is why, of course, tomorrow, together with the entire CDA group, I am voting in favour of my 40% amendment to the ENVI Committee, which we tabled together with Peter Liese and Karl-Heinz Florenz.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is moving towards a new model of development, a low-carbon economy. This is the challenge, while today the transport sector is still 94% dependent on oil and is responsible for more than 25% of greenhouse gas emissions. The aim of this regulation is to have cars on the road that are less polluting and consume less fuel for the benefit of the health and pockets of European citizens, as well as the environment. But it is not enough to set new and ambitious targets for reducing car emissions, it is important to ensure that the emissions certified on paper match the real ones. I therefore agree with the article of the regulation which proposes the introduction of a test of emissions under real road driving conditions, in order to avoid new scandals such as dieselgate. An analysis of emissions over the entire life cycle of vehicles is also essential, as proposed. It is not enough to measure pollutants only at the mlys, at the discharge during the years of operation, but also consider the stages of production and disposal.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Stricter and more binding CO2 targets are needed. The Commission's proposal sets the direction for more environmental protection, at 30%. But we should leave the church in the village, that is, keep the car industry in Europe. Firstly, 45 or even 50% by 2030 is utopia. This will destroy jobs tens of thousands of times across Europe. And a narrow vote by the European Parliament, with these unrealistic targets and without an impact assessment, weakens us in relation to the Council. A European Parliament that enters into negotiations in this way without using its own opportunities for impact assessment will not be taken seriously in the trialogue. We have noticed this on a repeated occasions. I wonder why the Reds, the Greens and the Yellows here in Parliament do not accept Parliament's impact assessment. My second point is that the introduction of an electric quota through the back door is a dangerous self-limitation. Instead of letting the market act, left-wing politics wants to set a technical direction, and once again without an impact assessment. Sufficient charging infrastructure - question mark. Disposal - question mark. Rare Earths - Question Mark. Apparently foreign words for many in the ALDE, in the S&D and among the Greens, according to the motto: why a market economy, when it goes through the wall with your head? Responsible environmental policy means, thinking from the end, analysing the consequences of legislation in detail. Ideology must not be a compass of politics. Let us therefore work together again on a compromise.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our objectives are clear, by 2030 minus 45% CO2 emissions, plus 40% of zero-emission or low-environmental cars, in order to achieve the Paris targets, to protect our health, to make the European car industry more competitive. For us Socialists and Democrats, in this phase of transition of industrial conversion, it is essential that it is not workers and technicians who foot the bill. Major changes are taking place in the world automotive sector. Europe cannot stand still, it can and must become a world leader in the production of electric cars, low-emission hybrid cars. Without courage and ambition, Europe will lose the global challenge in the automotive sector and we will have more pollution and less employment. With the proposals voted for by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we will have a regulation that brings together development, work and environmental quality.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your support I represent a country that has always supported the predictable development of emission requirements, but also sees economic factors such as car factories as strategic partners. That's what you need to figure out.  As a member of the Committee on the Environment, I have no doubt that 0 and low emission vehicles are the future, but it is also important to pay attention to international and global processes and not just to our own EU climate targets. The implementation of the Paris Agreement is a priority, but the Eu, which is responsible for around 10% of global emissions, cannot and cannot do so alone.  Excessive ambition by the EU does not result in reaching 1.5°C on its own. In the US, emissions from the transport sector are double that of the EU, while in some countries around the world this figure is increasing by hundreds of per cent.  In order to preserve the Competitiveness of the Union, we must set targets that are realistically amenable to car manufacturers but which reduce pollution within a reasonable framework.  The EU car industry currently faces a number of expectations, such as transatlantic barriers to trade, digitisation and decarbonisation. Impossible! Anyone knows, everyone who knows how to do it, that it is impossible for manufacturers to adapt technologically to 40% emission reduction targets. The emission reduction target must be set in such a way as to encourage car manufacturers and not impose additional burdens on them.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, we need to meet the objective of carbon neutrality in 2050 and improve the quality of life of citizens now. How the European institutions, national governments and the automotive industry can deal with the emissions challenge will be a barometer of their ability to take the technological and economic lead in a sector that our competitors are fighting hard for. European industry must be an ally of the energy transition if it wants to be globally competitive. It is not wise to counter environmental targets to the competitiveness of industry and its ability to maintain and create sustainable jobs. In fact, if European industry does not adapt to new environmental challenges, it can survive in the short term, but it is doomed. On the other hand, if you take the time to lead the transition to new industrial models and respond to new mobility systems, you will ensure their long-term survival and competitiveness, creating wealth, employment and better environmental conditions.  This Regulation makes a contribution to this. I welcome the rapporteur for her excellent work and I hope that this will be a key and positive change for the European car industry.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, the fight against climate change is not an option. It's an obligation. And, therefore, reducing emissions in a sector that produces a quarter in the European Union is also an obligation. And we have to find the right balance between the industry that generates economic activity and employment – in countries like Spain, very important – and the obligation of this reduction in emissions. That's the debate we have to produce. And we need to invite industry to make the necessary technological changes to maintain leadership in European production and industry as well. Why? Because we're talking about the future. We're talking about our health. And, therefore, making these technological changes will also mean maintaining in the medium and long term that future and that activity. We therefore have to comply with Paris and we have to pursue an ambitious reduction in emissions.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have always believed in the need to preserve jobs while ensuring the improvement of the quality of the environment. Because there is no fight against climate change if you fight the industry, behind the back of the industry or without the industry. As there can no longer be room for an industry that does not firmly contemplate that the road is a low-emissions economy, or I would say more, a dephosylized economy. In this sense, there is no hierarchy between survival of the planet and job creation. Let us trust european industry and society, which is carrying out a new industrial revolution by transforming the European economy into a low-emissions economy. This is already happening.  Let us trust in European society, which is on the path of meeting the objectives of Paris under the leadership of the European Commission. And yes, of course, we have to be ambitious, of course we do, but without endangering any workplaces. That we don't believe them here, that they are created by the industry. I'm done, President. Few of us, I believe, are automotive engineers and, in any case, today, we are Members. Our task as legislators is not to act as engineers but to set goals and ensure technological neutrality that frees engineers to advance the technological transition in the most coherent way possible. If we do not do so, we will only be making progress on paper, and we want to move forward in reality, as the Commission's proposal does.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, we’ve just had the latest news from the Trump administration in the USA: a forecast that the climate is going to warm up by four degrees, and the result is ‘we are not going to do anything’. We are going to have the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report within one week. That will tell us how drastically different the world would be with the warming up of two degrees that we have already caught up with, without even talking about the future. If you refer to science, CO2 emissions should be reduced by more than 50% in new cars, maybe 70%. We should make a drastic change to electric cars and new ways of moving. So this is a wake-up call. How seriously we are taking climate change is an issue. It is not adequate that we talk about the Paris Agreement. It is not adequate that the Commission is coming up with new plans and commitments for 2030. It is a question of what we are doing here in Parliament and the Council right now and in different pieces of legislation. This is one of the key pieces of legislation, so I appeal for us to go for at least a 45% reduction in CO2 emissions from cars.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the No one is questioning the need for action on climate change. I must admit, however, that Mrs Dalli's report causes me quite a lot of stomach pains. Luxembourg is one of the two Member States to have to meet the highest reduction targets in the non-ETS sectors by 2030. We are talking about minus 40%. Passive houses are already standard in the construction sector in Luxembourg. In the agricultural sector, too, we are at the forefront of agri-environmental measures. The transport sector accounts for 64% of non-ETS emissions. So I cannot avoid calling for a more ambitious target than the 30% set by the Commission. What makes sense in the short term does not have to be right in the long term. Some in this House are calling for a reduction target of minus 50% or more. The only way to achieve this goal would be to switch to electromobility. But where does this electricity come from? 25% of electricity comes from coal, 24% from nuclear energy, and that certainly explains why the electricity giants that rely on nuclear power are trying to influence us massively. We certainly do not want to roll out a new red carpet here in order to give new opportunities to coal and nuclear power. In any case, we want to have a technology-neutral discussion here. Like my colleagues Belet, Leinen and Pieper, I call for us to give alternative hybrid vehicles a chance. There is a myopia that can be corrected by glasses. Let's make this mistake ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, I need to ask you all to respect your time slots. We are running behind and will have to catch up, and we also have the catch—the—eye procedure, so please respect the time that has been allocated to you.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much for the floor, I will save a little time. Contrary to the fact that we have done so, I would like to thank our shadow rapporteur, Mr Gieseke, for pulling the sharp teeth at Mrs Dalli's report. In my opinion, the Commission's proposal was already committed and well-founded. As I have already said, the unrealistic figures that have been thrown into the conversation are unrealistic. The biggest problem, in my opinion, is that we have not taken the citizens along with us. We cannot explain outside why we are discussing 30%, 40%, 50% to 80% here in this Chamber. I believe that we must take a different approach. In my opinion, electromobility is not the philosopher's stone, it is not the only stone of the wise. I believe that we must also think very hard about other forms of propulsion, fuel cells and synthetic fuels. As a small example, electric mobility is 0.7% of cars sold, and SUVs over 23%. So where is the will of the citizen? I believe that we must look at this so that we can really achieve the climate objective, which is so important, together.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, there has been a fierce dispute over the last few weeks about how much can be demanded of the car industry. It is quite clear that the car industry must play its part in reducing emissions. Europe must become a pioneer in clean transport. But we still have to remember that the car industry alone cannot solve this, especially when we talk about issues that will come into force in decades' time. We must be able to cut transport emissions much more quickly.  At present, more than a quarter of Europe's emissions come from transport. We know that, according to the forecast, traffic volumes will only increase and transport emissions will be the only sector where emissions have also increased throughout Europe over the decades. In other things, the challenge is very big and requires much more than just solutions from the car industry. The fastest way to cut emissions is to use renewable sustainable fuels in cars that are already in existence, because it will take decades for the car fleet to reinsert.  What I do not like about this proposal is that it drives electric cars so strongly. Electrification will play a very big role in the future and already especially in cities, but at the moment the production of electric cars is not sustainable either. We know that there are many environmental problems in the extraction and battery production of battery metals, which also need to be resolved. In other ways, the fact that we want to cut emissions in Europe and in the world is very important, but it requires many measures. This is only one part of it, but of course it's important.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Miriam Dalli, first of all, for her excellent work. In Paris, we are committed to cutting 40% of total greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990. By 2015, all sectors had reduced their emissions, except for the transport sector, which, on the contrary, rose by 20%. In 2015, road transport alone accounted for 72% of emissions, 44% of which came from light vehicles. The decarbonisation of transport is urgent, and let us not forget that self-regulation was ineffective and state control has been insufficient for a sector where emissions results have even been forged. Moreover, the persistence in investment in combustion engines has made the European automotive economy less competitive in an international framework of electrification of the sector. The industry needs a clear signal that it cannot do "business as usual". To meet these objectives, more stringent measures are needed, such as the promotion of zero-emission vehicles to the detriment of fossil fuel vehicles, the measurement of emissions under real conditions and awareness of responsible consumption, as well as incentives for shared mobility in cities.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I had the privilege of representing Parliament, along with others, at COP21, and I remember that prior to that we were drafting a resolution, and finally we came to agreement with Peter Liese here, Karl-Heinz Florenz and Jerzy Buzek to add once sentence. We were in favour of increased ambition, provided other countries did the same, and we got the agreement in Paris – a global problem going to be solved globally.  That brings me to the point made by my colleague, Peter.
