I’m all in favour of pushing the car industry, and indeed every other industry, as far as we can in terms of reducing emissions, but not to push them over the edge. In other words, we do not want job losses, we do not want carbon leakage, but at the same time, we do not want to listen to them either saying they can’t do anything. So we have a very important role here to try and find what is the maximum attainable in the interests of the environment and in the interests of jobs.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very much in favour of us setting realistic targets and determining what emissions can be achieved in passenger cars and small commercial vehicles. We have currently registered and run 250 million cars in the European Union. If we consider that they emit 100 grams of CO2 per kilometre at a mileage of 40 000 kilometres, we are extrapolating that, then we are at a total of one billion tonnes of CO2. We want to reduce 300 or 350 million tonnes of CO2 over a 12-year period. For the time being, it only applies to new vehicles. But the fleet will have to renew itself within these twelve years. In other words, we need new combustion engines that consume three and a half or four litres of fossil fuels. We really also need new dimensions in electromobility. That is what we must achieve. In the end, I do not want to stand there and say: yes, unfortunately, it was all too ambitious and did not work. Then we will .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the transport sector is the only one that continues to see an increase in greenhouse gas emissions. According to the WHO, air pollution kills 7 million people every year and 9 out of 10 citizens in the world breathe air with very high levels of pollutants. The black jersey of Europe is Italy, where smog causes 91 000 deaths a year. The new regulation aimed at reducing CO2 emissions from light vehicles addresses the environmental and industrial issue, to reduce pollution through the transition to electric modes of transport and to ensure the competitiveness of the European car industry. I agree with the rapporteur, Mrs Dalli, whom I thank, we must be ambitious. We need a common strategic framework for vehicles, infrastructure, electricity grids, the production, supply and recycling of sustainable batteries in which economic incentives and employment incentives go hand in hand at national, EU, regional and local level.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I think that the debate that has been going on for too long has highlighted the main problems that we are seeing. There are the ambitious targets, the 2030 climate targets, with commitments in practice, with an effort to reduce emissions. There is, of course, an opportunity to strengthen the green economy, to have environmental protection and at the same time to invest.  The transport sector, as has been said, accounts for at least 20 % of carbon dioxide emissions. Serious action must be taken. The solution of electric cars is important, although of course too much investment needs to be made, especially in the areas of batteries. This does not mean, of course, that this will overcome all the problems. On the other hand, account should also be taken of the difficulties that will arise in European industry and, at the same time, that not all lorries can be replaced. There's going to be a lot of cost for micro-owners, too.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President, therefore, the Paris Agreement must not only be a set of commitments that will never materialise, and that is what we all, including the European Union, are responsible for. Polluted air kills millions of people worldwide, Europe is no exception here, and that is why we need radical and harsh measures. And the car industry also carries its own share. In doing so, I am convinced that measures that could be much more ambitious can reduce CO2 in the air, but this will also mean restructuring the car industry and finding new alternatives to oil, petrol, including electric vehicles and other forms of energy. And we must not, of course, seek compromise here, because there are no compromises in health, of course, and that is why we must be very determined and unwavering in doing so. And above all, the fact that we also have to protect the consumer and not mislead him here is what we often do.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: – Mr. Chairman, here is the second Green in a row that talks about this issue, but first I want to congratulate my colleague Dalla on an excellent report and I want to present a few facts because the discussion here is very interesting, so I think it will be interesting to you and Mr. Commissioner.  When it comes to innovation, Europe was the first in which an electric car was invented and manufactured, and in which batteries for electric cars were produced. When we look at today, we see that we are actually lagging behind our global competitives and we will lag even further behind if the money we have invested so far in innovation through Horizon 2020, what we will invest through Horizon Europe and is foreseen through other European funds.  How many billions has the European Union's automotive industry invested so far in innovation as far as electric cars are concerned, and we don't see that as a result on our roads? If we are talking about an alternative fuels directive, only eight Member States implemented the policy they needed under the directive it prescribes.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the management of innovation and the pace of large-scale application of new technologies must have as decisive factors the defence of the public interest, the improvement of the quality of life of the population and the environmental preservation. So too is the emissions of cars. We are advocating in this, as in other areas, a normative approach, as operifiable to market approaches, which have shown that they do not protect the interests I have mentioned. Public policies should frame this approach with strategies for defending and promoting employment, particularly in industrial sectors, combating existing imbalances and asymmetries and the predatory logic of multinationals. But it is important not to forget something very important: as much as they want to deceive the heralds of green capitalism, the current paradigm of the use of the individual automobile, the insane protagonism that has acquired especially in cities, is unsustainable and must be questioned, complaining of a new and reinforced centrality for public transport, a reality that even the myrific electric car can not change.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the construction of new passenger and light commercial vehicles with high-end engines, in order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and protect the environment, can be achieved. Zero carbon dioxide emissions are certainly ideal, but we must wait for this to be possible.  An intermediate solution will be the production of high-end fuels that limit air pollutants. The dream of many, which is the electric vehicle, at the moment is bound by many limitations, e.g. the availability of electricity, accumulators, charging positions and so on. We must focus on not transferring production costs to the consumer, not to lose jobs and at the same time not to buy European industries from Chinese.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the debate today and I have heard a broad range of positions, in particular on the level of ambition, and that is also the situation in the debates that have taken place in the Council. The transition to zero-emission mobility needs to happen during the next decades. However, this transition should happen at the right pace to allow sufficient time for the re-skilling of workers in the supply chain. And a smooth transition is particularly important for the many small and medium-sized enterprises operating in this sector, which are the backbone of the economy in many regions. Some Members addressed the issue of the introduction of a malus in the zero and low—emission vehicles incentive mechanism, in particular Mr Liese and Ms Ayuso. The Commission proposal contains a new mechanism incentivising manufacturers to put more zero and low—emission vehicles on the European Union market. It leaves manufacturers the choice as to how they compose their fleet but provides this benefit for those choosing to go for zero and low—emission vehicles. Adding a malus would mean that manufacturers meeting their CO2 targets could actually be penalised if they do not meet the benchmark, and analyses also show that the economic impacts depend on the combination of the target level and a possible bonus/malus benchmark for zero-emission or low-emission vehicles. With the increased penetration of zero and low—emission vehicles, driven by the high bonus/malus benchmark level, less effort will be needed in improving the efficiency of conventional vehicles to meet the fleet-wide CO2 targets. And this results in a projected shift towards larger segments for conventional vehicles, leading to an increase in the net economic costs for consumers. Some Members commented on the non-paper on assessment of higher ambition levels, produced by the Commission, and my friend Bas Eickhout actually said it was a political document. Well, I would point out that the Commission services have not manipulated any calculations and are not misleading the co—legislator: the non—paper clearly and objectively presents the results of recent analytical work and it aims to inform the ongoing decision-making process on the impact of options not considered in the impact assessments. The non—paper’s analysis is therefore only factual. It is fully transparent and based on the same methodological approach: as in the impact assessments, we provided all the necessary underlying background. In particular, the non—paper confirms that the only impact on jobs up to 2030 is positive for more ambitious scenarios. However, it also points to the fact that the transition towards zero-emission mobility will lead to differences between sectors. While overall employment increases with the level of ambition, existing jobs in the automotive sector related to the combustion engine risk being lost if the transition is too fast. The non-paper also confirms the key role of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles in this respect, allowing a transition to zero-emission vehicles while limiting automotive job impacts. In conclusion, I want to thank all of you for the very interesting debate tonight and I am looking forward to tomorrow’s vote. I am also confident that the Council and the leadership of the Austrian Presidency will be able to reach an agreement on a general approach at the Environment Council next week and that a final positive political agreement among the co—legislators can be found before the end of the year.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you Commissioner. We are all looking forward to the vote tomorrow. Madam rapporteur, Ms Dalli, your closing remarks.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, there is one statement by a Member from the EPP that will remain imprinted in my mind tonight, saying that we need to take the venom out of the Dalli report. Seriously, is this the level of the debate about such important legislation? What I heard tonight is not necessarily always based on fact. To the MEPs who think that by going low on ambition they are doing the industry a favour, I ask you to look at what is going on around you. See what is happening in Japan, see what is happening in China, see what our cities are doing, and see what our governments are doing. Case in point: the Danish Government is saying that it will ban gasoline and diesel cars by 2030. This is what is happening at this point in time, and not all EPP Members necessarily agree with this or are happy with this, but to come here tonight and say that having ambition going to 40% will be devastating really shows how much some people are out of touch. I will refer colleagues to what the chief of a major trade union in Germany said: that 40% is achievable. He said that infrastructure needs to move forward, and that is something we agree upon and that we also addressed in the environment position. We also heard about the push towards one technology over the other. It is not true. If we are speaking about a 40% CO2 reduction, let’s be factual with people. We are talking about a 10% battery electric vehicle market share by 2030. It does not mean that we are going towards battery electric vehicles overnight. It means that there will be a large share of efficient internal combustion engines and a large share of plug-in hybrids, which are labour—intensive and which require more employees across the European Union. So yes, I urge colleagues to be united, at least on a 20% CO2 reduction by 2025 and a 40% CO2 reduction by 2030.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 3 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – The emissions scandals of car manufacturers in recent years have significantly undermined consumer confidence, which is currently difficult to regain. The greening of the automotive industry, given its importance in European countries, is a key means of meeting existing environmental objectives. This has to do with the development of a low-carbon economy and further increasing the competitiveness of European carmakers. There is also a need to support effective development for battery and fuel cell technologies. This is part of a comprehensive approach where, in addition to reducing emissions produced, it is essential to focus on limiting the use of heavy metals, especially lead. With a stronger focus on the use of electric cars or other alternative drives, a gradual shift from dependence on imported oil towards electricity produced on the domestic market is expected in the future. This should help to further economic growth and increase employment in the electricity generation and supply sector.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Cars are the final link in the energy flow chain from primary to useful kinetic energy. Therefore, their harmful effects on the environment should be measured by a comprehensive efficiency indicator, calculated as the ratio of the effectiveness of the various links in this chain. A comprehensive estimate of the efficiency of vehicles with internal combustion engines is the production of fuels in refineries (petrol or oil) from crude oil with an energy efficiency equal to, on average, about 50%, and then used in vehicles with efficiency for mechanical propulsion, i.e. about 20%, which gives a final efficiency of about 10%. In the case of electric motor vehicle propulsion, we can come out with about 40% of the energy efficiency of electricity generation in the energy chain and about 80% of the energy efficiency of its use, which will estimate the final efficiency of the vehicle at about 30%. As you can see, the energy efficiency of "electricians" here would be about three times higher than the energy efficiency of internal combustion vehicles. Assuming that a 1% efficiency increase is about a two% reduction in CO2 emissions, we can see that a complete transition to electro-mobility would result in a reduction in CO2 emissions of around 40%. However, the transition to electro-mobility involves a number of difficulties to overcome. The capacity of power plants should be significantly increased and new power plants built. There will still be problems with the accumulation of electricity. However, I believe that in the near future hybrids will be the basis for new market solutions.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – It is a well-known fact that greenhouse gas emissions continue to grow in the EU transport sector. At the same time, in order to preserve the European Union's commitments under the Paris Agreement on climate change, it is essential to reduce emissions values at EU level and to facilitate the spread of clean-fuel vehicles. At the same time, I believe that the decarbonisation of the economy must be achieved in such a way as to ensure the competitiveness of the European automotive industry. Furthermore, the shift away from dependence on oil imports can lead not only to a shift to electricity, but also to an increase in domestic employment.  The provisions on new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles the proposal to reduce CO2 emissions sets out more stringent emission requirements than previous targets, which would reduce CO2 emissions from new cars by 40% by 2030, and to increase the market share of zero- and low-emission vehicles to 20% for new and vans by 2025 and 35% by 2030. In the light of what has been said, I fully support this ambitious proposal.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – It is paradoxical to discuss whether the industry should reduce by 30, 40 or 45% of new car emissions as of 2021, when the reality is that in China there are nearly 500 electric car manufacturers and 9 of them each produce more than the 7,000 vehicles per week that Tesla manufactures, or when the Indian government has 100% of new electric vehicles on its agenda by 2030 , which will save you more than US$60 billion in oil imports and 1,200,000 fewer deaths from pollution, and that is without the huge health costs involved. For our part, in Europe we are absurdly discussing percentages without any ambition, while industry is again caught in fraganti manipulating emissions, but this time upwards so that, as if by magic, emissions would be reduced beyond 2021 following the imposition of the regulations we are debating today. The European car industry has an eye blindfold, or rather a polluting smokescreen, which does not show that other economies are betting on the electric vehicle, at the risk of making them disappear or, rather, relocate.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. There is an urgent need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions in all areas, but particularly in transport, where CO2 emissions have continued to rise over the past 30 years. The Earth is suffocating, it is too hot: we cannot afford the luxury of waiting until 2030 to effectively reduce CO2 emissions from cars and vans! We must have a strong ambition, which comes into effect as early as 2025, with an incentive to go to the least emitting vehicles, but also discourage those who choose to remain confined to thermal engines, polluting and less competitive. Europe has everything to gain by investing in innovation, to remain competitive, and to create new jobs, otherwise it will be overwhelmed by international competition - because Asian manufacturers, for example, do not hesitate to make the technological shift. If we begin the transition now, we will be able to do so gradually, to accompany the transformation of the affected territories, and to ensure the maintenance of employment. In five years, it will be too late, today we must begin the transition to clean mobility, all over Europe!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Jeppe Kofod, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on harmonising and simplifying certain rules in the VAT system (COM(2017)0569 – C8-0363/2018 – 2017/0251(CNS)) (A8-0280/2018); and - the report by Tibor Szanyi, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on rates of value added tax (COM)(2018)0020 – C8-0023/2018 – 2018/0005 (CNS)) (A8-0279/2018).

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Mr Commissioner, we politicians are often, and sometimes deservedly so, criticised for being all talk and no action. When it comes to the supposedly temporary system for cross-border VAT in Europe, that criticism has surely been warranted. For 25 years, nothing really happened. Think about that: a quarter of a century has gone by with a patchwork of a system for cross-border VAT in Europe, full of loopholes, mismatches between 28 different systems of VAT and outright black holes where even authorities didn’t know how to accurately assess VAT dues. This system of compromises upon compromises and patchwork upon patchwork has been a contributing factor to the growing VAT gap in Europe. The problem has now reached a shocking and completely unacceptable scale, with an annual VAT gap of around EUR 150 billion every single year. Now VAT is of course short for value—added tax, but today I would propose that VAT might also be short for value—added talk, because now apparently the right politicians have started talking to each other and action has indeed followed. Commissioner Moscovici has spearheaded a much—needed reform of the EU VAT system, and we have had many constructive and productive talks with the Commissioner and his team. In these talks, we have found workable solutions to a range of specific problems with the current VAT model in Europe. Now, with the adoption of these new measures, as proposed by the Commission and amended by Parliament, we can reduce the current VAT gap in Europe by upwards of EUR 41 billion a year, and at the same time ease the administrative burden for trusted companies who pay their fair taxes by an additional EUR 1 billion a year. Now that is only the start, we have some way to go, but it’s an ambitious and highly effective start. First of all, we will establish the legal cornerstone for a new and defined EU VAT system. Secondly, we will be adopting a number of urgently needed quick fixes to the current VAT system. And finally, we will introduce a new safeguard against cross—border VAT fraud in the form of certified taxable person status. However, before a definitive new VAT system can be put in place, we need to address a number of urgent problems in the current system. These come in the form of four so—called quick fixes and will resolve long—standing issues related to the so-called call—off stock arrangements, where goods from one supplier are stored in the location of the customer but ownership of the goods is not transferred until the exact moment of use. Here regulation and interpretation of rules vary between Member States, which leads to legal uncertainty and to administrative burdens. Now we will ensure simplified administrative requirements that will clarify legal requirements and ease cross—border sales. We will also introduce simplified procedures for so—called chain transactions, where again a problem of legal uncertainty as to where VAT is ascribed in transactions between two or more companies currently exists. And finally, we will add simplification in relation to the proof of transport between companies and clarify that VAT numbers must be duly recorded. However, these quick fixes and simplifications cannot stand alone. This is very important. By introducing the status of a certified taxable person, we ensure that trustworthy companies who dutifully pay their fair taxes will be able to benefit from the simplified procedures for cross-border VAT, which will effectively cut down their administrative costs. It will also free up resources for Member States’ authorities to more effectively scrutinise companies which have previously failed to pay their taxes. It will also give a clear incentive for businesses not only to obtain the status of a certified taxable person, but also to maintain that status. As the European Parliament rapporteur, I urge Member States to fully implement the CTP provisions as proposed by the Commission and Parliament. I’m a little disappointed by the decision today by the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (Ecofin) in that regard. Talking frankly, the quick fixes and running – as some have been tempted to do on the Council side – are extremely ill-advised. This is a package and this must be adopted in its entirety. Let’s not waste this opportunity by being reckless and throwing the door open to simplification of VAT requirements to all corners. That would undermine the very purpose of these new initiatives and risk opening a new avenue for VAT fraud in Europe, and that would be the responsibility of the Council if they did so. I would like to commend the Commission, and Commissioner Moscovici and his team, for their dedication and excellent work in paving the way for a definitive VAT system. I would also like to thank the shadows from each political group for their constructive approach, their cooperation on this file and their support in ensuring a very large majority for the adoption of these new measures in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). I look forward to our ensuing debate on this topic, and hopefully to the swift adoption of these urgently needed improvements of the VAT system in Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Artist. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank the shadow reporters for their more constructive cooperation than is usual in the negotiation of such dossiers. I am pleased that, as a result of professional work that goes beyond partisan interests, we can discuss here today a report adopted by almost full consensus in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.  I trust that in tomorrow's vote we will also be able to act in a similar way in order to combat VAT fraud and to develop a definitive VAT system that has been going on for many decades.  The EU VAT system is an important tool for the single internal market and has made a major contribution to promoting trade within the European Union. However, as the current system of taxation of trade between Member States has not been able to keep pace with the globalisation and digitisation of the economy, the European Commission has proposed to amend the Directive.  There is a great deal of agreement within the European Parliament that the fragmentation of the current VAT system is a major obstacle to the proper functioning of the single internal market. However, it is a great step forward that under the new system, the privileges of individual Member States based on previous privileges will be abolished and that everyone can decide on their own VAT rate system on the basis of the same rules.  The proposal supported by the report therefore does not limit the current flexibility of The Member States in setting vat rates, on the contrary: it introduces harmonised and less restrictive rules, for example by introducing a so-called negative list instead of supplementing an already long list of goods and services to which a reduced rate of taxation can be applied. So let's just say that we can't be subject to a discounted rate. The new system therefore guarantees member states more freedom to decide which products they wish to tax at a reduced rate.  At the same time, however, a weighted average of 12% will be achieved in all Member States, taking into account all VAT rate, in order to ensure budgetary resources and avoid harmful tax competition. The political will to have not only a lower but also a cap on the standard VAT rate, namely 15% and 25%, will finally be stated. In addition to the general rate, each Member State will be able to apply two preferential rates and one rate between zero and 5%, in order to eliminate the further discrimination between Member States mentioned above.  I know that some of my fellow Members would have been even more sympathetic if we had voted with fewer key options, and perhaps this could be a next step in the future, but I would also like to reassure colleagues that the report specifically calls for the creation of an INFORMATION portal at EU level, which should provide accurate information on vat systems in all Member States, thereby helping small and medium-sized enterprises in particular.  As rapporteur, it was also of the utmost importance to me that the reduced rate should be applied for the benefit of final consumers and for the support of small and medium-sized enterprises. It was particularly important for the Socialists and Democrats group that, when applying reduced tax rates, social and environmental aspects should be taken into account by the Member States and that we should not allow harmful or luxury products to be benefited.  However, I must underline here that one of the key elements of the proposal for a definitive VAT system is that the VAT system for the taxation of trade between Member States will be based on the taxation of the Member State of destination.  Thank you for your attention, and I look forward to a forward-looking debate with my fellow reporters.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, less than two weeks ago on 21 September, the Commission published the VAT gap study, which shows the difference between the expected VAT revenue and the amount actually collected. EUR 150 billion per year is lost every year at the level of the European Union.  We must recognise that Member States have been improving VAT collection throughout the European Union, but such a loss for national budgets remains unacceptable, especially when EUR 50 billion of this is lining the pockets of criminals and probably even terrorists.  These figures show that the reform of the current European Union VAT system, combined with better cooperation at European Union level, are needed so that Member States can make full use of VAT revenues in their budgets. In April 2016, the European Commission presented a communication on an action plan on VAT in which it set out the pathway to the creation of a single European Union VAT area. The Commission announced that it would present a number of proposal for the fundamental reform of the EU VAT system over the coming months with the objective of making the VAT system simpler, more fraud-proof and more business friendly. This programme of reforms included the two proposals you will vote on tomorrow, namely the proposal adopted by the Commission on 4 October 2017, which introduces the cornerstones of the future definitive VAT system, together with four short—term improvements, or quick—fixes, to the current VAT rules in relation to cross—border trade in goods, and a proposal granting more flexibility for Member States to define reduced VAT rates. Considering the complexity of the past, the major subjects have been addressed step-by-step in 2016, but they all contribute to the same objective: to create a single VAT area that provides for a level playing field for business; to create a single VAT area that is fraud-proof; and to treat Member States equally and grant them more freedom in setting VAT rates.  To start with the first objective, I would remind you that our current VAT system is fragmented and complex to apply for the growing number of businesses operating across borders in the European Union. Such businesses have VAT compliance costs 11% higher than businesses whose main activities are domestic. We have to open the borders of VAT and create a real single VAT area for European Union companies. The proposals adopted in October 2017 presented the cornerstone for a new definitive VAT system, based on the principle of taxation in the Member State of destination, which will result in taxing cross-border sales or goods in the same way as domestic sales.  These proposals also contain four so-called quick fixes, which have been requested by businesses, stakeholders and Member States. The quick fixes aim to address specific problems encountered by business and tax authorities within the current VAT system related to the lack of clear and simple rules, or even the absence of any rules at all. In this respect, the Commission welcomes the support of the European Parliament and the draft report on this proposal in relation to the quick fixes, but also the cornerstone of the definitive VAT system and the concept of certified taxable persons. In May 2018, the Commission complimented these proposals by adopting a proposal on the detailed technical provisions for implementing the definitive VAT system. The Commission also adopted, in January 2018, measures to simplify VAT procedures for SMEs, which represent 99% of European Union business. We also welcome the support of the Parliament in this resolution, which was adopted on 11 September and we are confident that an agreement can be agreed soon in the Council. We have no time to lose. We estimate that this proposal will result in a compliance cost reduction of up to 11% for SMEs.  The second main objective of our VAT reform is to address the unacceptable problem of VAT cross-border fraud, which is estimated at around EU 50 billion per year. Before an agreement is concluded on the European Union definitive VAT regime, I am happy to say that – with the support of this Parliament – a first Commission proposal to address VAT fraud was already adopted in June 2018, only six months after its adoption by the Commission. It will enhance cooperation between tax administrations and law enforcement authorities and close loopholes in information sharing. It is the proof that, when there is political will, things can change quickly.  The last objective of the broad reform of the European Union VAT system is a full modernisation of the VAT rates policy. The VAT rates proposal is directly linked to the definitive VAT system in which Member States may be accorded greater freedom to apply reduced VAT rates, because it will be based on taxation at destination. The VAT rates proposal is also linked to the definitive VAT system, because it provides a solution to the current unequal VAT treatment of Member States. It will resolve the issue of over 150 temporary reduced VAT rates currently in place, which are due to expire with the entry into force of the definitive VAT system, and which are currently only available to some of the Member States.  In a nutshell, we are suggesting applying the subsidiarity principle to give more flexibility to Member States in a fair manner, in order to apply reduced rates in the sectors of their choice, according to their own national priorities.  On the other hand, our proposal sets a frame aiming to prevent both excessive revenue losses for Member States, and distortion of competition. Furthermore, in the future, reduced rates must clearly be of benefit to citizens, because they are the final consumers paying the VAT. Where common rules lead to a better outcome, we work together with the Member States. Where common rules are unnecessary, and rule—making can be achieved better at Member State level, the Commission steps back.  To conclude, let me say that behind the apparent complexity of some proposals, the reform of the European Union VAT system is a win-win situation for both Member States, revenues and European businesses. More money to spend for public services, and more money to invest for businesses. With the support of Parliament, the adoption of these proposals before the European elections will show citizens the added value of the European Union and the benefits of a real single market for VAT.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. Chairman, I greet the Commissioner and all present colleagues. The VAT system, and we can all agree on this, we need to simplify, modernise, adapt to the new digital age and help, of course, to better and simpler cross-border cooperation and trade.  The temporary solution for the VAT system in cross-border operations was adopted 25 years ago and is a true example of how temporary solutions are becoming time-consuming. This proposal for amendments to the Directive introduces simplifications that are also a preparation for the establishment of a definitive VAT system, which previous speakers have already pointed out.  Entrepreneurs point out VAT and complicated VAT calculation as the main obstacle to cross-border business and the use of advantages in the single market. In particular, they list the additional costs they have to comply with different rules in each member state and of course we need to change that.  It is with these changes that we want to simplify and adapt more to the needs of the entrepreneurs. Rules for VAT calculation in cases of movement of goods and chain transactions are defined and levelled, and we know that these areas were the most common areas of VAT fraud. Likewise, the concept of a certified taxable person is being introduced, but I must point out here that the Commission needs to further clarify and establish criteria for establishing this status in order to be used evenly at the level of all Member States and for states to recognise this status with each other. It is also important to set up a One Stop Shop for entrepreneurs to provide information on system changes and updating VAT rates in the Member States.  Finally, it is important to point out that we are able to combat these VAT losses and fraud with these amendments.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, we will vote tomorrow on two important texts on VAT, as a contribution to the implementation of this final VAT regime that Europe has been waiting for for so long - for all the time it has lived under the temporary regime, in which a clear fraud has slipped , known as the "carousel." Whatever the efforts of the Member States, the VAT gap - that is, the difference between the expected VAT receipts and the amount actually collected by the States - is 150 billion euros, of which 50 billion is due to this famous carousel fraud. Reform of the current system is therefore essential. It must ally itself with better coordination or cooperation between Member States at European level to facilitate cross-border trade and, above all, to make this system more resistant to fraud so that VAT revenues can actually be used by Member States in their budgets. Rather than taxing the purchasing power of European citizens more, it is undoubtedly fraud that we must try to reduce. This system must be more efficient and therefore simplified, and the Socialists fully support the principle of destination, a principle endorsed by the reform proposed by the Commission. But in the fight against fraud, we believe that we should not penalise companies that respect the rules of the game and that is why we have supported, with the report of my colleague Jeppe Kofod... (the President interrupts the speaker)... and we regret that the Council has not, for the time being, taken up the proposal contained in Mr Kofod's report of the status of certified subject, which would allow them to benefit from simplified procedures.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent The Polish delegation of the ECR Group strongly supports the basic orientations for the reform of the VAT system at European level. Both legislative initiatives are part of the policy of the current Polish Government, which has taken decisive action from the outset to seal the VAT system in Poland. Admittedly, he has had spectacular successes in this field. We therefore support all the so-called four pillars of the new regulation.  However, we do not support the promoted concept of a certified taxpayer. I would like to point out that the Council and the Commission have long agreed to abandon this proposal, and therefore our parliamentary consultation has not keeping up with developments. It's not strange to say the least? The Polish delegation of the ECR will abstain from voting on this report for this reason.  On the other hand, we fully support the draft report on the harmonisation of VAT rates. After all, Poland has been seeking to give this direction to this reform for the last two years. In my opinion, the draft report presented balances two aspects of legislation well: flexibility and the necessary minimum harmonisation, and deserves recognition and support.

name: Thierry CORNILLET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs for their work in this consultation procedure.  This is not trivial, we are united and our message to the finance ministers is extremely clear: this reform must be initiated without delay, which is guided by two key words, namely simplicity and efficiency.  Simplicity lies in the choice of a 15% floor and a 25% ceiling. It is also a simplification that results in a much more flexible procedure than unanimity in defining reduced rates. This is yet another simplification of what is still to be created, that is, a system of certified tax payers, which will allow access to much less cumbersome procedures and facilitate the payment of VAT in cross-border transactions. Efficiency, on the other hand, lies in the introduction of a comprehensive multilingual portal through which businesses and citizens can understand the system. Efficiency also requires a system of mechanism for resolving conflicts between states.  There is now another step, which will also be guided by efficiency and simplicity, namely the principle of taxation in the destination state, one of the means of combating fraud estimated at 50 billion euros in this area.  Therefore, a single VAT area for the whole of the Union is in the interest of all - both citizens and businesses and Member States - except fraudsters, which is also the aim.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, although I doubt many citizens will be glued to their screens watching this debate, we have done some important work in agreeing on a series of legislative proposals to update the VAT system, which we have been working with on a temporary basis since 1993. This clear and streamlined tax-raising regime should play an important part in reducing VAT fraud, which currently costs the public purse around EUR 50 billion a year. So it’s worth celebrating this unique, unified tax regime across our Union. It is also flexible, allowing Member States to choose how they use reduced rates to incentivise their own political preferences, while ensuring that, overall, rates are equal. At a time when the EU27 are demonstrating unprecedented cooperation on VAT, it is a matter of sadness and concern to me, as a British Member, that there is still no clarity on the VAT regime for British businesses after March next year. This poses a serious risk to small businesses, and I would urge the Prime Minister to end this uncertainty by making a definitive decision to stay with the unified tax regime.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we have accompanied the opportunity to simplify the VAT system and agree with the principle of the negative list which gives member states greater latitude in order to determine the different VAT rates.  What we don't understand is the inclusion of musical instruments in this negative list. The reduction of vat on musical instruments is an old demand of the artistic community. In Portugal, with the action of cfp members it was possible in 2018 to reduce the rate from 23 to the intermediate rate of 13 % and I therefore appeal to this House tomorrow to approve our proposal to withdraw the musical instruments in Annex 3a, thus allowing countries to continue with their policies to support the creation and cultural enjoyment.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am going to say a couple of things that won’t normally be heard in this Chamber but I feel it’s a good start: tax is theft and competition is good. We have to accept that taxation is required in order to run a state and we have to have a minimum of taxation because that is the best way to get people to work for their money and for business to thrive. But if you wish to get the best out of businesses, give them a competitive environment instead of harmonising across the EU with one rate of tax. Why not have localised tax, where different people have different sales taxes and people can compete to see which environment is best for business, which one entices people to set up companies, and what do the people in the area want: jobs or control and regulation? The whole concept of harmonising taxes across the EU is entirely against business, against competition, totally undemocratic and totally against the nation-state and all its values.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, plundering every day with an unfair tax and thinking that simplifying is the solution does not go far. I would like to show this cartel, two billion is the Italian VAT paid to the European bandwagon. I would have liked to have thought about how to spend VAT and how to reduce this waste. It is unthinkable that EUR 2 billion of Italian VAT should finance reception, and should finance the double seat, this one, which hosts us in Brussels, which is a useless location. Well, today what would be needed is to leave a few extra money in the pockets of italian citizens and not a few less money. To think of digesting an unfair tax with the term simplification is a big mistake, as it is a great mistake to have put this 25% ceiling on. Then think, we are talking about a quarter of the good, that is, I buy a good and for a quarter it is plundered by the State and By Europe and you think that the Italian people and the European people must be happy with these choices. Italian families like this feel punished. This is how they feel affected by a Europe that needs to be changed.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Admit that, in these reports, the current VAT system has allowed fraudsters to extract billions of euros from the EU budget for decades. You've known this for decades, and you haven't done anything about it. Why are you doing this now and who is responsible for creating such a pathological system? If it takes you so many years to notice the elephant in the room, to understand such a simple thing, Then I am afraid that taxpayers will not stand the pace of economic education. Because before you understand that EU subsidies are not working, that your communist agricultural policy is not working, that the whole social security system is leading to disaster, that all this socialism is one big failure at all, then here the stone on the stone in this Europe will not stay. And I support a direction that avoids tax fraud, but I do not strongly support the harmonisation of taxes, because that means an increase for most of us.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for amending VAT rates. There are seven proposals from Mr Szanyi. We achieved a good result with 44 votes in favour and four against. It is a corresponding Directive from the Council, so we can only wish to change it. We have done so, and some colleagues have pointed out that, since the 1990s, this provisional VAT system has led to an ever-increasing increase in fraud. In 2016, the Court of Auditors has found that EUR 147 billion was generated by fraud or non-payment of VAT. That is a huge sum and reform is urgently needed. The proposals on VAT rates give Member States more leeway. We supported an average rate of 12%, a maximum rate of 25% and a minimum rate of 15%, as well as exceptions that individual Member States are allowed to make, which other Member States also implement, so as not to create distortions of competition. The most important point, however, is that we have not agreed on a system to replace the transitional regime. The only system that clearly prevents permanent VAT fraud would be the reverse charge system. This is an extremely effective and efficient measure. The Commission has so far been opposed, and I can only ask the Commissioner to abandon the reticence it has had so far. Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic have applied for this. It can be seen here that all the measures taken do not work, because unanimity in the Council is still a prerequisite for meaningful harmonisation. I therefore ask that we adopt this report together.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Langen, it is my understanding that Ecofin today adopted a decision on the reverse charge system. I would have to double check, but I understand there has been a development in that respect.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The Commission's proposals to adapt the VAT system are, in principle, to be welcomed. But why is it important that we finally reform this VAT? The current VAT system has come of age. It is now more than difficult for businesses and tax authorities to find the right way through the jungle of tax rates, rules and jurisprudence. But fraudsters know exactly how to exploit the system. In 2016 alone, the EU budget lost €50 billion to VAT fraud, €100 billion lost to insolvencies, erroneous calculations, etc. a total of €150 billion – equivalent to the EU budget for the full year 2018. This money is missing at every turn, in schools, streets, pension funds. The need for action is therefore more than clear. It is clear that the new rules must be as simple as possible for all parties involved. I come from a border region and bureaucracy must not in any way hinder cross-border trade. As a tax auditor, I know from my own experience how important clear and concrete laws and implementing rules are, because that is the only way we can effectively combat VAT fraud and billions of dollars in tax losses. I therefore call on the Member States to agree quickly on a system that meets the requirements I have just described.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, streamlining the VAT system will really help to tackle carousel fraud, which has reached up to EUR 147 billion in the European Union. Of course, measures must be taken to support small and medium-sized enterprises, and above all there must be zero or minimum VAT on essentials and tariffs from the Utilities, in a Europe which really has thousands of poor and unemployed people.  On the other hand, competition from third countries must be tackled. And I am referring to the Aegean islands, which face competition from Turkey, which has 5% VAT. But the troika has imposed 24% VAT on the Aegean islands. This situation cannot continue, because these islands are now suffering, among other things, from huge migratory flows. The measure to be taken is therefore the imposition of low VAT on the Aegean islands, as was the case in the past.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, your proposal for a VAT directive is moving in the right direction for at least two reasons. The first is that it will enable it to effectively combat this scandal of VAT fraud, with systems such as the 'carousel'. The second reason for satisfaction is that you allow states to choose rates that are reduced from the normal rate. You indicate in your rewriting of Article 98 and Appendix III of the 2006 Directive that the reduced rates must serve the end consumer and serve to consistently pursue a public interest objective. I would just like to check with you that this is the case with the horse industry. It has a socio-eco-environmental dimension - land use, rural development, health activity, equitherapy and a sector that creates jobs that can't be relocated. There is no risk of unfair competition in this area. Last week, we even saw the presentation here in Parliament of a small horse that can be used as a guide for the blind. I would therefore like to check with you, Commissioner, that this sector can indeed benefit, if this is the wish of the Member State, from a reduced rate. That is my understanding of your proposal, and I thank you for your response.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, tax fraud in the field of VAT is literally a gangrene. We lose around EUR 150 billion a year from tax fraud and non-payment of VAT.  The measures proposed by the European Parliament, which are in line with the Commission's measures, lead to harmonisation, simplification and more European cooperation, by enhancing transparency, with a European information exchange system and can, if implemented, generate revenues of EUR 45 billion per year and also reduce costs for businesses by EUR 1 billion per year.  So we have to move on. And the reason we are not moving forward is that what the European Parliament and the Commission are converging on is refusing to be promoted by the Council, because some Member States are putting the brakes on this effort. That has to change.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, VAT is the greatest nightmare for any small business. It is an overcomplicated imposition on hardworking entrepreneurs trying to build their businesses and employ their fellow citizens in gainful employment.  We welcome these simplifications, but they are simply not enough. There should be less obsession by the EU with loss of revenue and more concern about the damage to businesses and employment caused by VAT. All I hear is whining about loss of revenue from politicians more interested in oiling the wheels of this place with other people’s money. Tax should be decided by Member States, competition encouraged and taxes lowered. Britain should not stick with the unified tax regime after Brexit. The Brexit dividend should be to get rid of VAT – an EU tax – introduce a sales tax at 6%, like the United States of America, and leave the money in the pockets of the citizens.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, the two reports we are discussing today represent an important step in the direction of completing the definitive VAT regime in the European Union. The report by Mr Szanyi makes progress in three crucial areas: firstly, Member States shall adopt a maximum of two reduced rates, which shall not be lower than 5%. These reduced rates would only be allowed for goods, the supply of which is in the genuine public interest. This will reduce dispersion in the VAT rates across the EU and benefit final consumers.  Secondly, the weighted average VAT rate should be at least 12%. Thirdly, while the derogations and the reduced rates will continue to be determined by individual Member States, they will also be available to exporters from all other Member States. Together, these changes will help achieve a level playing field in the single market, eliminate distortions and allow for a consistent application of the country of destination principle. At the same time, they will give more freedom to Member States in fixing the national VAT rates according to their priorities.  The other report by Mr Kofod aims at harmonising and simplifying certain rules in the VAT system. In particular, harmonising rules in VAT treatment of chain transactions will significantly reduce the scope for VAT fraud across the EU. This is especially true when it comes to so-called ‘triangular transactions’ or ‘carousel schemes’, which had been one of the most popular VAT fraud schemes in intra-Community trade.  Mr President, while acknowledging the progress achieved, I have to stress that the definitive VAT system is still a largely unfinished construction. I call on the Commission, and especially on the Member States, to show more resolve and determination in completing this important work.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur on his report.  Following on from the Commission's proposal to amend the VAT Directive to give Member States more flexibility to set the VAT rate, I welcome the changes proposed in the report as they stress that the reduced rate should benefit the end consumer in the first place, while pursuing social and environmental objectives.  Therefore, I agree that the reduced rate and exception should apply only to products that have a positive impact on the public interest with obvious cultural, social or environmental benefits and should never be applied to harmful or luxury products. With regard to small and medium-sized enterprises, I support the Commission's proposal to create a comprehensive, multilingual and publicly accessible EU VAT information portal, on which businesses and consumers can quickly and effectively obtain accurate information on the VAT rate in the various Member States, including goods concerned or services with reduced rates or exceptions.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in theory fiscal principles are not so difficult. A company pays corporation tax in the country where it makes its profits and indirect taxes such as VAT come into the state coffers of the country where it is consumed. But the reality unfortunately says something completely different. These seemingly simple principles are not so obvious in practice. In fact, tax revenues disappear through windows and doors. Profits made in European Member States are not even channelled into tax havens through such ingenious constructions. Through VAT carousels, my VAT is going to charge third parties to put it in their own pocket instead of transferning it to the treasury where they were supposed to arrive. In the case of VAT fraud, we can no longer speak of loopholes. It's so common and it happens on such a large scale that we just don't see the net through the cracks anymore. Each year, Member States of the Union together collect more than EUR 1000 billion in VAT revenue, but that could and should be much more. In 2016, the difference between revenue and revenue in the end was around EUR 147 billion, we have already heard the figure this evening. For my country of Belgium, this amounts to EUR 3.3 billion. I repeat: EUR 3.3 billion. Tackling VAT fraud, ladies and gentlemen, requires political courage and European action. It cannot be explained that we in Europe have been working with some sort of transitional regime for cross-border transactions between companies for 24 years. For 24 years, vat carousels went crazy with an invoice for the European Member States of EUR 50 billion. Every year. So it's not 5 for 12, it's not 5 after 12, lunch is actually long gone. A definitive vat regime is really necessary for this, not only because of the social outrage following the Panama and the Paradise papers, but also and above all because of the moral injustice. The newspapers are full of fissures in Europe and lost legitimacy. It's time for action.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, congratulations to both the rapporteurs, who are tackling VAT fraud and ensuring that Member States set VAT rates at a consistent level. Not only will this affect citizens’ daily lives, but it will also reduce compliance costs for businesses by up to EUR 1 billion. However, just a note of caution: this depends on how quickly the governments of the 28 Member States approve and implement this agreement. Large—scale VAT fraud means EUR 50 billion lost from national budgets each year because of the complexities with differing rules – money that could have been better spent on housing, better schools and improved health-care facilities. However, national tax authorities on their own have lacked the resources to tackle cross—border VAT fraud thoroughly. One big flaw is the system of VAT refund for exported goods. Far too often, this system has been abused, leading to carousel VAT fraud. This can be addressed only if we have a clear, automated, definitive and EU—wide VAT system. Particularly where there are disputes, a simple EU—wide VAT dispute resolution mechanism is urgently needed. Therefore, I welcome today the fact that agreement has been reached in the Council to move towards a strong, harmonised, definitive VAT system. An important step that this report is proposing is to enable Member States to reduce rates up to 5%, and for one item they can reduce it to even lower than 5%. This is hugely important. The so—called tampon tax, whereby VAT on this product can now be zero percent, is an issue that this House has been fighting for and prioritising as a means of addressing poverty. It is therefore essential that the Council accelerates … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleague, I apologise. Seriously, I do understand, but we all have hugely important points to make, but we would still be sitting here at midnight if we were to address them all. My apologies. I am sure this is relevant but I had to take the floor away from you.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, in the tax field it seems that nothing that is transitional remains transitional and lasts for a very long time, and the VAT regime in the European Union has been transient for too many years. This regime favours tax evasion and also constitutes a huge bureaucracy if the Member States have to and want to exchange that information in order to identify those who do the evasion. That is why I believe that the proposals made by the Commission and the amendments made by our colleagues in the ECON are a good step forward. Such proposals, such as, for example, the new concept of certification of VAT payers, as well as the new proposed ranges for the variation of VAT rates in the Member States represent not only a simplification of the VAT regime in the European Union, but also concrete steps towards that definitive regime that we want to achieve for VAT in the European Union.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. With these reports, we are taking important steps towards the creation of a single European VAT area. We want to create a system of common rules instead of a system of exceptions. It is right that we should combat VAT fraud in this way. Because we have a VAT gap of 170 billion and a cross-border VAT fraud of 50 billion. It is right that we are harmonising the system of VAT rates with the corridor solution, because at present more than 250 exceptions in the Member States lead to fragmentation and unequal treatment. It is right that we introduce simplifications with the concept of certified taxpayers, because complexity and bureaucracy in the current system slow down growth and employment. It is right that we should create a common online information portal, because citizens and businesses have a right to greater transparency. And it is right that we should create a better system, because VAT is a growing public revenue, including for the European Union. I call on the Council to make these measures a reality as soon as possible.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, this is once again a perfect example of why we need more harmonisation, better integration and ‘more Europe’. We had noticed that the existing system cannot tackle tax fraud and tax evasion, nor is it easy or manageable for those operating it. The answer is what Parliament has been calling for and what the rapporteurs have talked about: a single, European, united VAT system which is clear and simple, in which issues are resolved at European level, and which is supervised at European level. While this is being realised, I hope that, in the next review, the sustainable finance principles can be included in our VAT system. This will mean that products with a higher environmental and climate load should have higher VAT rates, while goods that are reused or recycled, or which impact less on climate change, should have a lower VAT rate – instead of the haphazard approach to lower rates, with percentage point differences here and there, which we see at the moment. Hopefully – and this is a message to the Commission – provisions to that effect can be included, especially now that we have the Commissioner responsible for climate change.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I want to thank all of you for this debate which shows the high interest and need for deep reform of the European VAT system. There is significant progress that we have already made, because, since 2015, new rules for sales of e—services online came into force which allows Member States to collect VAT where the consumer is based, through a one—stop shop. Member States have also now agreed to extend this new system to services and goods online, delivering another boost for VAT collection in the European Union. As I mentioned in the introduction, the European Union has also recently agreed on a ground—breaking new framework to exchange more information and boost cooperation between national tax authorities and law enforcement authorities.  However, after all the fundamental reform, a European Union VAT definitive system is still to be adopted by the Council. In his State of the Union speech, President Juncker called for an end of unanimity in taxation policy. Unanimity can block proposals that are in the interests of the majority and thus prevent companies and citizens from benefiting from a full single market.  The Commission will play its role in the reflection towards a chain of rules by presenting a communication in the coming months on qualified majority voting in the field of taxation. With your support, I am confident that the two proposals you will vote on will benefit from broad support and that progress can be achieved on all VAT proposals in the coming months.  Finally, in reply to the question from Mr Arthuis, yes, the horse sector can benefit from VAT reduced rates if the Member State so decides.  Commission Statement (in writing) The Commission and the Council are aware of a certain divergence in the VAT treatment of independent groups of persons that pool their services and share costs between their members. The Council and the Commission recognize the need to clarify such VAT rules on independent groups of persons. The Commission will analyse this matter in detail in a study to be launched shortly with a view, subject to its right of initiative, to a possible proposal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I do appreciate the very cooperative manner in which we have been able to discuss this whole issue. Thank you for that. I would just like to come back to one single item in this debate, namely the praise, the acknowledgment and the sense of change towards the principle of ‘place of destination’. This means that, from whenever this new system is introduced, there will be no possibility to issue invoices with so—called zero—VAT rates unless it prevails in the country of destination. But the proof of the pudding is in the eating, and we are longing to see whether or not it will function in practice. We believe that it will. We also believe that, ultimately, small and medium—sized enterprises and the final consumers will be the prime beneficiaries of this whole issue. I would like especially to thank the Commission because I think that it was a good proposal and so Parliament had a fairly easy job.  Finally, I would say that now governments are going to be responsible for their own respective voters. They can’t say ‘it’s Brussels’.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 3 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The current VAT system in the EU is a temporary system that is renewed every two years. A minimum tax rate of 15% applies, with some exceptions, so that reductions are possible. The allowable reductions are currently listed in an annex. The final system confirms the minimum tax rate of 15% and introduces a maximum rate of 25%. The Appendix of Permitted Reductions (up to 5%) shall be replaced by a list of goods and services for which no reductions are permitted. This gives Member States more freedom to reduce VAT rates on certain goods and products, with the average weighted tax rate exceeding 12%. In practice, this approach could prove to be a restriction on the fiscal freedom of national parliaments. Moreover, the introduction of a so-called "Certified Taxable Person" (CTP) does not provide a sufficient guarantee against fraudulent economic operators and should therefore not be discussed before a final determination of the VAT system. In principle, I am sceptical about further harmonisation of VAT, particularly in the setting of minimum rates. While I welcome the continued flexibility of Member States in setting their own VAT rates, I am not convinced that the new measures to be set will actually increase flexibility. The focus should continue to be on fiscal cooperation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – I support the Commission's proposal for a Council directive concerning the harmonisation and simplification of certain rules in the value added tax system and the definitive system of taxation of trade between Member States. With this measure, the European Union can prevent tax evasion amounting to almost EUR 50 billion a year. The proposal introduces an institute for a certified taxable person, which will be recognised by all Member States. Upon request, the national tax authority shall grant this status to a person who demonstrates the proper payment of taxes, an internal control system and proof of financial capacity. These entities will be regarded as a reliable taxpayer, allowing them to use simplified procedures for the award and payment of cross-border VAT. Mutual cooperation between Member States and control, together with the proposed measures, will reduce administrative burdens for businesses and improve VAT collection.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Commission and Council Declarations on the rise of neo-fascist violence in Europe (2018/2869(RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: President—in—Office of the Council. – Mr President, you have invited the Presidency to speak on behalf of the Council on a topic of common concern, namely how the EU can respond to politically motivated violence. I am grateful to have this opportunity.  First, I would like to express my sympathy to Ms Forenza, who was attacked in Bari a week ago, and who informed us on Monday at the opening session. Such attacks, especially against a Member of the European Parliament and her staff, have no place in Europe. It is our joint responsibility to safeguard the values on which the Union is founded. EU values are the backbone of the Union and encompass pluralism, tolerance, justice and fundamental rights. Among the fundamental rights, the Charter of Fundamental Rights includes freedom of expression and freedom of peaceful assembly. Any politically motivated attack on a peaceful demonstration is an attack on our common values.  The use of violence for political reasons to forbid others to express their ideas is unjustifiable in our open democratic societies. We are appalled by the most recent violent incidents in several Member States. Evidence from different sources, such as the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and the Council of Europe, confirms an alarming increase in intolerance and hatred in Europe. Whatever the source might be, let me be clear that there is no justification for this. At EU level, the Council attaches great importance to ensuring the effective transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision on Combating Racism and Xenophobia and other relevant hate crime laws at national level. The Council constantly calls upon Member States to develop effective methods to report and ensure proper recording of hate crimes. At national level, it is for law enforcement authorities and the national courts to protect fundamental rights when these are attacked by political extremists.  Let me also underline the important role of education and youth work. In my capacity as a Youth Minister, I want to stress the need to develop democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance, critical thinking and conflict resolution skills in learning processes. I would like to conclude by stressing how important it is to prevent our societies from becoming dominated by hatred. We are therefore obliged to take all incidents of this kind seriously and never ignore them.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we have all seen shocking cases of neo—fascist violence in Europe in recent months, including the shooting of six people of immigrant background in Macerata, Italy, the violent far-right protests that followed, and a fatal stabbing which sparked racial tensions in the German city of Chemnitz. According to the latest data we have, there are roughly four anti-Semitic incidents per day in France, the United Kingdom and Germany. We expect Member States to act forcefully against crimes committed by neo—Nazi groups – whether in the streets, in football arenas or in the targeting of places of worship or asylum shelters. However, we also have to look at where this violence comes from. Societal polarisation has increased, not least in the social media. We read and talk to the like-minded, and this increases the polarisation of our societies. As a society, we need to step up action against racism, intolerance and the toxic narratives which are shrinking the space for well-informed and democratic discussion in the public sphere and are polarising our societies. We have our Charter of Fundamental Rights and we have to make clear that its basic principles really matter: that they are not negotiable. But we have to ensure that people in Europe can also relate to them. These principles should become an anchor in the fast-changing and sometimes confusing world. Simply, they should be the bedrock of our society. For me, I understand the key principles as follows: equality before the law; no tolerance for discrimination; freedom of speech, but with limits to exclude, for instance, speech calling for violence; freedom of religion within the limits of the legal order; and access to justice for all, not only the privileged or the rich. And finally, among the main principles, I want to mention the right of feeling secure, of feeling safe, but not at the expense of the safety of others. These principles can only work if they are applied and visible in people’s everyday lives. The Commission is leading the work on countering the increasingly worrying phenomenon of illegal online hate speech. We are working intensively with Member States to step up the implementation of EU law to combat racism and xenophobia and to ensure that prompt investigation, prosecution and proportionate sanctioning become a reality in the EU Member States. The intent is to be practical, and we are striving to make a difference on the ground. Our work with Member States includes the compilation of promising practices and guiding principles on key issues such as hate-crime training and hate-crime victim support. We will also present a comprehensive guidance document on the practical application of the Framework Decision on Combating Racism. I consider these issues very important because they also send strong signals that hate crime and illegal hate speech are not tolerated and will be penalised. We too, as individual politicians, have a role to play in avoiding divisive attitudes and in sticking to the norms. This is the moment to stand up for the principles of our Charter. And the independent media also have their role to play here: it is their responsibility to counter discourse that sows division, spreads disinformation and encourages exclusion. The media are also instrumental in holding politicians to account and in defining the limits of what is acceptable and what is unacceptable in society. The Commission is also tackling the worrying rise of far-right violent extremism under its radicalisation policies. The Radicalisation Awareness Network has dedicated, and will continue to dedicate, its efforts, inter alia, to training frontline practitioners – police officers and prison staff – on how to address far-right extremism and all manifestations of polarisation. Overall, I can assure you, honourable Members, that this is a priority issue for the Commission and that we are working with all the relevant actors, including in law enforcement, civil society and industry, especially the digital industry, to tackle all these problems not only through the law but also in our work to foster a more tolerant, safer and law-abiding society.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I will recall the word that we all know, the word of St. John: "There was a word at the beginning." And we all know that great things begin with the word, but terrible and vile things can also begin in the word, and we all know that the word can change into deeds.  Unfortunately, today we are witnessing verbal aggression in many places in our Union, dividing society into a better and worse sort, into patriots and traitors. Permission for hejt in audiovisual media, written and online. Stories of refugees bringing parasites and diseases. This is reminiscent of the mosthyde propaganda of the darkest moments in European history. And these words are often followed by the approval of fascist marches inciting violence, racism, homophobia. There are already excesses such as the burning of the Jew's cuckoo or the symbolic hanging of portraits of politicians, who clearly article the need to protect the weak, minorities and call for the observance of European values. We have examples of this in the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, Malta. In some countries, the public media sows hatred of the government's political opponents, in others the government does so personally.  And words are starting to go into deeds, as exemplified by what we have seen recently in Italy. I will also mention the unfortunate excesses in Chemnitz. And we cannot pretend that nothing is happening or that these are the internal problems of several countries, because this terrible plague is spilling over. It is above all the responsibility of the Member States to combat this problem, and the Commission – thank you commissioner here – must work very closely with them, constantly draw up an action plan and consistently enforce it. Finally, Mr President, Auschwitz is in my constituency. At the entrance to block four is a plaque on which the phrase of the philosopher Santayana is engered , "Whoever does not remember history is condemned to relive it." Let us draw conclusions!

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party(S&D), a new spectre is hovering around Europe, the spectre of neo-fascism. For too long, the national parliaments and the European Union have ignored the emergence of a new and violent wave of nationalism. Let us be clear about this: the multiple economic and institutional crises have led to the re-surface of the blackest stain in our history. We, as members of a democratic institution, cannot accept intolerance. For the sake and freedom of all, we must oppose nationalist violence by pursuing the fundamental principles enshrined in the Founding Treaties of the European Union. If we are not able to do that, we will find in the national parliaments and here too, in this European Parliament, the detractors of human rights who will open their doors, our doors, tearing the Union apart.
