Every day, in our society, we see the repercussions of intolerance and hatred: insults, aggressions, punitive expeditions, raids against minorities and racist blitzes. It is these daily episodes, fuelled by the whirlwind of exacerbated hatred and propaganda slogans, in an endless campaign climate. A propaganda against migrants, against the Roma, against Afro-descendants, precisely Afrophobia, against Jews or Muslims, against minorities. Populist political forces blame the weakest for their failures, never looking to the public good and shamelessly lying. The new European nationalists have chosen rather strange terminologies to name themselves: Golden Dawn, House Pound, Forza Nuova, Front National, Jobbik, to name but a few. These and even the other parties that pretend to be more moderate only perpetuate their violence. They are even prepared to make inconsistent pacts in order to sell some of their defeatist propaganda. But the only things that populist and nationalist parties share are anti-European sentiment, xenophobia and racism. The democratic forces must therefore react, united and strong. We must defend our states and our Union in order to save freedom, equality, human rights, the rule of law, pluralism and solidarity.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, if you listen to the left or the mainstream media you easily get the impression that fascism and fascist violence are the top threats to public security in Europe. Of course, any kind of violence should be condemned, but it seems to me that Islamic and left—wing radicalism are much more relevant problems in today’s Europe, including when we talk about anti—Jewish violence.  It is very unfortunate that whenever ordinary people express their concern over immigrant or Islamic violence, they are immediately labelled fascists, racists and Nazis. One very good example are the recent events in Chemnitz, Germany. Many nationalist politicians and parties are systematically terrorised by the extreme left in many European countries. I find it worrying how little attention and condemnation this phenomenon gets in the public debate.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his It's not the boot tramp on our streets that scares me. Nor are the gap-necks roaring out slogans from the past that make me anxious. My focus is entirely on the people who manipulate and support these people. Our democracy is not a stable system. It must be defended. Our conditions are constantly under attack. Scientific knowledge is confused with opinions. Recognized experts are referred to as elitist obsessives who should shut up. In these muddy waters, fact resistance, racism and fascism germinated. Opinions and ideologies that we thought had disappeared are now on their way back and are here. What was previously unspeakable can now be aired freely. Hatred and threats against journalists and politicians are on the rise. Anti-racists and feminists are particularly vulnerable. After hatred and intimidation follows violence, and violence breeds more violence. We must fight for democracy in both small and large deeds. We must not give up and lie flat. We must continue to paint the image of the society that we want to see and fight for it every day. The inviolable rights of man are in focus.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my speech could be summed up in two words: Bella ciao. Two words that should call on the European Union and this House to wake up because the fascists have come back to strike. To strike in Greece, Germany and Italy and to strike throughout Europe, legitimised by racist and xenophobic cultures that are often now cultures of government.  Two words that remind us that Europe was born of the defeat of Nazi fascism and that today it can only be reborn by taking the baton of the partisans and partisans. I come from a Member State whose Constitution is anti-fascist and in which, however, the Minister of the Interior enjoys going to dinner with the representatives of Casa Pound and celebrating the arrest of Mimmo Lucano. At Casa Pound are the squadristi who attacked and threatened me and other anti-racist militants, friday 21 September in Bari, and still on my Facebook page I find threats from people urging 7 blacks to rape me because racism and sexism are the matrix of fascism. Finally, I would like to remind you that we must demand that the European Union be anti-fascist, that anti-fascism be a founding value of the Union, and we must call for the closure of all fascist bodies, and I dedicate this speech to Begni, Auro, Dax, Renato and all our comrades and companions who are victims of neo-fascist violence.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is not just the rise in neofascism and neofascist violence that’s the problem, it is political violence from both sides, including far left groups, such as Antifa, who are known for violent disturbances. Britain’s own Labour Party has been accused of anti-Semitism, and, may I say, the SNP (Scottish National Party) has tried to close down many businesses in Scotland undemocratically because they didn’t agree with them. So that wasn’t particularly democratic.  The rise of extremist politics in the EU has been caused by the EU itself. The EU has ignored so-called populist parties like UKIP, the Five Star Movement and the Swedish Democrats, and has left the doors open to unlimited number of people competing for jobs with ordinary working people. What do you expect if the EU tries to replace the nationalistic working class with a homogeneous bunch of people from abroad who will support the EU? They believe a vote for them. Chancellor Merkel opens the doors to everyone. What do you expect? People will defend their jobs and their homes, and they don’t want their religions or anything else changed. They want their homes and their freedoms; you can’t stop them defending that.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is truly grotesque to hear of fascist danger at the age of 75, 73, 74 years after the end of war and civil wars and therefore also of historical fascism. You really always have it in mind, it must be a Freudian and grotesque phenomenon, because fascism is no longer there. This debate reminds me of an enlightening phrase by a great Italian intellectual certainly anti-fascist, Pier Paolo Pasolini, who warned against those who wave the fascist danger, he says, is perhaps not "a weapon of mass distraction" to ignore what is true fascism, financial fascism against which those who arm themselves against four young men in black shirts, perhaps violent - in some cases that we condemn - specifically - and they do nothing to combat financial fascism, as populists do, we populists who have not forgotten the 5 million poor, to whom previous governments gave nothing, we populists, nationalists and so-called fascists have thought about it. And you've never done shit!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, the success of far-right parties in elections and, of course, the various forms of dissemination of neo-Nazism and neo-fascism are the bed of support for the rise of neo-fascist violence in Europe. An example is the boom in commemorable events in Croatia, in which the Ustašovce are heroes, which she pointed out and which were also warned about by a recent report by the Council of Europe. The far-right violence in Chemnitz, Germany, I think we all still have enough in mind. Despite these incidents, the strength of far-right parties at the moment is not, in my view, such as to undermine the democratic foundations on which the European Union stands. But if democratic parties do not find a way to effectively fight them in political competition, this situation can easily change for the worse. In this context, I would also like to point out that the danger to European democracy is not only from the far right, but also from the far left. I consider left-wing extremism to be no less pernicious than right-wing extremism. And there are still a number of Communist parties in Europe that are true emers of Marxism-Leninism, an ideology that is responsible for a comparable number of people's lives. Every democracy is fragile and vulnerable by nature, so we must take due care of our European one, so that it does not happen that it flows through our fingers. In practice, this means choosing the appropriate combination of preventive and repressive measures against all kinds of extremism: both right-wing and left-wing. If you recorded correctly, I am also in for punitive measures. An attack on European democracy can come from both sides.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is true that there is a ghost that runs through Europe: the ghost of nationalism, which is europe's denial; the ghost of populism, which offers the simple answer to those who feel struck by inequality and impoverishment to point out a scapegoat to them as if they were enemies of the people. But it's the ghost of the far right, which excites hate speech. Fascism did incalculable damage in the 20th century, but was not extinguished in the 20th century. Not only does it reach the 21st century, but it is also represented in the European Parliament. That fascism that proposes fear and exploitation of fear and hatred to the different. But to defeat him it is imperative that the European Union offers more than just a good diagnosis and even a good speech. It has to offer hope to those who have lost it. The hope of integration into diversity, respect for the different, the ability to overcome challenges and changes without opposing the reactionary response of the stimulation of hatred and contempt for the different. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – What you said is very interesting, but would you perhaps not agree with me that it doesn’t matter from which side violence comes, whether it be the left or the right, bearing in mind that the National Socialists in Germany in the 1930s were socialists? They came from socialism, as did Stalin’s mob. So, quite frankly, in all this thing about fascism – they are always waving this word about – what about just making sure we don’t have violence on any side and settle everything democratically? Wouldn’t you agree with me that left—wing authoritarianism is just as bad as right wing authoritarianism? At the moment the Labour Party in Britain are having tremendous troubles.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Stalin, as far as I remember, was a communist. (Interjection from Mr Coburn: ‘... then so was Hitler and so was Mussolini!’) I know.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: blue-card answer. – I too listened carefully to what you said, but let me tell you that it is simply grotesque to maintain in the present day that there is a relationship between National Socialism and whatever socialism stands for throughout the history of Europe. Socialism is, first of all, democracy and respect for human rights, and National Socialism is pure fascism, which is the denial of democracy, human rights and the European ideal, the denial of civilisation and the instigation of hatred in a pure state of negative mind. So being a socialist in the 20th and 21st centuries means standing up against any form of fascism, whatever you call it. National Socialism is fascism, whatever you call it. (Interjection from Mr Coburn: ‘Tell that to Honecker’)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I wonder where he is.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Hans-Georg Maassen, president of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, was removed from office after declaring that the hunt for people in Chemnitz was politically correct fake news, as was a video published on the internet that was supposed to support this thesis. So far, we don't really know what happened in Chemnitz. I am surprised that so few questions are asked about this. But one thing is certain – Germany has a problem with fundamental rights, and the European Union authorities maintain a strange discreet silence. Because either German society is bad, or people are hunted on the streets, or the authorities of the Federal Republic mislead their society, hide the truth and manipulate public opinion simply in order to exercise power effectively. Out, out, tertium non datur. Germany has a problem, and the European Union authorities, who say they are defending fundamental rights, are not really interested in that at all. It is high time that we became interested in this, because one thing is certain. We act as if Germany is above the law.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not a direct question to Mrs Jurek, because the use of a few words in this House is unacceptable. I saw that there was no reaction. I call on the Presidency to listen again to the last passage of Borghezio's words and to judge those very words there, because I have waited so long, but I have not seen any reaction and I invite you to be able to hear them to decide on the case.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This should not require us to ask Mr Borghezio to repeat the phrase, but in any case I would appeal to you to mind your language and not to use bad language, if that was the case.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which In Germany alone, 169 people have died as a result of far-right and neo-fascist violence since 1990. The reason for this is right-wing slogans. Words that are contemptuous must not be trivialised, as is already happening today. First the language changes, and then the inhibition thresholds fall. We must not continue to relativise or even ignore neo-fascism, because in doing so we are insulting the victims and the bereaved of this heinous violence. Here, too, there are arsonists in this House who are partly responsible for the burning of asylum seeker homes and the death of people. And behind numbers are people and personal fates. We must not forget that. Ladies and gentlemen, whoever has a spark of decency among us opposes this burgeoning neo-fascism.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Fascism is not an opinion, but a crime. Only yesterday, a group of suspected far-right terrorists was arrested in Germany. Since last week, we have known, through research by renowned media, that at least 169 people have been murdered by neo-Nazis in Germany since 1990. About a month ago, a demonstration of neo-Nazis took place in Chemnitz together with AfD politicians, from which there were attacks on migrants and journalists. Just as a reminder, the leader of this party is also sitting here in Parliament. We, the left, will not leave Europe to the right and its murderous ideology. We are part of a strong movement of solidarity, democracy and anti-racism. In Germany, hundreds of thousands of people have demonstrated in many cities for basic human rights. In Berlin on 13 October, we are expecting hundreds of thousands of people to take part in the "indivisible" demonstration, which will oppose right-wing incitement under the motto "For a free and open society, solidarity instead of exclusion". No pasarin!

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, during Ramadan, I attended a wonderful interfaith community event at Didsbury mosque in my constituency. Taste Ramadan was on example of the We Stand Together movement that has grown up in response to the attacks on our multicultural 21st century society. On 20 October, activists from Stand Up to Racism and Unite Against Fascism will stand in solidarity with the mosque community against an intimidating protest planned by the fascist English Defence League.  But this is not an isolated incident. We have seen similar neo—fascists targeting communities across Europe because of their religion, race, ethnicity or sexuality. We mustn’t forget that the results of fascism in Europe are tragic. In 2016, a week before the UK referendum, a Nazi—inspired terrorist murdered the pro—EU Labour MP, Jo Cox, while shouting ‘Britain first’. Jo was the mother of two young children and an inspiration to many. I was privileged last week to attend the naming of a square in Brussels in honour of her memory. So let’s remember Jo’s message as we continue her work: we have more in common.  (The speaker declined to take blue-card questions from Mr Coburn and Mr Sośnierz under Rule 162(8))

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, neo-fascism is not just behaviours of modern movements similar to Mussolini's party. This obsession causes functional blindness to the fascism of everyday life that we experience as citizens in mostly democratically or democratically democratic states.  In a European Union of principles and values, in societies fighting against totalitarianism, neo-fascism is also expressed in hate speech, which is increasingly becoming systematic and dangerous in daily systematic violence against citizens. But it is also expressed in immoral and false news and attacks by anonymists against politicians through the media and the Internet with the aim of morally annihilating good politicians. Fascism is the gagging of every opposing voice.  This fascism is dangerous and insidious and is brutally and degradingly directed against the weak, foreigners, immigrants, homosexuals, the poor, the alienated; it severely injures the Republic and the rule of law. The European Union means responsibility and those who understand this responsibility fight against fascism.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: Mr President, it is a disgrace what is happening here today with some colleagues. We are talking about the increase in neo-Nazi violence in Europe and they are talking about communism and socialism. In fact, with what you're doing, you're exonerating fascism.  Golden Dawn, the neo-Nazi party we have in Greece, will be happy to listen to you, rub its hands listening to you. Those in my country killed; they killed a singer, they killed a migrant, for no reason, in cold blood, and they continue to attack refugees on the islands, the other day to an MP from SYRIZA, the ruling party. These are the real fascists and you close your eyes to them and, when you close your eyes, you are actually complicit.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a dangerous nationalist and fascist resurgence in many, too many of our countries. We are seeing more than 100 fascist attacks in Italy, as Eleanor said, in the last five years. Today there is something new: there are those who fill their mouths with security, but with their daily hate propaganda they are legitimising violence and becoming our cities less secure. We also saw it in Bari. I express once again my solidarity and sincere embrace to Eleanor, Claudio, Antonio and Giacomo. Dear President, dear Commissioner, this is happening today in Italy, fascist organisations are circling undisturbed with clubs ready and with the knuckle-knuckle in their pockets and the political cover of some ministers who, according to the Constitution, should disband those organisations, but prefer to go to dinner. Well, in our Union based on the values of democracy and respect for fundamental rights, this violence and intimidation cannot be tolerated. Resistance!

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Commissioner, I come from a country that knows very well what fascism is. We still have a foundation named after dictator Franco, we still have the summer residence, the Pazo de Meirás. Like this t-shirt, like this t-shirt I wear that represents 19 people who were peacefully in the residence of dictator Franco and who are now in court, a justice that consents. The Foundation makes the apology of fascism and should be outlawed, I repeat, illegalized. This is how we defend the historical memory group in the European Parliament and also the Valley of the Fallen. Commissioner, like so many questions we have already asked against fascism: zero tolerance. Unfortunately there are a good number of fascists who are represented in this Parliament.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, we do not ignore the causes and broth in which far-right and fascist forces feed. The European Union, which cynically invokes concern at this advance, is the same one that supported and continues to support the fascist coup in Ukraine, which imprints an exploitative and xenophobic nature on its migration policy, which promotes and deepens policies that attack social, labour rights and the sovereignty of states, which imposes threats, blackmails and sanctions against its peoples. The right-wing policies of the European Union, implemented by the right and social democracy, are not distinguished in the objectives of what reactionary forces advocate: to increase oppression, exploitation and concentration of wealth, to ensure the maintenance of an inique social order, that of capitalism. Fascism, the creation of capitalism, today has an unsettling institutional expression in parliaments and governments in the European Union. The firm fight against far-right and fascizantes forces requires that the policies that pave the way for them not be whitened.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, some people here have found the opportunity to discuss fascist violence to remember communism. But in turn we will remind them that if the red flag had not been pinned to the Reichstag and if it were not for the 20 million Soviets dead in the Second World War, today they would not be here or even talking.  The premeditated murderous attacks of the Nazi Golden Dawn in Greece and corresponding raid battalions throughout Europe document their Nazi, therefore criminal, character, with vulgar anti-communism, hatred for workers and communists; they are a force to attack the capital.  Five years after the murder of the anti-fascist Fyssa and their other crimes, the Golden Dawn trial is still not over and the fascists are on the loose. They are broken up by the anti-communist ideology of the European Union, they are bred by its unpopular policy, they take advantage of fair popular indignation, they are encouraged by parts of the capital and the state apparatus. The only answer is their isolation from the people, the struggle to overthrow the system that feeds them.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, in Asturias, my region, we have in recent weeks experienced a campaign of harassment of our public office, sharpened and amplified after the assassination of our councillor in one of our municipalities. I would like to express my pain at this savage crime: since they could not with the blows to the head, they ended up strangling it. Now, other charges of my party in another municipality, also from Asturias, have had to endure threats within three days of this murder, there have also been death threats against our mayor and, three days later, another councillor of ours had his car wrecked and painted him the acronym "Rest in peace". I myself, during my time as mayor, received anonymous and suffered threats, and even shot the dog into my house. The culprits were never discovered. He never put his efforts into it. Therefore, in the face of this situation that so many companions suffer from my party— and also, it must be said, from other political forces — we must become aware that what is at stake is the same democracy. And politics is not possible under threat, blackmail or coercion.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr Jurek, I understand the positions of everybody here, but we have to address the topic at issue here. I would conclude with the reflection of a Soviet scientist, who said that history is very difficult to predict. So let’s not get into that. (End of catch—the—eye procedure)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I will do my best! I would like to thank you for the debate, which was emotional and included very strong declarations, which is needed because we have to have debates about this very serious problem, not only in the parliaments but in the many other fora where people are still able to speak to each other. This is one of our problems, that people are more and more divided into bubbles, and this is also due to the digital development in our communication.  I will try to bring a little bit of peace into that because before, at the beginning, I spoke about law enforcement reaction, about sanctioning and about the need to penalise these symptoms and aggressivity and violence. I would like to pause a little while and consider the reasons why we are witnessing and living through increased violence and aggression in our society. We should speak more about the breeding ground, which is fear, which is poverty, which is uncertainty, which is confusion. People in Europe went through the financial crisis. Some Member States and some societies were more affected, some less. People are still stressed by the migration crisis of 2015 and 2016, which was unprecedented. We were not ready for that. We are stressed by terrorist attacks, we have a lot of uncertainty in our society due to something which sounds positive but which can have negative consequences on many people and that is the technological revolution. People have stopped understanding the world and they ask for more security and more certainty. My question is, why we as democrats, we who say clearly that aggression and violence is intolerable, that collective guilt is unacceptable, why are we not able to reach out to these people and to offer them more security and more certainty? Why do these people come and more and more believe the populist parties and the people who provide them with easy solutions, which might lead to another tragedy in Europe? I think that we should not only deal with the consequences – and this was the debate about the consequences here in Parliament – but we should speak more about the sources, about the breeding ground.  So I will do this, at least in my work, because I am in very frequent contact with normal citizens, with these people which have senior age. They have said to me: we fear, we are uncertain and we want our sons and our grandsons to have a peaceful life in Europe. We have to offer this to the people and we have to take lessons from history and consider seriously what the new elements are. I already touched upon this, it is the digital revolution. Just imagine if the totalitarian regimes of the past, and I will not name them because I don’t want to get into the passionate debate again, but what if they had this digital highway for propaganda? It would be much more efficient, much more easy to capture societies and to come with very dangerous proposals which, as we know, were realised.  This digital world enables us to reach for very good things and bad things at the same time. Here, I would say, we should be able to alert society because the passive majority, if it remains passive, will enable the evil again to rule the EU. I think that this is our task: to alert people. You know that we have the Code of Conduct against hate crime and hate speech. We are doing a lot against disinformation and sometimes when I see the statistical figures showing the increase of aggressivity and violence, I ask myself, is it really true that evil is so automatic and so strong and the good must be organised? I think that we should ask ourselves these questions and ask ourselves what are the most efficient instruments, how to address the majority of people, the honest people who need to have the option for their electoral preferences, to vote for the people who offer something other than aggression and violence.  Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much once again for this debate. I’m sure we will probably, unfortunately, have to debate these worrying phenomena and developments in the future, again.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I was just wondering whether, if you do not communicate in the normal way, but only through gadgets, where you can be very loose with language, and you then meet the real people, is there not an extension of everything you allowed yourself to say to them in that space, which could be translated into physical violence? So there might be this too, but you have a point in that sense.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: President—in—Office of the Council. – Mr President, the emotionality of this discussion and all the loudness clearly showed us how important this issue is. There are many factors, as mentioned by the Commissioner before, that might be sources of political violence. However, in my opinion – and I think it is the opinion of most of us – there is no excuse for any kind of violence and the Presidency, and the Council as a whole, rejects any form of politically motivated violence and intolerance, no matter where it comes from. We have a legal framework in place that needs to be effectively implemented in practice. We need to support it with targeted measures such as education, public debate and counter—narratives to prevent and tackle intolerance. The Council will continue to follow this debate closely. I can assure Members that I have paid particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate. In my opinion – and I think in the opinion of most of us – there has to be zero tolerance for any kind of political violence.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part—session in October in Strasbourg. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – In the face of the deepening structural crisis of capitalism, the most reactionary and aggressive sectors of the ruling class are increasingly betting on fascism and war to save the system, to maintain at all costs the inican social order that characterizes it.  The fight against fascism will be inconsequential if it does not identify the broth of culture that feeds it: the injustices and inequalities generated by capitalism, the polarization of unprecedented wealth, unemployment, precariousness and work without generalized rights, wages stagnant or having gone back to levels prior to 2007/2008. Its growth would be impossible without a schizophrenic media treatment that hides and exaggerates serious manifestations of reactionary and fascizante nature, in an ideological behavior that tends to trivialize the phenomenon instead of combating it.  The difficulties and contradictions of the bourgeois liberal representation system favour the demagoguery and a far-right radicalisation presented as "anti-system", and in which – as in the European Union – the interferences and impositions that trample national sovereignty are exploited to foment nationalism, the fundamental food of racism and fascism.  Fascism is not a fatality. But it is a real danger that it is necessary to fight with the greatest energy. A fight where we'll be on the front row. As usual.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. – Nazis are allowed to march on our streets and spread their hate. These groups attack everyone that does not fit into their fascist view of society: ethnic and religious minorities, refugees, LGBTI-people, feminists, human rights activists and political opponents.  They attack our democracy and freedom. Why and what are we as a society waiting for? We have already seen in Europe what fascism can do. When are we going to learn from the past? We have to ban Nazi and fascist organisations in Europe. We have to stand together against hate and violence.  It is our duty to stop this growing neo-fascist violence and hate. It is our duty to protect and revive our democracy before it is too late.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. Jean-Paul Sartre said that fascism is not defined by the number of its victims, but by the way it kills them. The rise of neo-fascist violence follows the general rise of far-right movements, mainly attributed to the economic and migration crisis. In the Member States most affected by the economic crisis, unemployment, austerity, the collapse of the social contract and the marginalisation of a significant part of the population have made it prone to the political discourse of the extremes. A divisive and populist speech with propaganda rhetoric, aimed at angering the recipient, bypassing any logical process. In an environment of insecurity and uncertainty, extreme anti-Europeans have managed to instill a new kind of cynicism in politics, in the face of xenophobia, intolerance and ethno-populism, resorting to the toolbox of fascism, which has been sealed for 70 years. The climate of hostility and the "legalisation" of violence followed as consequences, having led to the rise of neo-fascist and racist violence even in countries not particularly affected by the economic or refugee crisis. Our response to every extreme voice and to the ethno-populists: a new common European vision, fully based on the principles of solidarity and cooperation. European sovereignty stems from national sovereignty and does not replace it.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on: – the oral question on the deprivation of voting rights in the EU, addressed to the Council by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000069/2018 - B8-0039/2018) (2018/2676(RSP)) and – the oral question on the deprivation of voting rights in the EU, addressed to the Commission by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000070/2018 - B8-0040/2018) (2018/2676(RSP)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: author. – Mr President, it’s very interesting to be discussing this issue, which is of great importance to EU citizens, at this hour. However, I’m very pleased that this debate is taking place since voting rights is a key issue for the committee of which I am Chair, namely the Committee on Petitions, in this House.  Participation in the democratic life of the EU and the electoral rights of EU citizens living abroad in another Member State in the Union is frequently the subject of petitions to my committee. Six Member States – namely Cyprus, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Malta and the United Kingdom – systematically deprive their nationals of the right to vote in national elections due to their residence in another Member State. The same Member States also disenfranchise their nationals in European elections if they live permanently in a third country.  However, the right to vote is a fundamental right. Therefore, depriving citizens of the right to vote once they move to another EU Member State is effectively equivalent to punishing these citizens for having exercised their right to free movement in the Union.  These persons very often feel like second—class citizens. These practices can change their whole lives without giving them the opportunity to participate, which was the case for all the British citizens who were not allowed to participate in the referendum about Brexit because they had lived in another Member State for some time. However, they were directly affected by the result when Brexit was a fact. It is therefore high time that the Member States in this Union address this very concrete concern because disenfranchisement has huge consequences for all the individuals concerned. The loss of electoral rights for citizens moving to another Member State can be seen as an infringement upon freedom of movement under EU law. It could potentially stop EU citizens from exercising their right to free movement in the Union. Indeed, the discouraging effect in each individual case may be difficult to prove, but the violation of EU citizenship rights does not require statistical or other evidence. It’s enough to read the petitions to our committee. The main justification for disenfranchisement, that citizens living abroad no longer have sufficient links with their home country, seems completely outdated in the globalised world of today. We are interconnected with each other. The nationality bond with a state is still the main connecting factor for the rights and obligations of each citizen, but citizens resident abroad still have obligations deriving from their nationality so they should also be conferred their corresponding rights. In addition, there has been a Eurobarometer on electoral rights, where two—thirds of the respondents thought that it was not at all justified that people lose the right to vote in national elections in their country simply because they reside in another EU country.  The Committee on Petitions considers that EU citizens who move to reside in another Member State should have the possibility to exercise their right to vote in the national elections of their country of origin. The committee therefore calls on those Member States that disenfranchise nationals who choose to live for an extended period in another Member State to ease the conditions for these nationals and preserve their right to vote in national elections. The committee is aware of the fact that the decision on who is conferred the right to vote in national and European elections lies with the Member States. Nevertheless, we also know that the problem of the disenfranchisement of voting rights has been known for a long time. It is therefore high time to take action now.  We therefore urge the Commission to propose specific measures for removing any obstacles to free movement. Especially in view of the upcoming elections in May next year, we must safeguard the right of all EU citizens to choose to vote either in their Member State of origin or in the host Member State where they reside. I look forward to hearing your answers to the questions put forward by the Committee on Petitions.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the possibility for citizens to express their political will by exercising their right to vote is part of the very fabric of democracy. The Union itself is founded on the value of respect for democracy. For the Council, increasing and improving citizens’ participation in the democratic life of the Union is a priority and all European institutions and Member States should join forces to achieve this objective.  The Presidency notes the concerns voiced by Ms Wikström, reflecting the concern of the authors of the petition regarding the consequences of the disenfranchisement of voting rights in national elections in some Member States in relation to the exercise of the freedom of movement. However, the Treaties do not confer any power to the Council to act in this regard, as this is a matter of national sovereignty, which in many Member States is regulated by the Constitution.  Concerning the facilitation of the exercise of the right to vote, I want to emphasise that in July, the Council adopted a revision of the 1976 electoral law act, encouraging the Member States inter alia to take the measures necessary to allow citizens residing in third countries to vote in elections to the European Parliament. This has been without any doubt an important move towards a more participative European election process.  Regarding the upcoming elections to the European Parliament, the Council supports the EU—wide information and awareness raising campaign on EU citizenship rights, including electoral rights to support turnout. In particular, last year the Council adopted conclusions where it invited Member States to enhance citizens’ participation in the EU democratic process, for example, by better informing them of their rights to vote in local and European elections and by removing barriers to their participation.  In the discussion held last year in the Council on the EU citizenship report 2017, the Council asked the Commission to promote best practices implemented in the Member States to help citizens vote or stand in EU elections. The Council also considered as a positive measure the developments by the Commission of a multilingual standard form to facilitate the swift exchange of information between Member States to its contact points about the rights of citizens to stand as a candidate when residing in another Member State.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all let me thank the Petitions Committee for tabling this question. In my answer I will summarise what the Commission has done up to now on this issue.  Already in the 2013 citizenship report, the Commission underlined that full participation of Union citizens in the democratic life of the Union at all levels is the very essence of Union citizenship. The right to vote is also clearly at the base of democracy. While most Member States allow their citizens to vote in national elections and referenda in their home countries, a few, enumerated by Madam Wikström today, set considerable restrictions on this right when citizens move to another EU Member State. Since no EU country currently awards foreign nationals the right to vote in national elections and referenda, it means that some EU citizens cannot vote in such elections in any of the EU Member States. The Commission recognises that Member States are solely competent to determine who can benefit from the right to vote in national elections. The EU Treaties only guarantee EU citizens the right to vote in their state of residence in municipal and European elections. However, the founding premise of Union citizenship is that it is additional to national citizenship and is meant to give additional rights. The fact that the exercise of the right to free movement may lead to losing the right of political participation is at odds with that principle.  The Commission has kept the situation under observation for a number of years and the Commission therefore issued a recommendation in 2014, in which Member States were asked that their nationals might apply to remain registered on the electoral roll and therefore retain their right to vote. In last year’s 2017 a report on EU citizenship the Commission referred to this issue of disinfringement in national elections. It noted that 67% of respondents to the 2015 Eurobarometer on EU citizenship felt it was unjustified that citizens should lose their right to vote in national elections in their country of origin.  In April this year the Commission included this issue in the discussion paper transmitted to Member States ahead of an exchange between national election authorities organised following the Commission recommendation of February 2018 on the efficient conduct of the European elections.  Let me assure you that the Commission continues to monitor developments and initiate specific actions within its competence. The annual fundamental rights colloquium to be held on 26 and 27 November this year in Brussels is dedicated to this issue and the title of this year’s colloquium is ‘democracy in the European Union’. You are warmly welcomed to this event. The colloquium will include a session focused on the exercise of the right to vote when moving to another Member State. I am convinced that if we work together we can induce improvements. With regard to the question on the complaints received by the Commission, I would like to inform you that we analysed the ten complaints received in the past five years, but had to conclude that it was not possible to take further action, notably because of lack of competence.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the right to vote is fundamentally linked to the rule of law and the exercise of political rights, as well as to the free movement of Citizens of the European Union. I am surprised that in the 21st century, some Member States deny the right to vote in national elections to citizens living abroad. After all, the right to vote is one of the fundamental civil rights, and citizens of the same state should be equal in their rights. In some situations, if the state unjustifiably denies citizens the right to vote, it effectively creates secondary citizenship. Is a citizen guilty of working, studying or staying in another country? This does not mean that he does not care about the fate of his country and that he should not have the right to comment on his affairs. Member States should therefore pay more attention to the Commission's 2014 recommendation and allow at least those citizens living abroad who so request to participate in national elections. However, in the institutions of the European Union, we should deal mainly with European elections. I find it unfortunate that some Member States – and the Czech Republic are among them – do not allow their citizens living abroad to vote for their national candidates in European elections. I strongly support the current bill that has been submitted in the Czech Republic for the introduction of a correspondence vote. In european elections, this law would allow Czech citizens to vote for Czech candidates from abroad for the first time. I consider this fair in terms of equal treatment of citizens living abroad. And I believe it would increase turnout. Following this new possibility, there will, of course, also be the need to avoid the double application of the right to vote. However, I believe that good cooperation and exchange of experience with other Member States will help us in this, as will the recently approved amendment to the Electoral Code.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, EU citizenship is fundamental for our millions of citizens. It is a shared identity in addition to our national or regional identities which unlocks the possibilities of exploring this great continent, allowing free movement and the opportunity to live, work and study in other EU countries. Political rights as basic as the right to vote or stand as a candidate sit at the very heart of our shared European values.  Since the EU referendum, we Brits are perhaps more aware than most of the value of EU citizenship, since we fear we will lose it. However, while we might share equal treatment protection in the workplace and in access to university places, we do not have equal treatment in that most fundamental bedrock of our societies: the right to democratic participation. Citizens who have taken advantage of the freedom of movement from five Member States, notably my own, often find themselves completely disenfranchised of national representation. They are unable to vote in national elections, both in their home country and in their adopted country.  While I have sympathy for those who argue the logic that citizens who live in another Member State may not be affected by domestic laws or taxes made in their home country, this complete lack of national voting rights for EU citizens who have moved using EU treaty rights is incompatible with our European values.  Moreover, today we have a further complication – in fact, we have lots of complications in relation to Brexit – as we will see EU citizens, either UK nationals in the rest of the EU or EU citizens in the UK, disenfranchised on purpose. These EU citizens, whether Brits abroad for longer than 15 years or EU nationals from our sister countries in the UK, are the most acutely affected by Brexit. Yet they had no say in 2016, and now their democratic rights are being disregarded again as there are no provisions in the draft withdrawal agreement on voting rights, no guarantee of existing rights and no provision for future rights. This is a moral dereliction of duty. What are you doing in the Commission and the Council to avoid this intentional disenfranchisement? Personally, I support a people’s vote and a final say for all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the initiative of the Committee on Petitions to bring about the deprivation of electoral rights at European Union level, I think, is very important. And initiatives of this kind must be taken frequently, as we move towards the European elections, because there must be full safeguarding and exercise of electoral rights during the European elections, which come in a very short period of time.  There should be full safeguarding and exercise of electoral rights for those who have left their home Member States. And this applies to over 400,000 Greek citizens who left Greece because of the crisis, who must be able to exercise their electoral rights. And as long as it is in the European Union, this, at least from Greece's point of view, is possible. In other words, they have the possibility to vote by a Greek ballot paper, even if they are, for example, in France.  However, this possibility should, in our view, also be given to those Greek citizens who are registered to vote and reside in third countries, mainly in the United States, Australia and Canada. This is the Greek homogeneity which, if registered on the Greek electoral roll, should be able to exercise this right in the European elections, either by letter vote or at the consulates and embassies of Greece in these countries. Only in this way can there be a full exercise of electoral rights.  I also think that the debate should be extended to look at the conditions under which the media promote the European elections and the views of political parties.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you Mrs Jourová for being here today, because we are talking about the free movement of people, which has been one of the main historical flags of the European Union.  However, this freedom is perverted when a European citizen moves to another Eu country and loses his right to vote in his home country. This is the case in several Member States, including the United Kingdom, which withdraw citizens' right to vote when they move their residence.  What would have happened to Brexit if the million Britons living in other European Union countries had been able to vote in that referendum? And there is also the case of countries such as Spain, which do not withdraw the right to vote, but create procedures so complex that in practice it is impossible to exercise it. It's called a "begging vote."  It is deeply anti-European that there are borders for fundamental rights, that when a European changes his residence within the Union he becomes a second-rate citizen. It's up to us to avoid it.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in recent years we have indeed observed in the Committee on Petitions of this Parliament a sad reality, in which the right to vote, a basic political right, is systematically denied to millions of citizens of the Union. In my country, for example, the reform of the Organic Electoral Regime Act has helped 95% of people living abroad not participate in elections, because of existing administrative barriers. The techniques used, seen in other countries as well, include begging voting, unrefiable deadlines, complex consular procedures, paying the voting costs themselves, loss of voting documentation, lack of staff in consulates, etc. Voting has become an ordeal for more than two and a half million people living outside Spain. So, as elected representatives, we demand that States comply with democratic principles, remove all possible barriers and that the Commission make an overall assessment of compliance with electoral laws on the basis of their competences. Not taking action means robbing citizens of the possibility of expressing themselves, and stealing even more from the system the legitimacy it has.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, every country has the right to establish its own rules on how to conduct elections. Countries like Great Britain, which has had a functioning parliament for over a thousand years, do not need, with due respect, advice from the European Parliament, which only allowed elections in 1979. The rules in the UK are clear: a person cannot vote in a UK election if they are not on the electoral roll. This is a means by which we can ensure only people entitled to vote can do so. Without this very reasonable check, we could see elections in jeopardy. Already postal vote fraud perpetrated in some migrant communities has undermined the integrity of the vote in many constituencies. Over the last decade, an average of 282 complaints per election reached the Electoral Commission concerning electoral fraud. We have every right to maintain our strict system in the face of these challenges.  The EU complains about our system but fortunately, in March we won’t be here so you won’t have that problem. I would say to Ms Kirton-Darling and Ms Becerra Basterrechea regarding more Brits voting for the European Union if they’re abroad that I lived abroad for many years and you don’t get anybody more pro—Brexit than me.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The House should be very grateful to the Committee on Petitions for discussing the issue. However, it is not exactly the best broadcast and session time. Perhaps this should be taken into account in the future, because the issue itself is far too serious for us to deal with this as a last item on the agenda. In and of itself, everything seems clear. Citizenship and rights are regulated by the Member States. The right to vote is one of them and is the responsibility of the Member States. Now, as a naive contemporary, it is believed that the Member States are trying to ensure that their citizens retain this right for a long time. However, the truth is partly different or, to put it in a statesmanly way, the Member States decide very differently in the European Union when and how citizens who no longer live on their territory can exercise their right to vote. We cannot accept that the right to vote in the European Union is de facto dependent on the place of birth. As the previous speaker said, the situation with Brexit was particularly spectacular, if you will: british citizens who worked on behalf of their country in Brussels were not even allowed to take part in the vote on Brexit. This is in itself a rather grotesque situation. That is why I am asking – and the Council too – and the Council – that we know in the Committee on Petitions itself what the legal situation is – to discuss the right to vote, to harmonise it and to find a better solution. The right to vote is a fundamental right, and this should not be taken away from the citizens of the European Union and, above all, should not be made dependent on the place of birth.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the most important, most decisive election in the history of Europe is imminent. Yet we will deal with it in the absence of an intervention that absolutely must come, once again depriving thousands of European citizens of the right to vote, together with the right of free movement, if they reside in a country other than their own.  This is in the absence of uniform legislation because not all states remove bureaucratic barriers and allow voting under these conditions. All this is truly absurd and absolutely anachronistic. We are well aware of how complicated voting procedures abroad are often, but I would like to ask the Council how we can still, all the more so, at a time when coherence with regard to the founding values of participation and sharing and common planning should be, how such a situation can be pursued. Thanks to the intervention of the Committee on Petitions, we hope that what is a huge gap in the democratic exercise of all European citizens will be filled.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, citizenship is supposed to be a community of equals, yet 1.8 million EU right holders in the North of Ireland could be disenfranchised from their democratic right to vote and to stand in the European elections post Brexit. LBC has reported that the DUP wants, I quote, ‘as hard a border as possible’ in Ireland and disenfranchised citizens, no matter the cost. It is against the very principle of democracy that the citizens be left without a voice in any decision-making process that affects them, but that is actually what the Democratic Unionist Party is saying.  Sinn Féin has legal advice that demonstrates there is no constitutional or legal impediment to (a) facilitate external voting for all Irish nationals and (b) create a new European constituency for the North of Ireland. It is the entitlement and birthright of everyone born on the island of Ireland to be part of the Irish nation and therefore the Irish Government needs to amend its national law to reflect this. Civil liberties for people in the North of Ireland cannot be allowed to evaporate before our very eyes, and I want to say that this Parliament and the EU are saying they are going to uphold the Good Friday Agreement in all of its parts, then that means upholding the civil liberties of the people in the North of Ireland too.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, the right of suffrage is a fundamental right and is recognised in the Treaties themselves. More importantly, when we talk about European citizenship it is essential to guarantee the right to political participation.  Voting is a basic civil right; it is by no circumstances a privilege. We have received many requests in the Committee on Petitions warning of the difficulty of being able to exercise this fundamental right in some countries of the Union: in Germany, Denmark, Cyprus, Malta, Ireland and the United Kingdom; in Spain and Portugal, difficulties because of the obstacles that exist in order to exercise this right.  It is necessary to ensure this political participation if we really want to achieve compliance with European values. In this sense, in Spain, it seems that obstacles will be removed in order to exercise this right to vote. The latest news is that the request for the vote will be removed so that it can last four years; the deadlines for documentation to reach the voter will be extended; in addition to consulates, Cervantes institutes, regional houses, houses in Spain and other centres will be enabled in order to facilitate the right to vote, and will always be attempted to ensure that guarantees and transparency make such political participation as possible as possible.  It is true that the problem of external voting is more complex because there is more vulnerability and it is more difficult to ensure transparency, but it is essential to work from the Commission, the Council and the Member States to ensure that the free movement of European citizens, which is one of the Union's achievements, never impedes the right to political participation.  We need to ensure — and, in that sense, I think the Commission and the Council can do a lot — that the electoral participation of the diaspora ceases to be, once and for all, the Cinderella of democracy.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak this evening. Firstly, I want to say how appalled I was today to hear the British Prime Minister boast about ending freedom of movement. This is denying every UK citizen the opportunity to live, work and study across 27 countries. On a personal level – I myself, my family, my friends, my constituents – we are all going to lose our EU citizenship. This is something we value and it is shameful to boast about denying individuals the rights they currently enjoy. With Brexit, far from creating a global Britain, my country is becoming Little Britain, smaller, insular and isolated. On voting rights, the dreadful disenfranchisement of UK citizens living abroad during the EU referendum is one which the EU must never allow to happen again. How could those who have most to lose have been denied their rightful say? The terrible uncertainty hanging over UK citizens currently living in the EU is one which could have been avoided. The EU needs to act to protect all its citizens’ rights.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, can I first of all reiterate everything my colleague Catherine Stihler said just now. The right to vote is a fundamental right, and it is the fundamental right that itself protects democracy, because at the end of the day, it is democracy that protects the individual from the excesses of the state. That can only be protected by participation. However, instead of making it easier for people to vote now, we seem to be making it more difficult, either by rigging the register or making it more difficult for people to turn out to vote on the day.  It is vital that we give people who move the right to vote, because it’s people who move in search of work, to discover, to learn, to export, to trade or to create wealth who are the people to whom we need to give a stake in the communities in which they choose to live. Those who have chosen to live in the European continent have been betrayed by the British Government in that referendum and betrayed in the withdrawal agreement. We are now seeing Brexit for what it is, namely the wholesale removal of rights from individuals by the state. They should get the right to reconsider the outcome.  (Applause)

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the fundamental right to be able to vote in elections is the most important of political participation rights. Democratic participation at elections confers legitimacy to those exercising public power and their decisions affecting citizens. Democratic participation is also linked to the right of free movement in the European project. Nowhere was this more visible than in the Brexit referendum, in which more than 700 000 British expat citizens were not entitled to vote, although it was clear from the beginning that, out of all citizens, it was their lives that the referendum result would affect the most. Citizens who move to and reside in another EU Member State should not be stripped of their democratic rights in their country of origin. The Council and the Member States are well advised to take steps to ease the conditions of disenfranchisement and to protect the right of EU nationals living in another EU Member State to vote in elections and referenda taking place in their home country. (Applause)

name: Julie WARD
text: –Mr President, (inaudible) citizens in modern democracies and free movement of citizens is one of the founding principles of the EU, enshrined in the Treaties. Despite both these statements being facts, thousands of citizens are unable to exercise their right to vote because they’ve used the opportunity to live in another European country. As an elected Member from the United Kingdom, I’m appalled at my national government’s disregard for British citizens’ freedom to exercise conjointly the right to vote and the right to move freely in other European countries. Another very urgent issue concerns the rights of UK citizens who, despite having lived in European countries for many years, may not be able to take part in the local political life of their host country. This is also a concern for European citizens living in the UK. These voting rights are not merely abstract ideas, they have a concrete effect on national and European politics – one of them being the gerrymandered results of the 2016 British referendum. Now, less than one year away from the European elections, I hope colleagues realise what is at stake. The very survival of our citizens’ faith in the European Union as a truly democratic project.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, Ireland is one of six EU Member States which deprived their citizens of the right to vote in national parliamentary elections due to residence abroad. As I’m sure you probably know, there are a lot of Irish people abroad. If you’re gone for longer than 18 months, you’ve given up your right to representation, it seems. However, during both the marriage and abortion referendums, the ‘Get the Boat to Vote’ campaign demonstrated that thousands of Irish people abroad are deeply concerned about the future of their country and, if the property market would allow it, they would one day return. Last year our government made the tokenistic proposal to extend voting rights in the election of the president, a largely ceremonial role with no executive powers. Why not enact meaningful reform and allow every Irish citizen a say in how the country is actually run? The answer, of course, is that these disenfranchised voters are also disenchanted voters, and cannot be counted on for their support. By consistently refusing to act and privileging those voters who didn’t have to resort to migration, Ireland is effectively gerrymandering the country and blocking those most affected by the catastrophic decisions of successive Irish governments. It’s got to change.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the right to vote is fundamental, it is inalienable and, for this reason, it is self-evident for every citizen of a State of the European Union. Each State has an obligation to take the necessary measures to enable its voters to vote, whether they reside in their own country or in another country of the European Union, even in a country on another continent.  Unfortunately, however, some countries do not give this right to their citizens and do not allow them to vote in European elections when they live in a country other than their own. The argument that someone who lives in a third country – I mean another country in the European Union – does not have good information, so he cannot have a good judgment about what is happening in his own country, is at least hypocritical. Greece guarantees the right of Greek citizens living in European Union countries to vote in the European elections. However, it does not recognise this right to homogeneity living outside the European Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as I said at the beginning of this very interesting debate, the Commission does not have the general power to intervene in electoral matters and it is primarily for the Member States to lay down the arrangements on national elections, including defining the composition of the electorate. As I also said, the Commission will continue to work in this area within its limited competences under the Treaty. We have used and will continue to use all the tools at our disposal to address the issue of losing the right to vote in exercising the right of free movement. We look forward to continue working with Members of the European Parliament on this matter, and thank you for your attention.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the Council notes that, in accordance with Article 4, the Union must respect the national identities of Member States and that it belongs solely to the Member States to decide on the composition of the electorate for national elections. However, I want to thank you very much for raising awareness about these issues, which are important for those Union citizens who wish to move freely to another Member State and not to be penalised by such decisions. As mentioned by Commissioner Jourová, there will be a Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, where this issue will certainly be discussed in more detail. I think that we will certainly have the opportunity at this event to deepen the exchange.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate is closed.
